PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The explanatory memorandum to the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill commences by saying that the Bill will `implement Government initiatives to reduce the net operational and administrative costs of the Freedom of Information Act whilst maintaining maximum public access to information held by this Government'. I repeat those words `whilst maintaining maximum public access to information held by this Government'. If anyone believes that, he will believe that pigs have wings. The hallmarks of this Government from the outset, which have become increasingly entrenched in its conduct, have been hypocrisy, incompetence and excessive secrecy. This legislation exhibits all those hallmarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Freedom of Information Act was an initiative of the Fraser Government in 1981. In opposition it was condemned by the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, and the present Attorney-General and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen). Why was it condemned? It did not go far enough. Senator Evans had no doubts upon the subject. He said:

Good freedom of information legislation is that which would set a minimum of procedural obstacles by way of delay or complexity of costs, and afford the maximum of practical assistance to those who are pressing requests for access to information.
He went on:
Such legislation would contain an absolute minimum of exceptions and exemptions.
What he was saying was very clear. Delays, complexities and costs should be minimised. Obstacles should be minimised and practical assistance should be maximised. He said:
The present Bill . . . is not a good, effective, freedom of information Bill.
That was Senator Evans's lofty judgment. The present Deputy Prime Minister contributed his 5c worth. He said:
If we look at the Bill from the point of view of assessing its merit, in any marking it would get about five out of 10-barely a pass.
He also said:
We on the Opposition side believe that freedom of information is a basic right and it lies at the very heart of the democratic system.

I applaud his sentiment. I agree with it entirely, but what does it mean? It means, of course, that in the Government's view the Bill was a bad Bill. In government these open, honest devoted and competent servants of the people would fix it up; this galaxy of talents who have managed to run the Australian economy into the ground would maintain, improve and protect freedom of information and the rights of Australian citizens.

What do we have here today? Do we have a Bill that minimises delays, complexities, costs and obstacles that so concern Senator Evans? Do we have a Bill that maximises practical assistance to those who seek information from Ministers and from government departments? We do not. We have a Bill that guts the Freedom of Information Act, enshrines delay, hands Ministers and bureaucrats a set of road blocks to obstruct and frustrate those who want to use the Act and prices freedom of information beyond the reach of the ordinary citizen. So much for the commitment of those opposite to open government. So much for their commitment to the values which they espoused so hypocritically in opposition and which they disregard so deliberately in government. We have here the politics of hypocrisy, which has won the day and which, as we well know, is entrenched in the hearts and minds of this Government.

We have as well the obsessive secrecy that characterises this Government, particularly in recent times-a characteristic of a government in disarray, a Prime Minister without authority and a party with the stench of political defeat in its nostrils. Let me say in passing that that was epitomised by the way in which the Government approached the termination of the legislation set out to examine allegations concerning Mr Justice Murphy. We all recall that in the repeal Bill, as originally framed, any material that related to Mr Justice Murphy, regardless of how tangentially or peripherally, was to be entombed forever. That would have been the unmistakable and indisputable effect of what the Government tried to do. Caught out, damned by the Press and the Opposition, what was the Government's response? Senator Evans said that it was all a mistake. It was an `oversight' that had somehow escaped the notice of Cabinet, of the drafting instruction to Parliamentary Counsel, of Parliamentary Counsel himself, I presume, of Senator Evans and the Attorney-General, presumably of Labor's legislative committee and of Caucus. Nobody realised it until we pointed it out, but blind Freddie, if it was read to him, would have understood just what it meant.

The same obsessive secrecy is to be found in this Bill and it is to be secured in two ways which also demonstrate the complete hypocrisy of the Government's so-called commitment to freedom of information. There will be new and increased charges and there will be an escape clause. First, as to the charges, there is to be an application fee of $30 for every freedom of information request. There will be an increase in the charge for agency search and retrieval time to $15 an hour, and there will be a new charge of $20 an hour for agency decision-making and consultation time. There will also be a $40 application fee for internal review.

One might say that that is fair enough. After all, if these government servants have to search through the archives to find out what is there simply because some citizen is impudent enough to want to know something about how government works, they should be paid for their time. They are going to be paid for their time. It will mean this: An open-ended cost structure is to be set up under this Bill. Ministers and bureaucrats can take as long as they like and charge it off to applicants. They can wear them down through one of the oldest of devices-the burden of costs.

If one can believe the Department of Finance estimate, the average cost would be $310 per application. Let me give the basis for that figure. I refer to a letter dated 9 September 1986 from the Assistant Secretary, Resources, Policies and Management Branch of the Department of Finance to the Secretary of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. The letter was directed, among other things, to the $4m estimate of revenue to be gained from these new and increased charges. The estimate assumes 12,800 chargeable requests, an average of four hours per request for search and retrieval time and an average of 11 hours per request for decision-making and consultation time, including time taken in correspondence and/or discussions as necessary with other Commonwealth departments and agencies, State and local government departments and agencies with private sector bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much for morning and afternoon tea time?

—The estimate assumes 11 hours for lunch time, morning tea, afternoon tea, flexitime and paper shuffling. What does that add up to? It means that freedom of information will be beyond the price of the ordinary Australian. Who can afford those sorts of charges? Once the Government's servants and those in Ministers' offices know that there will be an hourly charge, it will be the easiest mechanism in the world: Keep moving the paper around slowly and even more slowly; and the costs will go up. The message will get through to the applicant and the outside world that if an ordinary citizen has an embarrassing request he should not apply because it will be very costly. Mark you, the story will be: `We would never do anything that was wrong. We would never do anything but seek to comply as quickly as we can, but these things take time. There has to be full examination of all the relevant facts, doesn't there?'. So much for the costs.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the escape clause, which might be called: `How Ministers can hide mistakes, conceal incompetence and bury from public scrutiny evidence of malice and falsehood'. It is called the `multi-document request'. It applies to Ministers and agencies. Let me give an example of how it applies to a Minister. If at any time-at any time, mark you-after a request is made the Minister himself is satisfied that the likely total work load, not the actual work load, would substantially divert resources or would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests under the Freedom of Information Act, he can decide that the request should be refused. Who judges? The Minister judges.

What is a multi-document request? It includes a request that relates to a number of specified documents. A `number of specified documents' means simply that-two or more. Incidentally, the existing test will be scrapped. Under the existing test there must be a substantial and unreasonable diversion of resources. Under the changed test, the diversion of resources has only to be substantial.

The position gets better and better from the point of view of this Government's Ministers, and worse for the public. In deciding whether to refuse, because of the `likely total work load', to use the words in the Bill, a Minister and the agencies can take account of difficulty in identifying, locating or getting into order-the word used in the Bill is `collating', which means getting into order-documents, having regard to office filing systems and locations. The worse the filing system, the easier the excuse. Embarrassing documents could be scattered around the country and the response would be: `It is terribly difficult. I cannot find the documents easily, because I have scattered them around the countryside. It will need a substantial diversion of resources to get them all back again'. That places a premium on inefficiency, inertia, bad faith and complacency. The worse one's filing systems are and the more incompetent one is, the easier it is to raise an excuse.

Another factor that can be taken into consideration in deciding whether to refuse because of likely work load is the likely need for and extent of consultations. We know what will happen. There will be long consultations. Another factor that Ministers and agencies can take into account is the time needed to decide whether there is exempt matter. Now, these things are going to take a long, long time and one can imagine what is going to happen. A departmental head is going to come to the Minister and say: `Minister, we have received a most embarrassing request for those documents that relate to that terrible case we have been trying to bury. Minister, it is going to take a long time to look at this matter'. The Minister will say `Do you think, Mr Departmental Head, it is going to amount to a substantial diversion of resources?', and the departmental head will say: `Yes, Minister, I think it is going to cause a substantial diversion of resources'. In that event the Minister will say: `We cannot have that, can we, Mr Departmental Head? After all, it is essential that my office operate efficiently, that the Department operate efficiently, and that we are not burdened by these unnecessary requests for freedom of information'. He will say: `Yes, Minister'. That is how freedom of information is being gutted under this Government, with its cant and humbug about its commitment to principle and open government.

Hypocrisy is the yardstick of conduct, secrecy the order of the day, and a high value is being placed on incompetence. We know that this Government badly needs the shroud of secrecy. We will not be part of this conspiracy against the public. We do not oppose the increases in charges and the new charges because we are not opposing, as a matter of general principle, the Government's revenue raising measures. No matter how bad the Government's reasons, in Committee we will be proposing amendments to meet a couple of glaring matters in the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill, things that should never be brought in under a government that had even the most vague commitment to freedom of information, but we will not oppose the Bill itself.
I think freedom of information was referred to by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech. May I remind the Australian people that on 20 May the Treasurer said this:
. . . what we have is an entirely healthy economy.
And he said this:
Let me make the point that the Australian economy has been entirely robust.

He did not say that on 20 May 1984 or 20 May 1985, he said it on 20 May 1986. We know that what he said was false. There is no contest in this House that, at that time, the economy was deeply sick. The only question is: Was his remark a deliberate untruth or was it the result of deep, dangerous and contemptible incompetence? That is the only decision, that is the only judgment, that the Australian people need make. It was one or the other; because there was no way that an astute, well-informed and honest Treasurer could have come into this House on 20 May and said what he then said about the Australian economy.

Upon return to government the coalition will maintain the Freedom of Information Act and, so far as it is possible, enhance disclosure under it. Exemptions will be reviewed and departments will be instructed that the primary obligation is to reveal, not to conceal, information and that compliance with the spirit of the Act will be closely monitored.

Our view on freedom of information is unambiguous and unyielding. In the absence of good reason, government information is public information. The democratic processes depend on an informed, active and critical public. No-thing prevents government repression, nothing prevents government falsity, nothing prevents government incompetence more than a public informed enough to prevent it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that the role of the Opposition is to oppose and constructively criticise. I suggest that anyone who was listening to the previous speaker, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), must be somewhat amazed at the hypocritical stand that was taken by him. He talked about the Freedom of Information Act being basic to democracy. Yet it is quite clear that he would like to see the whole concept of the Freedom of Information Act discarded. We well know what his views were when he was a supporter of the previous Government. He criticised the attempt by this Government to reduce costs. Yet in the last couple of weeks we have heard the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) say that government costs must be reduced and that if his Party were in power that is what it would do. By way of the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill, the Government is trying to bring down a common-sense approach, to put a limit on costs in this area; yet the honourable member criticises it.

SPEECH.PARA: I note also that, whilst the honourable member attacked the whole concept, he did not bother to explain to those who would be interested in this Bill that there are no fees or charges to be paid by persons seeking access to their personal income maintenance documents. He did not bother to explain that there can be a remission of the application fee on hardship grounds or on the grounds that the documents sought relate to an applicant's personal affairs. Instead, he came out with a diatribe about how it will destroy the whole concept of freedom of information. I suggest that it was a diatribe.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), when he introduced this Bill, clearly stated that the purpose of the legislation was to reduce administrative costs and to try to increase the revenue to government in order to meet the running costs. We all accept that the Freedom of Information Act is very important. It is publicly accepted as part of our parliamentary and bureaucratic system. But I also believe that it is accepted that there must be a limit to the cost of any service that is imposed on the Australian taxpayer. Yet we find this approach being taken by the Opposition.

It is not the first time that this Government has tried to address the problem of escalating costs in the provision of information. It is not the first time that the Government has tried to increase the contribution paid by users of the information service. Honourable members know that in November last year the amendments put forward by the Government were defeated in the Senate. I hope that a more enlightened attitude prevails when this Bill proceeds to the Senate this time. I suggest that it is important that the costs to the user of the Freedom of Information Act are not exorbitant. I accept that it should not be a deterrent. But at a time when the community is expected to carry a cutback of $3,000m in existing government programs-and that is what the Budget has done; it has cut $3 billion from existing government expenditure-it is only proper that the freedom of information service should bear its share of the cutbacks in government finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish. You have spent more money.
—I hear the honourable member for O'Connor.
—The highest taxes in history.

—That is not true. But let us come back to what this is about. At the moment the return to government from the users of the freedom of information service is 50c for every $100 spent. Honourable members should think about that for a moment. For every $100 of cost in providing the freedom of information service to the people of Australia, the contribution by the user to government revenue is 50c. It is no wonder the government believes that, when one weighs up the costs incurred in pursuing a request for information, the community will accept the proposition that a $30 application fee is not too high. That fee will apply to all requests. Likewise, the increase in the charge on time spent in searching for and retrieving documents-an increase from $12 an hour to $15 an hour-is certainly not exorbitant.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the economic circumstances that our nation faces, I welcome the amendments contained in this Bill. But I regret that we have not addressed the existing Act in other ways by broadening the all encompassing role and powers. I see a need for even more open government in other administrations and legislatures in this nation. I would like to see the right of citizens to access to information broadened. I would like to see it broadened in such a way that it covers certain aspects of State government-those aspects where Federal moneys are involved.

I listened with interest this morning to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) when he talked about his efforts to try to get information from Queensland concerning Federal moneys that have been used and abused in that State. I suggest that if ever there was an example of the need for freedom of information relating to government decisions and expenditure at a State level, it is certainly Queensland. Last week the Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Nev Warburton, raised the issue of a National Party official and a former Senate candidate, Michael Behan--

TALK.START.PARA: —Walshie should have got someone to forge it.

—If the honourable member agrees with what took place he should stand up and say so, otherwise he should sit back and listen. Michael Behan, a Senate candidate for the National Party and a senior National Party official, was given a loan of $145,000, not on the direction of the Agricultural Bank but on the direction of a Cabinet Minister despite the recommendation from that bank that the loan application be not approved.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the Standing Orders which require a speaker to be relevant. If this speaker is permitted to draw in--
—Order! I take the point.

—Madam Speaker, I wish to speak to the point of order. If this speaker is able to refer to an example where freedom of information is requested, I shall turn my mind to the Murphy judicial commission and other matters affecting this Government.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I have been listening to the honourable member for Capricornia. I presume he is setting up some sort of analogy. I will listen with interest.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. I was suggesting, before the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) tried to cut me out, that there is a need to broaden the scope of freedom of information in our nation. Just as the people of Australia have the right to delve into decisions made by the Federal Government, I am suggesting-the only time one can raise such a matter, as you, Madam Speaker, would be aware, is in a debate that pertains to the Freedom of Information Act-that there is a need to broaden the present Act which we are now debating to encompass other Federal Government matters that relate to the States. I centre my remarks on the Federal money that was used by the State of Queensland. Some $85,000 of Commonwealth money was given to Queensland, under the national disaster relief scheme, at an interest rate of 4 per cent. However, secretly and by special ministerial direction, it was given to a National Party official who, the Agricultural Bank said, did not deserve to get it. In fact his whole farm was non-viable. It has taken more than a week for the facts to emerge because in that State, where there is no Freedom of Information Act, the Premier tried to cover up the issue. When the details finally came out he called it `a lousy $145,000'.
—It is okay for him to say that.

—It is okay for him to say that but I suggest to the National Party Government of Queensland and to the Premier that tens of thousands of primary producers would certainly not look upon that loan as a lousy $145,000. As Nev Warburton said, many farmers in Queensland, and for that matter throughout Australia, have virtually got down on their knees before the agricultural banking organisations and the rural reconstruction boards for much less than a lousy $145,000-as Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen calls it-and they have all been refused.

SPEECH.PARA: The significance of my comments is that this is Federal money; this is money that this Government has appropriated to the State of Queensland but we have no way of knowing what happens to it. This is so with moneys from rural reconstruction and rural adjustment schemes where this Government and previous governments-the Fraser Government was involved-have given tens of millions of dollars to the States. Yet there is no way we can find out what really takes place with it. The people of Queensland, the people of Australia, have a right to know what takes place. We do not know on how many other occasions similarly politically motivated deeds have been done for National Party supporters and members when it comes to giving away State funds and moneys given by the Federal Government and have not been aired unless some public servants in Queensland--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. On the matter of relevance, I am sure that your tolerance has gone far enough. Quite obviously the Government has the right at any time to pass legislation to keep track of its own money. This has no relevance to freedom of information, which is about seeking information from the bureaucracy. The honourable member has had a good go.
—I suggest to the honourable member for Capricornia that he return to the Bill.

—I am speaking to the Bill. Madam Speaker, you would know that this morning the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, raised this very issue publicly and I suggest that it is very relevant. I would not argue in any way with what you have had to say.
—The honourable member for Capricornia will stick with the Bill.

—Yes, I shall. Madam Speaker, you would be aware that the Bill refers to the right of people having access to information. I believe that the people of the Commonwealth of Australia like to know, for instance, what really happened to the $20m that was given by the Commonwealth to Queensland for roads in north Queensland. No one knows where it went because we cannot get at the information. It is believed that the $20m was spent on the rail electrification scheme in Brisbane, but there is no way of knowing. What we know from Budget papers and the Auditor-General's papers in Queensland is that something like $10m has been transferred from the rural adjustment and rural reconstruction schemes to Consolidated Revenue.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order, Madam Speaker has just ruled that the honourable member for Capricornia is to stick to the Bill. The legislation before us is the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill and is for the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. The honourable member keeps going back to situations relevant to the Queensland Government and to the road funding agreements and other Commonwealth legislation. If he wants to debate those matters he should do so when the debate on them is current. The debate he is taking part in relates to this Bill, and if he cannot talk to it he should sit down and let someone else who has prepared his speech properly do so.
—The point has been made. I ask the honourable member for Capricornia to stick within the terms of the Bill.
—I ask for your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—You have just had a ruling.

—The honourable member should just listen; he should clean his little ears out. Mr Deputy Speaker, is it not the right of the people of the Australia to use the Freedom of Information Act to find out what happens with government moneys at a Commonwealth level? Is that not correct? I am suggesting that when those moneys are spent by the Commonwealth-regardless of where they are spent, be it on a Commonwealth roads scheme administered by the States, be it through a farm improvement program--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order.
—Order! There is no point of order at this stage.
—Be it in any area where there is a Commonwealth jurisdiction or--
—I am raising a point of order.
—Order! I am listening to the honourable member for Capricornia.

—Be it on a joint activity with Commonwealth and State Ministers, the people have a right to know what happens to that Commonwealth money. That is exactly what this issue is all about. I am putting to this House instance after instance where money has been given to the States, to Queensland, and we cannot find out--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member is not speaking to the Bill.

—Order! The point of order has been made previously. I do not think the honourable member for O'Connor needs to raise a further point of order. The honourable member for Capricornia has sought the Chair's opinion on this matter. Madam Speaker, who was in the Chair when the matter was first raised, made it fairly clear to the honourable member for Capricornia that he should stay within the bounds of the legislation. Some of the matters the honourable member raised a moment ago certainly would be relevant to the Bill. I was not here for the earlier part of his speech, but rather than hold him up and have persistent points of order raised on his speech, if the honourable member can restrict himself to within the confines of the Bill, the House will be able to give him the time allotted to him.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate that ruling. It is quite clear that Opposition members do not want members of this Government to raise these points about the Queensland Government. That is what this is really about. I believe that those listening to this debate will agree with me that they have a right to know what is going on. It is quite clear that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) would like to see a closure on any information that relates to governments in which the Opposition has an interest. Do Opposition members support the $85,000 given by this Commonwealth Government to Queensland for national disaster relief being lent to a National Party crony? If they do, let them stand up and say so. Or do they believe-they have supported it in this House; it was Mr Fraser who introduced the legislation--

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: Is the honourable member going to speak to the Bill? He is using every device available to him not to do so, and I congratulate him on his skills. But it is your responsibility to see that he speaks to the legislation. It is Commonwealth legislation and it is quite clear. He should be very concerned about some of the matters that have been raised if he has the sorts of concerns he says he has. This is a restrictive Bill. It is going to cut back on the opportunity to get information.
—There is no point of order.

—The honourable member for O'Connor said that it is a restrictive Bill. In fact, in speaking to the Bill I am saying that there ought to be an expansion of the very role and powers of this Bill to encompass these areas. On one hand we have the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) talking about restrictions. I am suggesting that we turn that whole thing around. I am saying why we should do that, and I am keeping it very closely linked to Commonwealth involvement, because we know what takes place in the State of Queensland. We know that moneys have been misappropriated. We know that Commonwealth moneys have been misused, whether they be Commonwealth road funds or Commonwealth health funds.

—I rise on a point of order. The honourable member has the opportunity to move an amendment to this legislation to achieve his aims. If he is prepared to do that, the Opposition will give him that opportunity.

—I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to resume his seat. There is no point of order in that suggestion whatsoever and if the honourable member for O'Connor continues on these frivolous points of order I will take action. I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to resume his seat.
—I will move dissent from your ruling. It is a clear requirement of this Parliament--
—You will do anything to try to stop debate, won't you?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, are you ruling that it is not appropriate to--

—If that is your ruling, I move dissent from your ruling. If I am given a piece of paper, I will write that dissent out now.
—You are a sick person.
—I ask that that be withdrawn. Firstly, I am quite healthy and--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I request that that disparaging comment be withdrawn.
—I ask the honourable member for Capricornia to withdraw that comment.
—And I ask the honourable member for Hindmarsh also to withdraw his comment when the honourable member for Capricornia has withdrawn.

—I request that the honourable member withdraw without any qualification.
