SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to let the occasion pass without drawing the Australian public's notice to the fact that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), is a former Leader of the Opposition in Queensland who was dusted up by the Premier of Queensland. Since then he has come to Canberra, and he thinks he can fight a Queensland election from here. If the honourable gentleman wants to get himself involved so totally in Queensland matters, let him return to Queensland, stand for the State Parliament, and have another go at Joh from there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill presents a particular problem for the Opposition. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the shadow Treasurer, often refers to this place and politics as attempts to reconcile the irreconcilable. That is true of the Bill in some ways, for listeners to our debate would have heard clearly from the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), that the Opposition is largely in opposition to the proposals put before it by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the Bill. We are opposed to many of the Bill's provisions for very good reasons to which I shall come. Our problem is that we are in Opposition and it is not our position to rewrite the Budget from Opposition. It is not our position to attempt to run the country from Opposition. When people say to me that they hope an early election is in the offing, I agree with them. The sooner we have an election and get rid of this Labor Government and start to turn the country around, the better we shall all be.

So we find ourselves up against two principles. The first is that we are opposed in large measure to what is in the Bill. The second is that we are not prepared to stand in the way of a government undertaking its budgetary process. Later today we shall be discussing some amendments which go to some of the functions and clauses that are set out in the Bill, but we shall not be standing in the way of measures that are budgetary items. The process is rather frustrating because we are faced with a ploy. The Government has thrown this measure in with the Budget to place us in the difficult position of not being able effectively to prevent it. I say that it is a ploy because the Government adopted a similar approach last November when it tried to sneak through some regulations which it tabled in the Senate. Fortunately, the non-government parties in the Senate had the necessary numbers and we were able to put a stop to that ploy, which was designed to bring in some charges through the back door.

When the Government was in opposition it was a strong supporter of many things. For example, it supported an increase in pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, a policy which it dumped as soon as it got into government. In March 1983, the Prime Minister promised to drop the price of petrol by 3c. As one of the Tasmanian members said yesterday, the price of petrol has done nothing but go up and up ever since. The Government supported also bans on uranium mining. However, when a South Australian election was on, it supported and gave approval to the establishment of Roxby Downs, one of the largest uranium mines in the world. If that is a little bit difficult to understand, I should explain that there is an inconsistency. While Roxby Downs was allowed to proceed, the Government stopped all the other uranium mines going ahead. Just to top it off, we have had the proposal that there should be uranium mining in Kakadu Park. Does the Government `Kakado' or `Kakadon't'? It seems not to know whether it is coming or going, whether it is Arthur or Martha.
A year or so ago the Labor Party was against uranium exports to France, but that policy was dumped in the Budget for about $60m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel compelled to raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. What this speaker says is not relevant. Since the ruling on the previous speaker was taken in such a narrow vein I ask that you rule that the current speaker speak to the Bill. The Bill has nothing to do with uranium at Kakadu.
—The honourable member for Hindmarsh has made a point. The Chair has been fairly liberal with previous speakers, but I ask the honourable member for Flinders to stay within the confines of the Bill.

—I appreciate the sensitivity of the honourable member for Hindmarsh on this matter as I think he was one of the three members who walked out of the chamber when the uranium decision was announced in the Budget. In deference to him I will try to keep clear of what has been a very sensitive subject.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I ask the honourable member to withdraw the inference that I am sensitive. I am not at all sensitive about the question of uranium.

—The honourable member for Hindmarsh will realise that there has been no personal reflection on him in the remark made. Again, I ask the honourable member for Flinders to stay within the confines of the Bill.

—I will be very pleased to do that, Mr Deputy Speaker. I started with a preliminary point and one made very eloquently by the shadow Attorney-General when he raised the question of hypocrisy-hypocrisy with a capital H. He went to the Hansard and quoted Senator Evans in April 1981 when the present Government was in opposition. I did not discuss this matter with the shadow Attorney-General before today but it is interesting that the references he took out of the Senate debate suggested that the then Opposition did not think that the Bill went far enough and that it was barely a Bill, et cetera. When I went to that same speech I took out a statement of principle of support for freedom of information which was then laid down by Senator Evans. I will quote what he said in Hansard when he was in opposition in 1981. It is interesting how opinions change when one party moves from opposition to government. At page 1230 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The case for such legislation is overwhelming . . .
He also said:
It is necessary to remove the unnecessary secrecy which can be used to conceal weak or inappropriate or sometimes even improper grounds for decision-making.
He later went on:

. . . not least, freedom of information legislation is necessary to maintain and improve the quality of our political democracy. That is the point the Senate Committee made very succinctly in a very early paragraph of its report.
Senator Evans quoted from paragraph 3.7 of that report which I do as well. It states:

The essence of democratic government lies in the ability of people to make choices: about who shall govern; or about which policies they support or reject. Such choices cannot be properly made unless adequate information is available. It cannot be accepted that it is the Government itself which should determine what level of information is to be regarded as adequate.

That is a statement with which I am happy to agree. I am glad I can agree with it because if one does not agree with Senator Evans one is very quickly a troglodyte or a neanderthal. They are terms I think most Australians do not understand, but I can tell them that those terms are not very nice and that they are certainly creeping into the vocabulary of the Government. That paragraph, the statement of that proposition, shows very nicely what hypocrisy we have in the Bill before us today. Let the Government have no doubt that the man in the street does not take kindly to this sort of freedom of information amendment law being introduced. I was out door-knocking a couple of weeks ago with Tom Warwick who is the very good candidate for the Liberal Party of Australia for the seat of Dunkley. Tom was pretty keen, as soon as he was pre-selected, to get out door-knocking. We were talking to people in Frankston- -

TALK.START.PARA: —This has got a lot to do with freedom of information.

—It is all tied up. One bloke said to me `I am a Labor voter, mate. I am against uranium mining'. I said `We have a difficulty, because I am a Liberal and I am in favour of it. What is your attitude to the Labor Party?' He said `It is not about uranium. The one thing I cannot stand is hypocrisy'.

SPEECH.PARA: Freedom of information legislation is an important means for individuals to find out how a government is spending its money and how it makes decisions which affect us all. As the Go-vernment's political troubles pile up, it is fairly typical that it should attempt to close off those avenues which have provided considerable embarrassment to it. The Bill was introduced as a Budget measure, but it is just a ploy to introduce restrictions under the all-embracing heading of cost restraint. As I said earlier, the Government tried the same trick last year and was defeated in the Senate in November 1985. The basic means adopted to stop access is to charge like a wounded bull for information. The Government's argument is that the costs have grown out of all proportion and that, therefore, people should pay for the information that they require. The expected costs of operation and administration are about $15m per annum.

My experience of the Freedom of Information Act is that much of the cost has been brought about by Ministers and agencies who are reluctant to provide information. I have had some experience of it, and I wish to bring to the attention of the House some examples-some case studies-of where costs have blown out of all proportion, not because people have properly sought information, but simply because every sort of obstacle has been placed in their way.

The Commission for the Future is one of the Government's pet projects. It is a complete waste of money which, I might add, has been allocated 50 per cent extra funding this year. Some time ago I asked the Commission for the Future for some documents on its operation. On my first request, I got the information fairly quickly. I suspect that I got it fairly quickly because other members had asked for it. The Commission had been through the process before, it had it all there and I got it without trouble. I received a list of consultants, so I asked for copies of the documentation relating to the appointment of consultants. The 45 days came and went. I then lodged an appeal on the grounds that it was a deemed refusal, and that caused additional costs. There is no basis upon which that information was delayed for 45 days and no basis upon which a situation was allowed to develop whereby I could subsequently lodge an appeal. The documents then turned up and the matter has therefore been effectively discontinued, but that is an example.

I am glad that the Attorney-General is in the House, because in mid-January I lodged an application with the Constitutional Commission when I was filling in for the shadow Attorney-General. I telephoned the officers concerned and asked about the costs, and I was told that I could not have any figures. I spoke to one bloke who had the figures on his desk, but he was naturally hesitant to give them to me. That aroused my suspicions, so I lodged a freedom of information application. I would have thought that it was pretty reasonable for a Federal member of parliament to seek details and information on the establishment costs of a body such as the Constitutional Commission, which is supposed to give us a new Constitution by 1988, when we celebrate the Bicentenary.

I lodged an application in January. When I lodged it, I said that the Government had not provided me with the information that I had requested and I hoped that that did not signify that there had been some appointments or jobs for the boys in the Constitutional Commission. After 87 days, I lodged an application for refusal. We had a preliminary hearing with a barrister who was employed by the Commonwealth and who had a solicitor and a few departmental blokes present. They kept drip-feeding me with documents. On six separate occasions, the documents were fed out to me-I suppose to lure me on. We ended up having a full hearing with a very good, senior barrister from Melbourne. Two departmental blokes from Canberra had to go to Melbourne for a briefing, to give instructions to the barrister, and then they had to fly the barrister to Canberra for the hearing, and I suppose that was paid for. The hearing went on for a day, and I suppose that his overnight accommodation, et cetera was paid for. Of course, there was some embarrassment, because we found that Mr Whitlam was getting so much per sitting day and that his former Press secretary was involved. There were all sorts of moneys involved, and questions were raised.

That is an example of how the action or inaction of government affects the costs of a freedom of information application. This was a very simple one. The Constitutional Commission had been announced and formed in December, and in January I wrote to ask how much it was costing. The costs involved in this freedom of information application must have been astronomical. There were about seven blokes at the hearing, against me doing it on my own. I do not know why the Commission had to have so many people there or why it had to bring a bloke from Melbourne.

The Murphy matter is another example. When it appeared that the High Court or the judges unofficially were going to look at the matter, I asked under the Freedom of Information Act for documents that the Attorney-General may have forwarded to the High Court justices to help them with their consideration of the matter. After some considerable time, a decision was made and they asked me for $12.50. I can understand that there was some cost involved, but my reaction to that was that if the Attorney-General was sending information across to the High Court justices-and it was a matter of public interest-those documents should be released without charge. But they asked for $12.50, so as a matter of principle I said `It is a matter of public interest and I seek remission'. It took nearly three weeks for me to get a decision on whether they would waive the $12.50. It was absolutely crazy. I hate to think how long it took them to make up their minds on that one.

Under the Act covering the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the Commission has the right to appoint advisers and consultants. I would have thought that it was pretty reasonable for a Federal member of parliament to ask the Commission to tell us who it has appointed as advisers and consultants. I have lodged a freedom of information application, but I have not heard a word from the Commission. I can be sure of one thing-that I will not hear from it. To get the basic information to which every Federal member should be entitled and which should be public knowledge, because it is taxpayers' money, I will have to lodge an appeal. There will be great expense, and the Government will stand up here and say that freedom of information is costing too much.

I could give many such examples. I could tell the House about the Australian Tourist Commission. I have had a run-in with it. I will have a run-in with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). I have asked him how he costed his work-for-the-dole scheme. He has said that it would cost $700m to introduce it. Surely it is not unreasonable for him to produce his calculations, but I know that there will be a fight on that one. On ministerial allowances, I have asked the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) for the documents showing the nominations by Ministers and office-holders of their principal places of residence. There is no basis upon which this information should be delayed. If there were a real commitment to freedom of information, much of this cost would be avoided.

Not only politicians are interested in information. One of the amendments provides that someone can have information if it relates to incomes support. In many situations, private individuals should have reasonable access to information. One case is that of Mr Trewin of Wonthaggi who, when he was a prisoner of war and without his knowledge, was demoted from Acting Corporal to Private. It is a simple case, but it is quite unreasonable that the government should introduce legislation, for example:
to introduce an hourly charge for decision-making time. . .
That is an hourly charge for blokes to stand on their shovels. Another reason is:
to strengthen provisions for refusal of requests on workload grounds. . .

Many public servants have said to me: `We cannot help you because we are too busy'. What sort of a response is that? I am disappointed with the legislation. I hope that the Government will reconsider it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the honourable member for Gippsland, I inform the House that the honourable member for North Sydney has indicated to me that he seeks leave of the House to correct a statement that he made earlier.

—In my speech, based on a Department of Finance estimate, in information contained in a letter, I cited $380 as the average cost of an application. According to the Department's information, the figure should have been $310, made up of $60 for search and retrieval fees, four hours at $15 an hour, $220 for decision and consultation, 11 hours at $20 an hour, and a $30 application fee. I thank the House for its indulgence in allowing me to correct the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most consistent characteristic of Labor governments is that, sooner or later, they will repudiate promises and commitments they made while in opposition. The betrayal of so many disaffected Labor supporters who plague the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by way of demonstrations wherever he goes is ample evidence of that. I do not know why the Prime Minister's shocking turnabouts of recent days should surprise any of his previously fervent supporters. It certainly comes as no surprise to any of us who witnessed his track record as leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the record of the previous Labor Government. Again, there has been a total turnaround, a betrayal of the most basic principles fundamental to the operations of a democracy, in the restrictions placed on the Freedom of Information Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The shutters have come down on open government. Let me make it perfectly clear: The Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill is not an attempt to defray the costs of freedom of information applications; it is an attempt to restrict access. All of us have an understanding and an appreciation of the need to curtail government expenditure, but the problem inherent in the legislation goes beyond the increase in fees. It is the opportunities that are given to the Executive arm of government to deny information that gravely concerns me as well as my colleagues in the Opposition.

At the conclusion of this debate I intend to send a copy of the Hansard record to the producers and script writers of the very popular and too-often revealing program Yes Minister. Nowadays, of course, the program is called Yes Prime Minister. It would make a fascinating episode to show how the bureaucracy, in collusion with Ministers, has completely manipulated access of the individual citizen to the workings of government.

One does not need a fervent imagination to conjure up an image of Sir Humphrey, that arch bureaucrat, reassuring his Civil Service colleagues that they need not worry about pesty, insignificant citizens who may have an eye on an opening into the workings of the Civil Service-the mystery, deepness and vastness of the Public Service will never be explored under this Freedom of Information Act. At the same time, Sir Humphrey will advise his Minister that his Government need never lay itself open to any embarrassing disclosures or any kind of accountability to this country's citizens. It will be an interesting episode because, for the first time, it will not be Sir Humphrey putting it over his Minister; it will be a partnership between Sir Humphrey and Jim Hacker to remove any type of inquiry into their respective responsibilities.

I immediately see a number of similarities between the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who has charge of the Bill, and Jim Hacker. The Attorney-General is a bus accident away from the prime ministership. Jim Hacker, who is of a similar disposition to the Attorney-General, found himself thrust into the prime ministership.

TALK.START.PARA: —He looks a bit like him, too.

—Our Deputy Prime Minister even looks a bit like Jim Hacker. There is no question that the Government impaled itself on its rhetoric when in Opposition. Senator Evans, the then Opposition shadow Attorney-General, when speaking on the Freedom of Information Bill 1981, spoke with grand and high sounding rhetoric about the need for ordinary people to scrutinise the actions of the Public Service and the Executive arm of government. Is it not sad that now he, together with the present Attorney-General, acts so stringently to close off any avenue, any real opportunity, for individuals to inquire into the actions of government. Let me quote one section only of the Hansard record of 8 April 1981. The cliches espoused by Senator Evans are so fine sounding that one could speak at length on them, but the following caught my eye especially:

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary to remove the unnecessary secrecy which can be used to conceal weak or inappropriate or sometimes even improper grounds for decision-making. It is our task, as a Senate, as a Parliament, as elected representatives of the people, to make it a good, effective, Freedom of Information Bill. The extent to which we succeed, as a co-operative legislative exercise, in improving this Bill will be an excellent measure of the seriousness with which we are entitled in the future to describe ourselves as legislators and as parliamentarians.

By the standard set by Senator Gareth Evans, he and the Government have failed totally to be regarded as legislators and parliamentarians. Instead, they are revealed as a self-interested group seeking only to protect themselves from accountability.

Let us examine how the legislation will close off the opportunities for individuals to scrutinise government actions. The first is the charge of $20 an hour for decision making and consultation time. That means that a public servant can charge $20 an hour for the time spent on deciding whether or not an application should be granted. It means that, where requested documents may cover sensitive areas-the Attorney-General said in his second reading speech that examples of that may be security, law enforcement, business, policy development, and so on-it is necessary for agencies to consult widely. We appreciate that. The point is, why is the discretion left entirely to a public servant to decide the time limit spent on such consultations? A public servant, bent on denying an application, need only resort to that measure to make it financially impossible for an individual to continue with an application.

Another measure is that the legislation strengthens provisions for refusal of requests on work load grounds. This is the classic: Refusal of request on work load grounds. Good heavens! The Government itself has said that 2,000 surplus public servants need to be removed. Now it tells us that the Public Service may be unable, on work load grounds, to comply with applications.

The Minister said in his second reading speech that he is unable to formulate a test for what constitutes an unreasonable work load. He is unable to lay down even guidelines, let alone a concrete test that a public servant must satisfy to justify refusal of an application. Again, the discretion lies with the Public Service or, perhaps more accurately, with the Public Service in conjunction with the Minister or at the direction of the Minister. Nonetheless, it is yet another aspect of a shield that the Public Service and a Minister can use to deny applications to the workings of government.

A further aspect that concerns the Opposition is that the present 45-day limit on answering requests will remain. Under the existing legislation the time limit for responding to requests would reduce to 30 days as from 1 December 1986. This legislation will enshrine the present arrangements, making 45 days the minimum under which a response need be made. Again, that is a tightening of the ability of an individual to receive within a reasonable time an answer to his or her application. It is yet another tool to be employed by the Government in restricting access to government functions. Interestingly, the Attorney-General, again when in Opposition, without the responsibilities of office and with the opportunity to appease any specialist interest group which approached him-and many did at the time over the Freedom of Information Act-is on record as saying that he did think the time limit for responding to requests should be 10 days. There is a big difference between 10 days and 45 days. The Attorney-General is not even moved to honour some part of his previous argument by allowing the 30-day time limit for responding to applications to be implemented, as the existing legislation provides.

There are numerous examples that have been touched on by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) on how the freedom of information legislation has allowed disadvantaged individuals to rectify their relationship with the Government and to improve their standing with the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the land owners up around Orange.

—The honourable member for Gwydir has said that a classic example of the need for the Freedom of Information Act is the `no base' debate which raged until very recently. It was only through a freedom of information application that the covering up, the inconsistencies, the bungling and the incompetence of the Department of Defence under the administration of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) were revealed. Moreover, the treachery of many of the actions of a number of parties in that divisive and often bitter debate was shown.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many examples of this, and in drawing my speech to a conclusion I wish to touch on just one of fundamental importance. All of us are worried and, if I may use a colloquialism, worried sick, about the status and standing of the New South Wales judiciary. It may well fall within the State Government's jurisdiction-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. During the earlier debate I tried to raise matters that related to Queensland and this Bill and we now have a speaker on the Opposition side raising questions about New South Wales. I suggest that, if I was out of order in raising those matter, this speaker must also be out of order.
—Order! The point of order is upheld. I ask the honourable member to come back to the confines of the Bill.

—I, with my colleagues, am rather surprised at that ruling, and so would anybody who was listening 45 minutes ago, given that at no stage did you rule that the honourable member for Capricornia was irrelevant in his address.
—That is incorrect. I did make a ruling. I asked him on a number of occasions to come back within the confines of the Bill. I am asking the honourable member to do the same.

—Recently this House considered legislation which would prevent any disclosures of any information, under threat of gaol or fines, from the judicial commission established by this chamber, in regard to the allegations made against High Court Justice Lionel Murphy. It worries me-
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I pursue my original point that the honourable member is continuing with his argument and is debating your ruling.
—I do not believe that that is a point of order which should be upheld.

—The point I wish to make is that this Government has a penchant for secrecy. If the Attorney-General is concerned, as we all are, on a totally bipartisan basis that the standing of our judiciary, whether Federal or State, be unimpaired in any way, for heaven's sake, he must allow the charges that have been made against that individual to be put to rest once and for all. Instead, sadly, we are brought to the conclusion that the Government seeks to protect someone else, perhaps even someone from the right wing of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party, who is implicated in the evidence already put before the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the remarks the honourable member has just made and ask how they are relevant to the Bill before the House.
—I ask the honourable member, in continuing his address to the House, to stay within the confines of the legislation.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I make a plea for you to listen to the excellent contribution being made by the honourable member for Gippsland. He is talking to the long title of the Bill. Because this Bill is listed under its correct title name, my colleague is using the long title of the Bill to pursue very pertinently, very precisely and very importantly those points which need exposition. I draw your attention to a ruling that must be made in line with my colleague interpreting, for the purposes of his speech, the long title of the Bill. If you check with the Clerk, Mr Deputy Speaker, I think you will find that the proposition I am making is immaculate in its logic.

—The honourable member for Groom raises some very interesting points. It is a pity he was not in the House earlier to hear many of the points of order raised against speakers in this debate which required both Madam Speaker and myself to draw the attention of honourable members to the need to stay within the confines of the Bill. I ask the honourable member for Gippsland to do so.

—During my remarks I listed three measures within the present legislation which will close off very significantly the ability of individuals, whether in the Opposition or outside this place, to scrutinise government actions. The first is the introduction of a charge of $20 per hour for the bureaucracy to decide, to consult, to reach a conclusion on whether to respond to the application. Secondly, there will be a strengthening of the provisions for refusal of requests on work load grounds, even though no test of what amounts to unreasonable work load grounds is set down. Thirdly, there will be a maintenance of the present 45-day limit on answering a request. They are the three measures in this legislation which close off the ability of an individual rightly to pursue government actions affecting him or her.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same vein, the legislation that recently passed through this place, closing off any opportunity for a judicial commission to make known its evidence to date, is a reflection of this Government's refusal to open itself up to scrutiny. We just have to wonder why the Attorney-General will not allow a free and open hearing, not just in relation to the Murphy affair but also in relation to the overall operations of government. For that reason I think this Government stands condemned. I think there is a growing and widespread cynicism about the motives of this Government in relation to the Murphy affair and its operations generally. Until the Attorney-General takes definite and positive steps to allow his Government to be scrutinised in the best traditions of a democracy, the grave fears most of us have about a number of aspects of the judiciary will remain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I want to make the point that this is a Budget measure announced on the night of the Budget which endeavours to save the taxpayer substantial sums of money. If people want information it will not be denied, but some reasonable contribution has to be made when that information is going to be provided at a substantial cost to the taxpayer. That is the point that I think has been missed in this debate. People have been wandering into other areas, asking whether this Government has something to hide. Not at all. The issue is one of cost to the taxpayer. Apart from that, I am disappointed that the major contribution made by the Opposition was to belittle members of the Public Service. It talked about how incompetent and wasteful they were and how they were not able to cope with their job. The allegation was made that they spent most of their time at morning and afternoon tea or shuffling paper.
—Who said that?
—I wish I could say that it was the honourable member for Gippsland.
—It wasn't.
—It was said by previous speakers from the Opposition.
—In quite different terms.
—It was not in quite different terms. The honourable member should not try to get away from it.
—You are making excuses.

—I am not making excuses; I am replying to what was said. Mention was made of incompetence, delay and excessive cost on the part of the Public Service. It was said that members of the Public Service spent their time at morning and afternoon tea and shuffling paper.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that honourable members opposite are listening to this, because I want to give them a few facts as to what the issue is about. The legislation is a budgetary measure. There is no question of there being a cover-up. It is a question of the cost of supplying information. Honourable members will notice that in the second reading speech clear evidence was given as to cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is going down.

—It is going down. It has gone down to between $14m and $16m. That is how far it has gone down. Honourable members will notice that the contributions have gone up to $60,000. That is an enormous gap that must be picked up by the taxpayer. We are not trying to hide anything. What is causing this cost gap? Honourable members opposite say that it is caused by incompetence and delay on the part of the Public Service. I do not accept that, because the nature of the requests must be looked at. Firstly, if there is some suggestion-this suggestion was made-that there will be some extraordinary cost, of course, that can be investigated by the Ombudsman. If there is a suggestion that the costs are excessive, it can be the subject of a complaint to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Nobody mentioned that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, it should also be made clear that, if one is seeking personal information, no charge will be made. No mention was made of that fact. The existing provisions provide that account must be taken of a request where it relates to a person's personal affairs, whether the payments would cause hardship and whether disclosure of the documents is in the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are taking that out-the public interest one.

—We are not taking it out. The provision in relation to charges remains. But let us come to the point: Why are we expending so many millions of dollars? I will give honourable members some examples. An academic lawyer wanted to find out, as a matter of interest, all the information related to what was called the Westinghouse case. It is nice to want to acquire that information, but the cost of providing all the information on the Westinghouse case was $203,000. That information was provided to the gentleman because he was interested in writing a thesis on the issue. That is one case.

SPEECH.PARA: In another case, a person wanted to know whether there were any papers related to people's criminal records-particularly in relation to himself, I guess. It cost $18,000 to compile all the information because there is what is called a scattergun request. One would not mind if the request were specific and accurate. One can talk about such a matter. But one must look at the facts: An amount of $16m, of taxpayers' money is being burnt up in this issue. This legislation is a budgetary measure-there is no other reason for it-to try to recoup a mere portion of that amount. We will be fortunate if we recoup $2m or $3m having regard to all of the exceptions relating to hardship and other matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are estimating $4m.

—We hope that that figure can be realised. The honourable member knows that such estimates depend on what sort of charges will be applied. I bring the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) to the point which he failed to address-that is, it is a budgetary measure. All that he has done is to belittle the Public Service and suggest that the Government is trying to cover up something. The issue is that the money that is being paid out is taxpayers' money. We are trying to recoup it, and that is why these charges are being applied.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Opposition know that, as members of the Parliament, they can place questions on the Notice Paper. They know also that a lot of information is disclosed in the normal course of information that is supplied by departments. So, it is a bit unfair for people to say that they want all of this information. If it is personal information, certainly, charge need not be made. But, if they want the information because they have an idea that they might like to make a study of something-that is what happened in the Westinghouse case-why should the taxpayer have to pay $200,000 on the basis that that request ought to be complied with? Why should there not be some recoupment? A person may want to find out everything that is contained in the police files about himself or somebody else. Why should that cost be borne by the taxpayer?

Mr Newman-a former Liberal member of the Parliament-sought to obtain all records of people's trips overseas. I had some information about this matter taken out. About 10,000 different items were involved-every laundry bill, every aspect of any charge that was made in the course of a trip. The cost of complying with one of Mr Newman's requests was $43,839 because it took 170 days to go through the thousands of documents-which, when itemised, amounted to 800 pages-on this very simple matter of cost. He wanted to know every item of cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are throwing the entire thing out, though, aren't you?

—Nobody wants to throw anything out. We are suggesting that Mr Newman should have made a contribution and should not have bludged on the taxpayer to the extent of $43,000 just because he wanted this information. Why did he want it? He could have got it by placing a question on the Notice Paper. It could have been provided in the normal way and the cost would have come out of ministerial expenses. Mr Newman wanted to find out this information and somebody would have had to obtain every document from all of the departments. How is that a matter of public interest? Any member can ask what the cost of the trips was. But it is outrageous for people to want every document examined and every docket produced. If that was not done, the suggestion would then be made that the Government was trying to cover up something. There is no suggestion that anything is being covered up. It is a question of the cost being borne by the taxpayer. The honourable member for North Sydney should not shake his head. It will fall off if he continues to shake it.

SPEECH.PARA: I make this point: This is a budgetary matter. It is as simple as that. I do not want to go into every other very doubtful accusation regarding hypocrisy, stench, decay and all of the putrefying matters that we might expect to hear at times. The issue is that there has been a bitter attack on the Public Service. It has been suggested that public servants are incompetent and are always at morning and afternoon tea. I know that honourable members opposite are regretting it now. The issue is that we are trying to recoup a little more than $60,000 of the total cost of $16m. Nothing is being held back. Honourable members should ask themselves: If one request by Mr Newman cost $43,000, why should he not pay a substantial part of that cost? The issue he raised was of no interest to anybody. He wanted the luxury of making a request. Why should the academic lawyer who wanted to know what happened in the Westinghouse case ask that all documents be given to him, at a cost of $200,000? The documents, virtually, are a matter of public record.

The important thing, firstly, is that we have information that is available to the people and we want to get it to them as quickly as possible. If it concerns a personal matter it can be done at virtually no cost. Secondly, the bleating we heard today, with the greatest respect, had very little to do with cost. It had everything to do with accusations about other matters which we will deal with in another debate. It had nothing to do with the matter that we are debating.

The Government is not trying to cover up anything. It recognises that public servants are doing their job and doing it as best they can. Honourable members ought to look at the nature of the requests. It is important that, if people require a specific piece of information, it ought to be given to them quickly. But, when people ask for all documents relating to a period which spans 18 months or three or four years, that will take a considerable amount of time and will be very expensive. It is about time that we got rid of these wide ranging, scattergun requests. People who make such requests say: `I don't know what the files will contain; but, if I can get hold of the information, it will be helpful to give it to the media'. We suggest that the information will be made available; but, if it is of a wide ranging nature, some contribution towards the cost must be made. It is as simple as that.

Nobody has mentioned that there is a gap of $16m which is being met by the taxpayers. That is what this Bill is about. It concerns the $16m that honourable members opposite are asking their constituents to pay, so that some members have the luxury of obtaining information that they could have obtained anyway. That is the point. That is the real issue. What value was it to Mr Newman, a former member of this place, to say: `I would like to know what the costs were'? We might ask to look at all the information relating to him. What would that prove? One can always find out the information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked for it and you would not give it to me.

—We even gave the honourable member a remission on his $12; that shows how mean he is. The honourable member is getting plenty of money but he could not afford even $12. I want to make it very clear that what we are about, with the greatest of respect to the learned leader in this debate for the Opposition, is a Budget matter; nothing else. The honourable member for North Sydney did not address even one remark to the question of how we might recoup the $16m gap, except to suggest that the public servants were lazy, that they did not understand the position and that they were spending most of their time shuffling papers. That is not true. I know the honourable member wants to recant from saying that and I hope he does.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank my colleagues for some of their contributions. If we go into what is happening to public moneys, particularly Commonwealth moneys, we ought to be able to get the information wherever it is-whether it be in the States or somewhere else. The honourable member for North Sydney talked about a cover-up. The greatest danger we face at the present time is not being able to find out what happens to substantial sums of Commonwealth moneys that are given to people to spend. We would like them to account for it and that is where the cover-up is. It is not in this legislation which deals with some recoupment and some reimbursement. I thank honourable members for their contributions and I hope that the Bill has a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 9-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 10 (Processing of requests, &c.).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 10, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Processing of requests, &c.
`10. Section 19 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from paragraph (1) (a) `is made in writing and '.'.

The amendment seeks to achieve the effect of making sure that the present limitation periods apply, that is, that as from 1 December this year compliance time should be reduced from 45 days to 30 days. A good deal has been said about costs by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). One of the arguments I understood he put in support of maintaining the period of 45 days is that there may be, or will be, a need for extra staff. Let us look at the history of costs under the Freedom of Information Act. In doing so I make it perfectly plain that if the Attorney-General had wished to deal with the kind of abuse to which he referred in relation to the academic who wished to write a thesis it could be dealt with very simply by an amendment to the Act which was designed to cure that kind of abuse. So we can put that matter to one side. The rest of what he had to say in his reply, if I can call it that, to the second reading debate did not in any way deal with the criticism we have made and the matter of compliance.

There has been a lot of talk about the costs involved with the Freedom of Information Act. Many of the cost estimates that were made from the very beginning have been wrong. The Attorney-General estimated in his second reading speech that there will be a saving of about $4m. However, to my surprise, in his reply to the second reading debate he said that he is hoping to get $2m to $3m. Does the Government know what it is doing or does it not know what it is doing? Does it have estimates or does it not have estimates? If this is any indication of the accuracy of some of the Budget projections, it tells us that the Government does not have the least idea of what the Budget outcome will be.

On the basis of past government predictions, all estimates about the Freedom of Information Act have to be understood as being overestimates. For example, in 1984-85 it was estimated that the Act cost $16.5m to administer and in 1985-86 $14m, a decrease of 15 per cent in money terms and around 23 per cent in real terms. Governments have consistently overestimated the cost of freedom of information. The original estimate in 1982 was in the order of $30m per annum. The actual cost for the year was less than half that figure. According to the Attorney-General, costs of processing requests have continued to decrease as agencies gain experience and improve procedures. The Attorney-General has also pointed out that apparently there is a levelling off. In his second reading speech, after referring to decreases in processing costs, he stated:

In 1984-85 the operation and administration of the FOI Act cost the Commonwealth between $16m and $19m, depending on the precise allowance made for overheads, and the preliminary figures for 1985-86 indicate a cost between $14m and $16m.
Of course this figure is down. He continued:

Although there is some indication that the total number of requests is levelling off-preliminary estimates for 1985-86 the 36,000 to 37,000 requests as against 33,000 in 1984-85-it is clear that administration of the Act will continue to involve very substantial Commonwealth expenditure.

The Attorney-General says this provision is a budgetary measure; it is a measure that does a number of things. One of the things it does is to impose charges. It also guts the Freedom of Information Act and that is a proposition that he simply did not address at any time in his reply. He had not a word to say about the changes which will be made to the way in which requests can be dealt with and diverted, the way in which they can be refused.

The Opposition takes the view that there is no reason for not persisting with the original plan. We have had former years of experience under this Act which sought to bring down the processing time, the response time, to 30 days. The Attorney-General's assertion in his second reading speech as to the need for extra staff must be viewed with a very considerable degree of scepticism. Without saying that the Attorney is seeking to mislead the chamber-I do not say that-I do say that we do not accept what has been put by him for the reasons, in summary, that: First, the Attorney-General's statement that costs of processing requests have continued to decrease as agencies gain experience, secondly, the tendency of governments to over-estimate the costs of freedom of information compliance; thirdly, the Attorney-General's indication that the number of requests may be levelling out; and fourthly-this is something the Attorney-General did not refer to-there will be very considerable costs in the increase of freedom of information. As I have pointed out, the average cost, based upon Department of Finance estimates, will be $310 per application. The necessary result of that is that there will be fewer applications and that will mean less time will be spent processing applications-one would think overall-and, consequently, fewer staff would be needed for that purpose. Therefore, we propose that the timetable laid down in the present Act stand so that from 1 December the response time can be brought down to 30 days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pick up some of the points in regard to the reduction in the number of days. The Attorney-General's point is that all the costs involved in the administration of the Freedom of Information Act are costs brought about by applicants. That just is not true. Earlier today, although my time was limited, I gave a number of instances where I had lodged applications and requests for information under the Freedom of Information Act and had been nothing else but mucked around by departments. The costs involved were costs created not by me but by the departments themselves. Let me give honourable members another example and some more details regarding the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. I do not know why we need that body in the first place, as there are various such commissions set up around the States. I might add that it is something we will be doing away with when we return to government because it is a tremendous waste of money. I applied to the Commission for details of the names of consultants and advisers appointed by the Commission under the relevant Act. Specific clauses in the Act talk about who can be appointed as consultants and advisers. The ordinary taxpayer is entitled to know who the Commission is appointing to provide it with advice and consultants.

—Order! The honourable gentleman should realise that he cannot repeat the speech he made on this matter during the second reading stage. The amendment moved to clause 10 is to amend section 19 of the principal Act by omitting some words from the relevant paragraph. The honourable member might direct his remarks to that and to its implications rather than recasting the general question that was canvassed in the second reading debate.

—Mr Chairman, I am attempting to give a case study example of the application of the Freedom of Information Act by an agency responding to an application in a manner which is not consistent with the Act and which gives grounds for my claim that many of the costs involved are created by departments. My example takes away the Minister's claim that this is a cost cutting exercise because, by definition and as a matter of logic, if the costs are created in the departments that is where the problem ought to be rectified, not by removing people's rights to freedom of information.
—Order! I really think that the honourable member is talking to clause 11 rather than to clause 10.
—Which clause are we talking about?
—We are talking about your amendment.
—Our amendment, which is in relation to the number of days?
—Yes.

—That is exactly what I am talking about. If the Chairman will allow me two more sentences, I will bring the matter into relevance. When it comes to the time within which applications ought to be responded to by departments, it is a classic example of their being no excuse whatsoever for information not being provided within a reasonable time upon an application. One of the points that needs to be made about the existing Freedom of Information Act and its provisions is that documents ought to be provided within a reasonable period and not later than 45 days after the request has been made. There is even a clause in the current Act which provides that one can go off to the Deputy Ombudsman in charge of freedom of information matters, who will provide one with a certificate which says that prior to the 45 days the delay has been unreasonable, which certificate will give grounds for an appeal against deemed refusal. The point is that many of these costs are created.

SPEECH.PARA: This case is a classic example of where it is not a matter of time. Ample time was available to officers to provide documentation. I was asked for $188 and when I rang up to ask how long it would take to get a remission, the response was: `We have to go to the Attorney-General's Department to find out the grounds and circumstances in which we will give a remission on an application for a reduction in fees'. That is not good enough. It is no good the Attorney-General saying `We have nothing to hide' when I can give details of a case study where I asked for information which ought to have been readily available because it is relevant to taxpayers' money being spent on advisers and consultants, where I could not get it and where it is obvious that I will have to lodge an appeal at some stage. The whole thing is in a mess. When the Attorney-General, after telling us a couple of weeks ago in his second reading speech that the saving was to be $4m, says today that now he does not really know, that it might be $2m, $3m, $1m or $10m, where do we stand? I ask the Attorney-General to cast his mind back to 1981-82, I think it was, when he was reported as saying that not 45 days, not 30 days but 10 days ought to be enough for most departments to respond to freedom of information applications. If that is true, it is worth putting to him. I am interested in hearing his response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, let me make the point that when we talk about savings we are talking about how we might be able to save in terms of administration costs. That saving would be in the vicinity of $2m to $3m. The revenue cost is $4m, although that is still an estimate. So what I was talking about previously was savings and trying to get down what one would call the overriding cost of administering this scheme which, I reiterate, is somewhere in the vicinity of $14m to $16m. The number of requests has been 37,000. The Opposition is now saying that it sees no reason why the provision of 45 days, the provision likely to obtain unless we make this alteration to the Act, should not be reduced to 30 days. The reason given is that if there is to be that restriction it may increase costs because it might mean having to put more resources into complying with requests within the time limit of 30 days as against the 45-day period which now obtain. That is the reason, the rationale and the explanation given in the second reading speech. That is the advice given to us.

SPEECH.PARA: If one considers the nature of some of the requests given to us and how diverse and difficult they are, one sees that there would be an additional factor if more resources had to be diverted to comply with a 30-day time limit as against a 45-day time limit. It does not follow that everybody will take 45 days. I hope that simple requests can be dealt with readily, in a very short time. The point we come back to is how we can make the departments more efficient and more understanding of people's claims. We are always anxious to do that. Streamlining the Public Service, and how one does it, are part of a continual process. Some departments feel a bit fearful about having to make decisions and delay doing so. Since the Act was first brought in the question of whether more speedy decisions could have been made has been an educative process. That, in fact, has happened. The overriding administrative cost has been reduced from $19m to somewhere between $14m and $16m, despite the fact that the number of requests has risen to 37,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must be one out of the box, because every time I make an application I have nothing but trouble.

—Maybe it is the nature of the honourable member's personality or the nature of his requests. The honourable member made some outrageous charges about members of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission having their fingers in the till when he knew that in many cases they were not getting paid at all. It is a pity that he did not answer some of the correspondence he received from those he maligned, but that is a matter for him.

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with this Budget matter-I get back to that point; it is a Budget matter-it is important that we try to contain costs within the Budget for the reasons mentioned, which relate to deficits and everything else. If the Public Service can improve and lift its game, cost saving will improve out of sight also. But at the same time we are not going to have taxpayers being asked to supplement the cost of extraordinary requests which really do not relate to the applicant's personal affairs or income-related matters. Income-related requests or requests in cases where there is hardship can be complied with very quickly at no cost. That is the real issue, not this wide scattergun approach of perhaps we might find out something which would be very handy to give to the local Press or somebody.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—There is nothing wrong with it as long as it is paid for. That is the point. We do not mind at all, but the full cost should be paid for. Not one honourable member opposite has queried what a dreadful hole in the bucket there is when it is costing $16m and we are collecting $60,000. I can tell the honourable member that honourable members on his own side who passed this legislation when in government are having second thoughts as to the cost factor, but not one honourable member opposite has queried the cost factor. It was and is enormous. Nobody expected to be able to divert so many millions of dollars unrecouped. We do not mind putting the resources there if the cost of providing them is going to be reimbursed. That is the simple issue. I reject this amendment because it just increases the cost factor for the reasons that I have mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 11 (Requests may be refused in certain cases).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech in the second reading debate I spoke about the multi-document request and the change that is proposed to be made to the Freedom of Information Act 1982. This is a very major change which is being sought to be made to the Act and I will now be a little more technical about it. I ask the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to disagree with me specifically if he believes that I am wrong in any way. Section 24 of the Freedom of Information Act is to be amended by clause 11 to permit an agency or Minister to refuse to grant access under what is called a multi-document request. If the agency or Minister is satisfied at any time after receipt of the request that the likely total work in dealing with the request would substantially divert resources from other operations, would interfere substantially with the performance of the Minister's other functions or would result in substantial delays in dealing with other requests, there is this power to refuse the request. I have pointed out that the person who makes the decision is the agency or the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: What is a multi-document request? Its definition is a good example of the kind of drafting that we do not need but which has just become entrenched practice in parliamentary drafting. I say that without intending any discourtesy to the actual drafter, because certain drafting practices have grown up. But one consequence of the drafting practice that presently exists in this Parliament is that laws are almost unintelligible to the ordinary citizens-and laws should be intelligible, particularly a law such as this, which is meant to provide freedom of information to the ordinary citizen. Returning to a multi-document request, it is defined to mean a request:
(i) that is expressed to relate to all documents, or to all documents of a specified class, that contain information of a specified kind or relate to a specified subject matter;
I might add that that is presently the only type of request to which a work load objection can be made. The definition continues:
(ii) that relates to a number of specified documents; or
(iii) that is one of a series of related requests;
Under this amendment, it is further stated:

2 or more requests made to an agency or Minister . . . shall be taken to constitute a series of related requests if they are made by the same person or by persons whom the agency or Minister believes on reasonable grounds to have acted in concert in making the requests.

I know what the Attorney-General is going to do when he gets up; he is going to refer to abuses. I agree that abuses should be met, but one meets abuses by specific amendments to the Act, designed to do just that. What has been done here is to greatly extend the power to reject applications under the Freedom of Information Act. I remind the Committee that the number of factors that can be taken into account in determining the likely work load-that is what the Minister or the Department looks at-involved in dealing with a request will be increased to include, in addition to the number and volume of documents and difficulties of retrieval, the usual location of documents, the likely need for and extent of consultation in dealing with the request, the time and extent of resources reasonably likely to be required to examine the documents concerned for exempt matter and to make decisions in relation to the deletion of such matter, and the likely work necessary to formulate and notify interim or final decisions-all this in the interests of freedom of information.

These provisions would substantially increase the power to refuse a request. That is undeniable and I do not expect the Attorney-General to get up and say anything else. Not only will there be an increase in the number of excuses that can be raised but also the requirement that the diversion of resources or interference with functions must be unreasonable has been deleted, so that the interference or diversion need only be substantial.

I now come to the point that I would like the Attorney-General to specifically address his mind to. Under section 24 of the present Act, when one looks to requests that may be refused and the power of the agency or Minister to refuse to grant access, one sees these words:
. . . a request . . . which . . . would substantially and unreasonably divert the resources of the agency . . . or of the office of the Minister.

`Substantially and unreasonably' are two tests that have to be satisfied. What has happened to the reasonable part of this test? What has happened to the lack of reason? Well, I have in my hand an explanatory memorandum, which states:

Section 24 (1) will provide that a multi-document request may be refused where the agency or Minister is satisfied at any time after receipt that the likely total work load would substantially and unreasonably divert the resources of the agency from its other operations, would interfere substantially and unreasonably with the performance by the Minister of the Minister's functions.

So that the Attorney-General will know what I am referring to, that is contained in the section of the explanatory memorandum relating to clause 15, as it originally came out. I would like the Attorney-General to tell me this: How was it that, when the explanatory memorandum originally came to this Parliament, it has those words in it; that is: `substantially and unreasonably divert the resources'? If the Attorney-General refers to the section of the explanatory memorandum relating to clause 15, which is now before this Committee, he will find that the words `and unreasonably' have disappeared into thin air. Why is that? I may not have noticed it but, as far as I am aware, there has been no attempt by the Attorney-General to tell us what happened. We have an explanatory memorandum mark I and an explanatory memorandum mark II.

Those words which have gone out are not insignificant words; they are important words, because there were two tests that had to be met and now there is to be only one test. Was that what the Government intended? Did it change its mind at the last minute? Was the deletion of these words not a reflection of the drafting instructions? What happened? How is it that those words have now dropped out? True it is that the Bill makes perfectly plain that one only has to be satisfied that it is a substantial diversion of resources, which is a very much easier thing to say, but why is it that those words have gone? Is it sheer incompetence? Is it a change in drafting instructions? It must be one or the other, because those words appeared in the original explanatory memorandum-which I can give the Attorney-General a copy of if he does not have a copy-but they are not to be found in the explanatory memorandum that is now here.

There is one other thing that needs to be said about this very increased power to refuse, and that is this: The Government has now laid down a framework of charges. This framework of charges is going to apply to search and retrieval and to consultation and decision making, so if one has a multi-document request that imposes a very considerable burden, but a burden that the Department or Minister is willing to accept, the charges apply. So it cannot be said, on the Government's own legislation, that the rejection of this provisions would add any cost burden. In the interests of freedom of information I would ask the Government to reconsider the exclusion of this wide power, which is a direct negation of the underlying principle of freedom of information. I ask the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) specifically to direct his mind to the explanatory memorandum and tell me why the change was made. Secondly, I ask him why, as a matter of routine for the purpose of keeping Parliament advised, a specific reference to the change that was made was not put somewhere in the second explanatory memorandum so that parliamentarians would have a better idea of what the Government is about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the funniest contemporary stories that go around about Yes Minister is the story of the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, and his departmental head, who were watching one of the Yes Minister shows. They both laughed at different times.
—I hope that the honourable gentleman is coming to the point and is not merely making an attack on a former Prime Minister.

—I am coming to the point. A public servant friend of mine gave me an edition of Yes Minister. The last chapter relates to a set of circumstances where Sir Humphrey, when he was a junior secretary, made a mistake and wanted to cover his tracks. He finally persuaded his Minister to help him to do so by removing a file. The file finally read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: This file contains the complete set of available papers except for:
(a) a small number of secret documents;
(b) a few documents which are part of still active files;
(c) some correspondence lost in the floods of 1967;
(d) some records which went astray in the move to London-
that could be Perth, Melbourne or Timbuktu, because that is what the amendments to section 24 will allow-
(e) other records which went astray when the War Office was incorporated into the Ministry of Defence.
That is another possibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the ones that went astray in your time from the Solicitor-General's Office in Perth. Tell us about that.
—I was elected to this place only in December 1984; so the honourable gentleman cannot place the sins of the past, if they were sins, on me. I return to the quotation, which continues:

SPEECH.PARA: (f) the normal withdrawal of papers whose publication could give grounds for an action for libel or breach of confidence, or cause embarrassment to friendly governments.

Perhaps a further paragraph could be added for Australian circumstances: `(g) other documents no longer available due to the Freedom of Information Act brought in by the Hawke socialist Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shades of Hodgman.
—I sit right behind him, which is sometimes an advantage and sometimes a disadvantage. There are some amazing things in the amendments to section 24. For example, proposed new sub-section (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where-
(a) a multi-document request is made; and
(b) the agency or Minister is satisfied at any time after the receipt of the request-

What does that mean? Does it mean that a decision could be made about the extent of the work load involved before a request was made? That is an amazing proposition. I like the provision relating to multi-document requests and an attempt being made to get around the provision by a whole lot of people making single requests. This wonderful new clause will be a delight for those who believe in conspiracy theories. We have the following provision:

2 or more requests made to an agency or Minister . . . shall be taken to constitute a series of related requests if they are made by the same person or by persons whom the agency or Minister believes on reasonable grounds to have acted in concert in making the requests.

So if my brother and I and a cousin made an application on a similar matter, each one for a single document, the action could be defined as acting in concert, acting in the furtherance of some devious conspiracy, which would enable the Minister to refuse the application. Similarly, and more likely, if 10 Opposition members all decided to lodge requests, we can be sure that the conspiracy theory would operate and we would not be supplied with documents under this provision.

The Bill would do justice to Sir Humphrey Appleby of Yes Minister fame. When I am asked whether Parliament and the Federal Government are like Yes Minister, I usually say that they are not because Yes Minister is not always a wonderful reflection on members of parliament. In this case, however, I think that the Attorney-General should get the prize for the closest thing to Yes Minister we have had for some time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) for praising me. I think he was directing his remarks to my appearance, if nothing else. The honourable gentleman has not had the benefit of being in government and I have no doubt that he has already dissociated himself from the mistakes of his own Party when it was in government. We live or die in this Parliament on how good we are on our feet; we would not want to rely on what might be called the infrastructure. We have to work things out from the point of view of how we shall behave. That is the whole process of government. However, the honourable gentleman will continue to raise these matters, as he is entitled so to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The real issue, which was put to me with some clarity by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), is the deletion of the question of unreasonableness from section 24. The honourable member for North Sydney asked me why `and unreasonably' is not in the explanatory memorandum of which I have a copy when it is in the one he has. I can only say that he has something that is not related to the Bill. I have no doubt that what the honourable gentleman has said is right, but it is not in the explanatory memorandum that was issued by me, and it is certainly not what is in the Bill. The Bill takes out the issue of unreasonableness.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the first explanatory memorandum that I received.
—I do not know where the honourable gentleman got it from.
—I can tell the Attorney-General that it came from the Government Printer.
—Perhaps the Government Printer was looking at the original Act, which has in it `substantially and unreasonably'.
—Come on. That is no answer.
—It is an answer from my point of view. I am responsible only for what is issued here.
—It says `circulated by'--

—I have no doubt that the document comes from the Government Printer, but, from my point of view, in the Bill that has been introduced into the House the word `unreasonably' has been deleted. That is very clear. Clause 11 deletes the original words in section 24 (1). The explanatory memorandum which is in the possession of the honourable gentleman is incorrect because it relates to the words that are currently in the section.
—It was issued with the authority of the Attorney-General.
—Not at all. The explanatory memorandum that was issued with my authority is the one that is in my hand. Is the honourable gentleman suggesting that we issued two different documents?
—Yes, I am.

—I do not know how it happened. If it is in the explanatory memorandum in the honourable gentleman's possession it has no relationship to the Bill, which is amending section 24 by deleting the words `and unreasonably'. It would be a false explanatory memorandum if it suggested otherwise. The Bill is directed to this very issue, which is the subject of the honourable gentleman's complaint.
—Yes.

—I accept that from the point of view of the honourable gentleman's argument but not from the point of view of his amendment. We are talking about the diversion of resources which would interfere substantially with the performance of the agency. We have deleted `and unreasonably' because we regard those words as amounting to some sort of objective test.
—Surely `substantially' is also subjective.

—No, it is a matter of a Minister coming to the view that it is a substantial diversion of resources. Having brought in that issue, we see no point in arguing whether the diversion of resources is reasonable or not. The issue is whether it is substantial and that is the issue that comes into the question of whether the agency is able to provide the resources. I have already given the example of 170 working days being expended to deal with one request. Surely the honourable gentleman would regard that as being a substantial diversion of resources. The implication is that that is not reasonable on the basis of what remains available for dealing with other requests, which is another aspect of the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Requests are not dealt with one at a time. Indeed, many requests are dealt with at the same time. If there is an expectation that all requests will be dealt with expeditiously and if all the agency's resources are diverted to deal with what is described as a multi-document request-as I have said, one such request took 170 days to meet-what will happen to all the others in the queue that are awaiting to be dealt with by the agency?

It is for that reason that this amendment has been introduced-to discard the question of unreasonableness as we do not think it is relevant. The issue is whether there is a substantial diversion of resources. The honourable gentleman goes on to criticise the draftsman, in a way, by asking what is meant by a `multi-document'. It means, of course, more than one. The issue though is the question of a substantial diversion. That is the test. It is not so much the multi-document aspect; the substantial diversion is the test. It is important to recognise that requests can be made which would require a substantial diversion. We have already explained that in the memorandum and in the second reading speech.

Let me come to the point. Why in the name of fortune put so much emphasis on some pro forma, some explanatory memorandum, when it is not in the Bill? The point in the Bill that the Opposition is entitled to argue about is that we propose to delete the words `and unreasonably'. We hope to delete that because we do not regard that as being an appropriate test. The question is whether there had to be a diversion of resources for the reasons I have mentioned. So I do not think we ought to waste a lot of time arguing about how the honourable gentleman got something which is obviously incorrect. It was not issued with my authority. The document issued with my authority is the one that is here in the chamber-it was tabled at the time of the second reading speech. That is the appropriate document. I am not responsible for every draft that might float around the place on the basis that it is related to what the Government had in mind. The Government had in mind what is clearly in the Bill. That is what I am suggesting the honourable gentleman should address his mind to.

For that reason, in the spirit of the argument, we do not accept that we could have this clause deleted because it would take us back to where we were before, having to comply with two tests, substantially and unreasonably. We are not going to face up to that issue. We are talking from the point of view of a Minister having the capacity or his Department having the capacity to advise the Minister, that there would be a substantial diversion of resources. That is the test.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) gave the game away some time ago when he interjected on the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and said that maybe it was the nature of his request that caused him so much trouble. SPEECH.PARA: What does he think the other test is? That is subjective too. Who makes it? The Minister makes it. How does he make it? He makes an assessment. What does he do when he makes a judgment on the other arm as it presently stands as to whether the diversion of resources will be unreasonable? He makes an assessment-a judgment. In both cases there is a subjective assessment. It is nonsense for him to say here today: `The reason we want to get rid of this is because it is subjective. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for that copy. I acknowledge that there must have been two explanatory memoranda printed, but only one was presented here.
—Where do you think we got that?

—I make the point: Only one was presented here and it has a different catalogue number, as he notes. I have just been handed a note saying that there was an error made in printing that one. The error would not be because there had been some change, it would be because somebody had used perhaps some earlier explanatory memorandum relating to the existing clause.
—Some earlier draft of the Bill.

—No. The point is that the Bill and the memorandum are accurate. The honourable gentleman wants me to give an explanation of how somebody in the Government Printing Office produced an earlier memorandum-

—Apparently, and that is the problem. He said it came to his office in North Sydney.
