—I would like the Attorney- General to--
—Order! He shall not contest the suggestion from the Chair. The Attorney-General might also assist by not responding to the interjections.

—I apologise. I just want to make the point that the issue is how the honourable gentleman and his office got an incorrect explanatory memorandum well before this matter was introduced. He might like to take this up with the Government Printer.

—Mr Chairman, I want an opportunity to make a personal explanation because the Attorney-General has quite misunderstood or misheard what I said. SPEECH.PARA: Is the honourable member going to suggest that every time he debates this matter he will be looking at the explanatory memorandum which is incorrect, instead of addressing his mind to the Bill? For that reason, it is clear that in the Bill-the honourable gentleman has gone off on this other line, and I do not want to say any more about that-we do not want to face further arguments about whether, while the work involved may be substantial, it is reasonable. That is another argument. Certainly, many of these matters are taken on appeal, and that is the issue that we are facing. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 13, page 5, lines 29-33, omit paragraph (b), substitute the following paragraph:
``(b) by inserting in paragraph (3) (b) `or a person on whose behalf the application was made' after `applicant' (second occurring).''.
(4) Clause 14, page 6, after line 6, insert the following word and sub-paragraph:
``or (iii) the giving of access is in the general public interest or in the interest of a substantial section of the public.''.

The purpose of the amendments moved to clauses 13 and 14 of the Government's Bill is to give a power to remit charges and application fees on the basis of general public interest or the interest of a substantial section of the public. If I heard the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) correctly, some time ago he referred to the public interest criterion in a context which suggested that he thought that power would remain to remit charges and application fees on the basis of the public interest criterion.

I have said before that the purpose of this Bill is to gut the Freedom of Information Act. I have heard no real argument addressed to my detailed criticisms about the way in which the Act will operate. I have heard the Attorney-General say that it is a Budget Bill, as though that is an answer to all objections to the Bill. I ask the honourable gentleman to reconsider and to ask himself a very simple question: If the Government has any commitment to the maintenance of any kind of freedom of information legislation, should there not be a power to remit charges and application fees on the basis of the public interest? That is what the amendments seek to do and that is what I would ask the honourable gentleman to reconsider.

It would be astonishing if, in a Bill or an Act such as this legislation, where there is a power to remit such charges, and where a high public interest is served by the making of the application and what is discovered, there were no power to say: `You, a citizen of this country, have gone to great trouble and great expense. As a result of what you have done, we have discovered things which we did not know'. For example, a Minister could, as a consequence of the application made by a citizen, learn something of vital national interest-something which has been kept from him. Is it not fair and right that, in those circumstances, he or the department should be able to say: `It is true that if we were to charge you on the basis of the existing charge structure, it would cost you $10,000, but it is also true that what you have done is of very great public interest. Therefore, we believe that it is fair, in the public interest, that charges and fees should be remitted.'? I ask the honourable gentleman to reconsider the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for North Sydney asks why we are deleting the question of whether giving access is in the public interest. The reason is that we are basically dealing with remission. This section is about whether the charges should be remitted, and that question is usually related to the person wanting that remission. It does not really involve a public interest. Whilst it is mandatory in the present section, it is thought that that is far too strict a test. At the same time, whilst we are deleting it as a mandatory test-very seldom would a test application for remission be deemed to be in the public interest; dealt with more on the basis of hardship and other matters-I make the point to the honourable gentleman that it will still be contained in section 30 (3), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Without limiting the matters which the agency or Minister may take into account . . . the agency or Minister shall take into account . . .

In other words, while it will not be mandatory, it does not follow that there would not be some discretion at times to look at those matters. The mandatory aspect has been removed, but if there was a public interest factor, it could well be taken into account.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen)-by leave-read a third time.

Ordered that the message be taken into consideration in Committee of the whole House forthwith.
Senate's further amendment-
Page 3, clause 8, lines 15 to 27, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:

``8. (1) A person who is, or has at any time been, a member of the Commission, a member of the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission shall not, directly or indirectly, disclose to any other person or make use of any document or information to which the first-mentioned person has had access by reason of being or having been such a member or counsel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives does not insist on its amendment made in place of the amendment of the Senate to clause 8 of the Bill and agrees to the further amendment made by the Senate to that clause.

Whilst we agree with that, it is not what the Government wanted to have in the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill. Nevertheless, we have faced the issue that the Commission of Inquiry has already advised that it is unable to take evidence and that there needs to be some winding up of the Commission.

The intention behind the clause was to prevent the publication of documents prepared within the Commission, which could well be allegations, which obviously would be damaging to Mr Justice Murphy and his family, because the documents had never been the subject of any examination, nor could they be, for reasons that relate to Mr Justice Murphy's terminal illness.

At the same time, the Government is critical of the drafting of the Senate's amendment, which suggests that the only people who are responsible are the members of the Commission or their staff. There could well be others. However, the Senate fails to agree with the Government on that issue, so we will not be successful because the Senate has the overriding capacity to reject the Bill. The Bill went back to the Senate and was rejected for the second time.

I do not want to delay the Committee any further because the matter has been canvassed extensively. I think that it is without precedent in a party commission that, if there is publication of documents that should not be published, the only people who can be impugned or dealt with are the commissioners or members of their staff. That is a fatal flaw in the Bill. The Bill does not deal with the other people who might well circulate or publish such material. The Commission was set up in camera on the basis that allegations could be made which have no substantiation whatsoever. Such allegations will never be subjected to testing in this case.

Earlier, it was asked whether there was any cover-up. There is no cover-up in this matter. It is a question of documents which have been prepared within the Commission. All documents that might have been given to the Commission can be returned under section 18 (2) of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act. Any information that might relate to criminal activity can be given to the appropriate law enforcement authority under section 34. The issue was that the Commission was in the process of preparing documents which might, perhaps, have been the subject of a hearing in camera and also the calling of witnesses, none of which was able to take place because of the unfortunate illness. The Commission made the point that it would be contrary to natural justice to continue when Mr Justice Murphy was unable to be present, and certainly unable to give instructions.

That information is now a matter of record. The Commission has furnished a report to the Presiding Officers. I again make the point that the Commission is a parliamentary commission that reports to Parliament. We are dealing with the machinery aspects of being able to say that the Commission will be wound up. Everyone in the Senate accepts that position of the winding up in the terms of the Bill before the Committee, except in respect of clause 8, which has been the subject of contention as to penalties. It was suggested that the penalty of $100,000 was outrageous. It related to a corporation. We are well aware that media interests will be very anxious to publish allegations. I have no doubt that they will be published, probably after Mr Justice Murphy's death so there will be no question of defamation. The issue in this case is: What will it do to his family to have allegations, of which there has been no substantiation and, indeed, on which no evidence has been called, nor could it be called? I think that the Senate's view is very unfair but, as we must get the Bill finalised, we have no alternative but to agree to the further amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great irony that, immediately after debate on the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill, a Bill that will greatly restrict the accessibility of information from Ministers and departments, we should have before us a Bill that is unprecedented in the nature of the restrictions it imposes on information being made available at any time and for any use. It was only very late in the day that the so-called oversight was discovered and the Bill was amended so that material relating to Mr Justice Murphy might be seen after 30 years, if there is agreement by the Presiding Officers to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: A few points must be made quite clear. Everyone in the Senate did not accept the Bill as it presently stands. Our view has been perfectly plain. We deeply sympathise with Mr Justice Murphy and his family. However, we have taken the view and have maintained the view that, as long as the judge is determined to sit, the Commission should continue in existence. We have made it perfectly plain that it should not have hearings if he is unable to attend and give instructions. There was never any dispute about that.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) referred to the considerations of natural justice. We entirely agree that considerations of natural justice need to be observed, but the Commission said that it might arise that, in effect, Mr Justice Murphy would be unable to appear before it-not, as I understand it, that that was precisely and indefinitely the position. We have no quarrel about the way in which the Commission should operate. If it is to operate, it should always operate in accordance with notions of natural justice. It would be quite wrong if it were to do anything else. Given the high calibre of the men who head the Commission, I have no doubt that it would have done an outstanding job had it been able to pursue its task to the end. I am very sorry that it will not be able to pursue its tasks to the end. That that is so is simply because of one's sympathy for Mr Justice Murphy and his family.
The Attorney-General said that the effect of the clause that was drafted by the Government was the right way of protecting Mr Justice Murphy against allegations. The clause reads:

A person shall not publish, or otherwise disclose to any other person, the whole or any part of a class A document that has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission.

Among other things, the fatal defect in the way in which the clause was drafted was that material that may have been given by the Commission to the National Crime Authority could not be used by the Authority. That is an extraordinary example of legislative incompetence in drafting. We go further and say that the amendment we proposed is the right one. It was deliberately restricted. The way in which the Government's clause is phrased would have caught the commissioners, their staff and counsel assisting. We deliberately directed our amendment to a narrow compass. We do not for a moment believe that the commissioners would do other than act with the highest honour and integrity, because that is the kind of people they are. We have faith in the staff of the Commission. There is a good precedent, to which I referred on the previous occasion when we debated this issue, for that kind of a clause. That is the reason it was drafted in the way in which it was.

The Attorney-General referred to allegations against Mr Justice Murphy. I have no desire to see unfounded allegations against Mr Justice Murphy surface in the media, either before or after his death. However, we need to understand that this attempt by the Government to entomb material is quite without precedent but the making of allegations about people regarding their conduct is certainly not without precedent. Every day of the week in the courts of this country allegations of a most serious nature are made. Those allegations frequently never come to trial. I speak of civil cases where allegations of the most serious fraud, of the most grievous misconduct, may be made in open court at an early stage of a case and because the case is settled those allegations always remain around. I say that simply to dispel this myth that we are somehow dealing with an extraordinary situation. It is extraordinary in one sense-that it is the only time we as a parliament have ever had to look at the question of investigating a judge pursuant to section 72 of the Constitution. But the general making of allegations in legal proceedings, allegations that may never be proved, allegations that may be totally groundless, allegations that may in fact unfairly damage people, is not novel. I do not say it is something to be promoted outside the courts, but I point out that it does exist.

There is another question that needs to be addressed and that is the way in which the Government has handled this whole winding up. My time is limited but I would like to make this point: The Government has failed not only to inform us fully of what has taken place, it has failed also to ensure that the material that came to the Commission would be properly examined. I will now read to the House what I believe is the fullest statement of the way in which the winding up has taken place. This statement was made to me in answer to communications I have had with the Commission because I was not satisfied with what I had heard from the Government's side. I make no charge of a personal nature against the Attorney-General. I simply say that I was not satisfied with what I had heard. I will now read to honourable members what is the fullest account of the winding up of the Commission. The Commission refers to my communication to it, and in a letter dated 10 September goes on to say:
With respect to the matters set out under the heading `As to section 34' the position is as follows.
Material in the possession of the Commission was not `analysed' for the purpose of possible communication to other persons and agencies specified in section 34 of the Commission's statute.

I interpolate by saying that section 34 is the provision which allows the Commission to communicate material relating to criminal activities or suspected criminal activities to law enforcement agencies and other bodies in the law enforcement field. The Commission then went on to say:

The Commission is not called upon by its statute to do such analysis. However, the question generally was addressed by Counsel Assisting the Commission and the Instructing Solicitor though naturally not in the same depth as would have been the case had the Commission gone to finality.
I stress those words. The letter goes on:

On an overview of the material available, much of which came from the National Crime Authority, the Director of Public Prosecutions or the Australian Federal Police, analysis was not warranted, in the opinion of Senior Counsel. A good deal of the material is inchoate and, in that form, unsuitable for reference pursuant to section 34. Generally, to be suitable for that purpose such material would need to be enhanced by further investigation and/or cross-examination of witnesses.
I repeat that:
Generally to be suitable for that purpose such material would need to be enhanced by further investigation and/or cross-examination of witnesses.
However, when it became apparent that the Commission was to be wound up by the Parliament, it consulted the National Crime Authority over materials in its possession that the Authority might require.
I interpolate here that the National Crime Authority is an authority of limited powers which can examine only specified classes of criminal offences. The letter goes on:
Those requested by the Authority were provided to it.
The letter proceeds:
I confirm what you have set out in your communication under the heading `Receipt and Disbursement of Information' except that the material proposed to be sent to the Parliament under the repeal Bill-
that is, in its present form-
will not include:
files received from departments and authorities;
material provided to the Commission in confidence on the basis that it would be returned;
Senate Committee material;
Counsel's personal working notes which, I understand, have been destroyed; and
administrative files.
However, relevant information from the material described immediately above is contained in the Commission's records, which, it is proposed, will be sent to the Parliament.
I add that it is material which, once it gets to the Parliament, neither we nor law enforcement agencies will see, as we are dealing with material that falls within the class A description.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very clear that the Government has never given any instructions to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. I make the point that we have had no contact at all with the Commission. The Commission itself had to make this decision because of the evidence before it and it made the point that no evidence has been heard and therefore nothing decided. It said it would be contrary to the principles of natural justice for it to continue. Any documents given by anybody else would have been returned to them. Any evidence, in terms of witnesses, that is available is still around. The question is of course, that due to a most unfortunate set of circumstances-the dreadful illness of His Honour-the matter will be finalised. One can only hope that there will be a period of recuperation and better health, although the prognosis is very dismal indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the honourable gentleman for his recent remarks but I think it is regrettable that so much emphasis has been placed on the assumption that there has been some attempt to cover something up here. I do not think that is the case. I appreciate that I have run out of time and I will leave the matter at that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Dr Klugman

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to participate in the debate on the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry legislation but I understand that grievances have to be noted at 12.45 p.m. so we may have to bring the matter on again later. I am perfectly happy to speak now as I will take only about a minute and a half.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen)-by leave-agreed to:
That Grievances be postponed to no later than 12.55 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise what I think ought to be considered one of the most important points facing parliamentarians and people who believe in the democratic institutions of this country generally. I support the original legislation, but can see why, for practical reasons-the most important one, of course, being the composition of the Senate-it will not help matters. We can all imagine a National Times edition published after the death of Mr Justice Murphy, when one could say anything about the deceased, without the protection afforded by libel laws applying. I want just for half a minute to address myself to the general proposition: that scandal sheets such as the National Times want a National Times commission not a national crimes commission. What they want to do is run all the rumours themselves, and that for various reasons. But there is one important reason, as far as some of the important members of the National Times are concerned. We have David Combe's word, given before the royal commission which investigated him, that Brian Toohey and Marian Wilkinson, who are very prominent on the National Times-at one stage Brian Toohey was its editor-would never do anything to harm the Soviet Union and that they are extremely friendly to it. The same does not apply to their attitude to the democracies in general. But this feeling is, of course, reciprocal. As far as the Soviet Union is concerned, it has repeatedly subsidised the National Times by buying two and four-page advertisements, meaningless advertisements, for $10,000 to $12,000 at a time. If we look at issues of the National Times as it was going down the gurgler last year, they were doing that repeatedly. I think that they were after New South Wales Labor people, who support and defend democracy in New South Wales. I think that it is reasonable to say that they were--
—The honourable member is testing me on the matter of the relevance of his remarks. I hope that he will come back to the motion before the Committee.

—I have nearly finished, Mr Chairman. I think, unfortunately for themselves, and especially unfortunately for Mr Justice Murphy, they nearly destroyed Mr Justice Murphy instead. We have all seen similar sorts of things happening in other areas, again led by the Fairfax people in New South Wales. We have seen the recent misuse of a grant from the Institute of Criminology to Professor Vinson to investigate armed robbery. This was used to pay for `research' for the Fairfax Press to try to frame a district court judge. Anybody, even mildly numerate, would realise that the published `research' proves nothing and only makes one wonder about the academic standards at one of our universities. One of his fellow academics at the University of New South Wales, Mr David Brown of the so-called Left, and Mr Ken Gee, QC, of the so-called Right-the latter in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald-and many others, have exposed some of these fallacies. To conclude: Let us be careful as parliamentarians, and others who have some influence, when we try to please journalists. Some of them, for various reasons, will try to destroy not only individuals but also institutions which are necessary for us to continue as a democracy and thus continue to have a free Press. It is very easy to get applause from journalists if we give them muck to write about other people. But let us remember that basically the most important thing that we have to try to protect is the form of democracy which I think we enjoy in this country, whatever quibbles we may have about minor points, and that we must enable that democracy to continue.

—Order! It being just past 12.45 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a I shall report progress. I have no doubt that at a later hour the House will again resolve itself into Committee to consider the remainder of the Bill.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Constitutional Commission-Trade Unions-Pharmaceutical Benefits-International Year of Peace-Pacific Highway-Pensioners-Local Government

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that an important debate has been interrupted at this stage, but I am also glad that grievances are to be noted. My grievance concerns the Constitutional Commission, the body established by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) late last year in the silly season, which began public hearings in Canberra yesterday as part of its agenda of rewriting Australia's Constitution. In particular my complaint is that we know already, as we did at the beginning, what recommendations, in broad terms, the Commission, is going to make. We know that it will recommend increased powers for the Commonwealth, reduced powers for the Senate and the States and certainly reduced powers for the Governor-General. We also know what the Commission is not going to recommend. As I have already stated, we know that it is not going to recommend reduced Commonwealth powers, but we also know that it will not recommend, and probably will not even consider, imposing a constitutional limit on Commonwealth spending, a constitutional limit on the size of the public sector or a constitutional requirement that all Commonwealth expenditure be financed from taxation and not borrowings. In other words, the balanced Budget principle, which is so widely debated in our constitutional model, that of the United States, will not even get a look-in here.

SPEECH.PARA: How do we know all this? There are three obvious sources for this information. The first is the set of constitutional principles set out in the book which is the father of the Constitutional Commission, `Australia's Constitution. Time for Change?' by John McMillan, Haddon Storey and the former Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans-who thought it was a good idea at the time. This book is based on the assumption that the Australian people are dumb. They must be, according to these writers, because they have repeatedly shown that they do not want to change the Constitution and certainly do not want to make big government even bigger. Therefore, they say, special techniques must be used to get them used to the idea of `reform', which is how they label their fuddy-duddy ideas. For example, the writers make it plain on page 375 of the book that the best thing that could happen to Australia would be to remove all restrictions on Commonwealth power by abolishing the States, the Senate, the Monarchy and the Governor-General. The trouble is that the stupid Australians do not want to hand total power to Canberra governments and its bureaucrats so, they say, it has become necessary to create `a popular momentum for change' by establishing a forum for constitutional debate on a `cross-party, cross-State basis' under such apparently neutral slogans as `efficiency', `development' and `rationality'. This is the situation that we have with the Constitutional Commission. But the book also tells us, as I have indicated, the direction in which this popular momentum is to move.

The second source of information about the recommendations that the Commission will make is the selection of its members. There are several eminent and impartial persons among the 39 members of the Commission and its committees. Sir Zelman Cowen is an obvious example and there are others. But the predominant voice is that of people, all well known and all very capable in their different ways, whose public track record tells us in advance what their views are-the varying mixtures of centralism, socialism, republicanism and so on. There is Gough Whitlam, Don Dunstan, Jack Ferguson, Rex Patterson, Donald Horne, Peter Garrett, David Solomon, Thomas Keneally, Sir John Moore and many others. The same prior knowledge applies to some of the distinguished lawyers, such as Sir Maurice Byers, on the Constitutional Commission. Does anyone really doubt where Sir Maurice already stands on constitutional issues? It is probably true that some members have agreed to serve on the Constitutional Commission in order to try to stop the recommendations being, as it were, less worse, but the trend is clear.

It is also important to note who are not represented on the Constitutional Commission. The small population States are not well represented. The National Party is not represented at all, but of course the Nuclear Disarmament Party is. Certainly those economists and lawyers who want to deregulate the economy-and in particular the labour market-do not have any voice at all, even though they have the initiative in the public debates at the moment. There is no room at the Commission for the New Right. The Constitutional Commission is stacked the other way.

The third source of information about the recommendations to be made is the timetable. The five advisory committees of the Constitutional Commission are to complete their recommendations in just over six months from now. It took the old Constitutional Convention 10 years to get almost nowhere but these fellows are going to crack it in a few months. Just look at what they are going to crack. Some of the committees have put out issues papers outlining the questions that they will explore and answer. The issues paper of the Advisory Committee on Executive Government includes the following questions, and these are only a sample: Should Australia be a monarchy or a republic? If a republic, what kind-parliamentary of executive? If a monarchy, should the Monarch's power be retained or altered? Should the Monarch still be required to be a member of the Church of England? I guess we know the answer to that one. Should the head of state-president or Monarch-be elected by Parliament as happens in Tobago, or by a college as happens in India, or directly by the voters as happens in Ireland, or in some other way?

No end of questions are raised about the Governor-General: Should the office of Governor-General be retained or abolished? If retained, should the Governor-General be nominated by Cabinet, or elected by the Parliament or by the electorate? Should the Governor-General have a fixed term? How should he be removed? Should he retain any reserve powers? If so, what ones? Whom should the Governor-General be able to consult? Should there be a judicial review of the Governor-General's exercise of his reserve powers? Should the Governor-General remain Commander-in-Chief or should the Minister of Defence be Commander-in-Chief?

There are plenty of other questions. Should the Westminster system be preserved or abolished? Should the Prime Minister be elected directly by the people? Should non-parliamentarians be allowed to be Ministers? Should the Senate be allowed to defer Supply and what should be the consequences of such deferral? And so on and on. That is only a sample from the issues papers of one of the five advisory committees. They all have to settle issues like these by April of next year, giving the Constitutional Commission itself a year or so then to reflect on them. It is obvious that with such a tight timetable they will either recommend nothing-which is unlikely, because it would make them a laughing stock-or they will adopt the ready-made, prepackaged, centralist and radical proposals advocated by the likes of Senator Evans and his ideological colleagues, dressed up of course in the jargon of rationality, efficiency and consensus.

Then the Constitutional Commission itself has to make final recommendations to the Government. Again, it will either deliver a few minor recommendations, which will make it and the Government ridiculous, or come along with the radical, centralist proposals that the Government wants and the Attorney-General has said he wants, no doubt knowing that they would be defeated in any referenda. So is it all a $4.5m time-wasting wank? I do not think so, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Government also has a hidden agenda. Even if nothing directly flows from the exercise, the radicals, the reformers or whatever they call themselves will have achieved a good deal. They will have had a two-year road show in which to peddle the idea that Australia has a shonky Constitution that is unworthy of public confidence; that the States, the Senate and above all the Governor-General are obstacles to progress; that more centralisation and bigger government are essential; that the removal of the constitutional checks and balances on government is a measure of progress; and that laying even the basis or the beginnings of a populist republic will be a step forward. Setting up the Constitutional Commission has been a huge attempt to delegitimise the Constitution of Australia. That is the hidden agenda.

Our Constitution has in fact served us well. It has not been able to stop that curse of Australia, big government, but it has placed some limits on Commonwealth power and has been the framework of democracy in this country. Of course it is not perfect and should be reviewed but preferably by people-not necessarily parliamentarians-who have been elected to do that, people who have been given a long term brief. For example, let us have, as Professor Lumb has suggested, an elected, statutory, constitutional convention which has a right to make recommendations every 20 years. But let us have no more commissions of men hand-picked by government for their known prejudices and given a mandate to report in a matter of months with centralist recommendations that have been more or less written in advance. Despite the fact that some good men are serving on it, the Constitutional Commission is one of those ridiculous bodies like the Human Rights Commission and the Commission for the Future which should be abolished, and the sooner the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the grievance debate to defend the millions of Australians who have already made sacrifices for the common good yet are still badgered and imposed upon by our Opposition, and by some academics and business leaders, to give even more. I am speaking of the 60 per cent of the Australian work force who form the nation's unions. When Labor came to government it had a mandate to attack both unemployment and inflation concurrently. The fight-inflation-first policy of our opponents had been a dismal failure and had resulted in only 2 per cent growth over seven years, high unemployment and no real impact being made on inflation. Our whole policy was dependent upon the co-operation of the union movement through the prices and incomes accord. By this agreement the Government committed itself to policies of higher growth and employment while the unions promised to show restraint in wage demands and industrial disputes. The accord itself was no philanthropic gesture by the unions but rather an acknowledgment by all parties of the desperate nature of the economic and industrial chaos which seven years of conservative rule had bequeathed us.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has more than discharged its part of the obligation. We exceeded by more than 100,000 our goal of half a million jobs within three years. Australia's growth over the same period was about 5 per cent per annum. After the experience of the wages explosion of the early 1980s many commentators doubted whether the unions would hold their side of the bargain, arguing that the increased profits which private enterprise had been getting since we came to office would be too tempting a prize. Yet the unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, despite pressures from within and without, have held to the accord. The results have been remarkable-a 5 per cent fall in real wages at a time when some of our major trading partners have been recording increases, a 7 per cent fall in real unit cost, which no other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nation has even come close to and a reduction in the level of industrial disputation to less than half that of the Fraser years.

The Opposition could only dream of achieving such results yet, despite the accord's success, a hard core of Liberal dries and right wing intellectuals and a handful of big business leaders have chosen to step up their attack on trade unions. Their most recent skirmish was the Peko-Wallsend lockout. The worrying aspect of the dispute was not so much the issue of restrictive work practices itself but the men who were behind the lockout, their methods and their objectives. Charles Copeman, Peko's chief executive, adopted a belligerent attitude from the start. He announced that the disputed practices would be dispensed with overnight. When the unions objected he locked them out. When the Western Australian Industrial Commission ordered that the practices continue through August he ignored it. For good measure he denounced central wage fixing, unionism, arbitration in general and democratically elected governments. If Mr Copeman were alone in all this criticism there would be little cause for alarm. The extremist views of one man, even of one very powerful man, might be ignored. But Charles Copeman is just one member of a very select, intelligent and influential group which goes by the name of the H. R. Nicholls Society. His actions are but the result of a new theory in employer-employee relations-a theory espoused by the wider group known collectively as the New Right. Their economic philosophy embodies a primitive faith in market forces. They see unions as a bar to the free operation of market forces and so want unions and the arbitration system to be eliminated. Their way of achieving this is by head-on confrontation, with no room for negotiated settlement. Though it is a policy which failed at Robe River, it is one which the New Right overall has not abandoned and we can expect more of the same belligerence.

What the Australian community now has before it is a choice of industrial relations alternatives. On the one hand there is the accord, proven over more than three years to be adaptable to the economic realities which Australia faces, and successful in allowing non-inflationary growth and increased employment. Alternatively, there is the New Right theory which does away with unions, wage fixing and arbitration. The theory looks something like Margaret Thatcher's Britain in practice. All of the so-called cures have been tried-anti-union legislation, privatisation, laissez-faire economics and decentralised collective bargaining. The result is an economic and social nightmare where unemployment is rife and where, despite the Government's best efforts, real wages have increased by 10 per cent over the last three years. The gap between rich and poor has widened, paving the way for racial violence of tragic proportions. The Government in England has fast run out of government owned industries to sell off in a desperate effort to balance the budget. In short, Margaret Thatcher's experiment has been an ignominious flop. The only ones to profit by it have been big business and the haves in general. The category of have-nots has increased exponentially and, lo and behold, when we look at the members of the New Right, who do we find? We find big business leaders and academics sponsored by big business. The lessons of Thatcherism, or rather its advantages, are being taken to heart by the New Right.

Would a decline in union power and arbitration be of any benefit? Not at all. We have in this country the experiment of the early 1980s to show us the real results. The social Darwinism which the New Right preaches, whereby the strongest survive, will apply to unions as well. Powerful, determined unions can apply all their efforts to going on an industrial rampage to secure their goals. In this case the free marketeers may not be very pleased with what the unions can get when they try out the old theory of what the market will bear. Smaller unions, or workers employed by larger firms, will be squeezed for all they are worth. The anomalies between different workers will be enormous. In fact, the members of the New Right should recognise the foolishness of some of their suggestions. Three-quarters of the restrictive work practices which Peko believes should be abolished were negotiated between the unions and the previous owners of the Robe River mine. Not every employer will act like a Charles Copeman, just as not every union will act like the Builders Labourers Federation.

Some of the more responsible employer groups have already seen the error of the New Right's ways and have sought to distance themselves from it. Mr Lindsay Thompson of the South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has denounced `breakaway groups' who `could do a lot of damage'. Mr Brian Oakes, the Chairman of the Confederation of Australian Industry, expressed support for the work of the Arbitration Commission, while only last Monday David Hoffman of the Queensland Federation of Industry stated that the New Right was a potential danger. Of course, they should have every reason to be sceptical about the economic management abilities of the New Right's theorists. After all it was the H. R. Nicholls Society's president, Mr John Stone who, when he was Secretary of the Treasury, recommended the policies that have put us in the predicament in which we now find ourselves. In 1981, Mr Stone recommended, and then defended, moves to increase the current account deficit, to augment resources and enable growth to take place. He was also instrumental in keeping the dollar artificially high, thus destroying our export competitiveness and strangling our import replacement industries. Well might some employers doubt the competence of the New Right. The same John Stone, it might be added, is also a director of Peko but, of course, there should be no suggestion of any complicity in the matter.

Another factor which they have totally failed to account for is the extremely small gain that their industrial belligerence would obtain. We know from experience how damaging a protracted dispute in a key industry can be. It brings misery to the workers, it crushes the profitability of the firm involved and it lowers the industry's standing domestically and internationally. But suppose all that bitterness could be avoided and the New Right could achieve what it wanted without any tears. Even then an across the board 10 per cent cut in wages in the manufacturing sector would still reduce costs by only 3 per cent. The battle is simply not worth it when one considers that the biggest single boost to our export competitiveness has come about through the floating of the dollar. Since the end of 1984 our currency has fallen by 40 per cent on the trade weighted index. This is the major factor in our increased competitiveness and it is this factor which our industries must capitalise upon. In one sense, then, the battles which the New Right would subject us to are all over small change. The New Right's posturing is all the more petty in the light of the call by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last night for a summit on restrictive work practices involving unions and business. It is clear proof that the system works well under Labor without lockout strikes or sackings. The unions, indeed, under the accord have come of age. Through the accord, Australia's working men and women have offered industrial restraint in return for a say in the way in which the economy is run. The New Right would destroy this harmony for its own petty gain.

In such circumstances Australians have a right to ask the Opposition where it stands on the matter. Is the Opposition merely the mouthpiece of this new group? The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) has denounced the New Right as ignorant of the social aspirations of people. We still have not heard the Opposition leader clearly state his position. The working men and women of Australia have accepted the need for restraint. They will not now be bullied by academics, ex-public servants and second rate businessmen into giving up the institutions which have given them their high standard of living.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's decision to remove 45 items from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme is a calculated and callous attack on Australia's three million pensioners and low income earners. It is an attack that will not be felt until it takes effect in six weeks time, but nevertheless is a kick in the head that will not be forgotten by the pensioners. The deletions mean that pensioners will have to pay for commonly used paid killers such as aspirin and Paracetamol that are used extensively by arthritis sufferers and for pain relief. Additionally, there has been a total deletion of antihistamines, which are widely prescribed to relieve cold and influenza symptoms and for allergies. The removal of commonly used cough suppressants and expectorants as well as some vitamin preparations and other items will cause great concern and stress to pensioners. The Government will save about $40m yearly, most of which, if doctors wish to keep up treatments, will come out of the pockets of pensioner patients. More than seven million prescriptions are involved annually. Examples are as follows: Almost one and a half million for Paracetamol at a cost of $6m; 949,000 for Aspalgan at a cost of $4m; 550,000 for Solprin at a cost of $2.3m; 356,000 for Zadine, costing 41.7m; 232,900 for Polaramine costing $1m; 521,000 for bottles of Senega and ammonia mixture worth $2.1m; and 452,000 for bottles of Pholcodine Linctus, costing $1.8m, to name just a few.

SPEECH.PARA: In a letter to the Canberra Times of 1 August 1986 the Minister for Health, (Dr Blewett) stated that most of the drugs delisted were available over the counter, through supermarkets or pharmacies. He continued:
This means that pensioners can buy these various drugs without first having to visit a doctor.

Indeed, I point out to the Minister that they can do that now. In effect, what he was saying was: `We do not want pensioners going to doctors. We want them to pay for their drugs.' Obviously, this is purely a cost cutting exercise. On 19 August last in this House, in answer to a question from the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) the Minister said:

First of all the decision was made on health grounds on the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee which provides recommendations as to which drugs should go on the essential drug list in this country. Its advice in relation to the 46 formulations we are now discussing was that these were not drugs that could be justified on that essential drug list on the grounds of their minor therapeutic effect.

He made a further point in that answer about concern being expressed on both sides of the House, and by medical authorities, about the increase in the usage of drugs by pensioners. The point needs to be made that there is no essential drug list in Australia. It is a nonsense for the Minister to state that these deletions have been made on health grounds. I make that charge for three reasons. First, all of the preparations have been, are and will continue to be, in major usage by the medical profession in this country and world-wide. Secondly, I understand that about 80 per cent of the delisted drugs will be added to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits list. Thirdly, if the drugs are so detrimental to the health of pensioners, why will they continue to be so readily available to the community-and that includes pensioners on an over the counter basis in pharmacies and, in some cases, supermarkets. The question is immediately posed: Why has the Health Minister misled the Parliament and the public? If these deletions are made on health grounds, why is the medical profession able to prescribe them for repatriation patients but not pensioners? Why are they readily available all over this country and in other countries, and why have they not been withdrawn from sale altogether? If some of these drugs have been overprescribed by some members of the medical profession-and that does occur in some instances-why not tackle the problem at the doctor level?

The Minister has approached this matter in a most devious and unprofessional way. While I recognise and accept the right of the Government to make decisions to add to or delete from the list, the Government and the Health Minister in particular deserve condemnation for the devious way in which it has been brought about. The simple matter is the Government said that cuts had to be made in the cost of pharmaceutical benefits. The deletion of these items is a cost cutting exercise. To achieve the cost cutting, hopefully with as little criticism and odium as possible, the Minister adopted a cowardly approach by hiding behind the PBAC. The Health Department went to the PBAC with a great list of drugs-a list, incidentally, much larger than that of the 45 items that eventually were deleted. In addition to the deleted analgesics and antihistamines, cough suppressants, expectorants and some vitamin and other products, the list contained reference to antacid and antifungal groups. In effect, the PBAC was advised that if it did not make substantial deletions the Minister himself would make them. The outcome is that the PBAC, comprising seven doctors and two pharmacists, has done the Minister's dirty work. The Minister has effectively achieved his goal by coercing and manipulating the PBAC to make the decisions, thereby taking the heat off himself and the Government. In effect, the PBAC has been a party to deceiving the public, probably unwittingly, but nevertheless it has done so, at the same time allowing itself to be compromised. One has only to examine a document that I have in my possession entitled `Deletions recommended at June 1986 meeting of PBAC' to realise that the reasons for the removal of most of these drugs really has nothing to do with health grounds. Included at the end of the list of 45 drugs are the words `The items above are from the list submitted to the Committee by the Department'. Certain words then appear:
The following items were also recommended for deletion at the same meeting.

A further six drugs are then listed for deletion. It is quite clear that the Minister wanted to effect cuts. The PBAC had its riding instructions through the Department and the cuts have occurred via its recommendations-a neat process, with the Minister hiding behind the PBAC's recommendations. One has only to look at the reasons for removal to see that there are really no strong health reasons for such deletions. Take the case of the analgesics, concerning which the following is stated:

Aspirin products removed as, in general, they are used mainly for minor complaints. They are readily available over the counter without prescription, in smaller quantities from stores and supermarkets and in larger quantities from pharmacies. In general only a limited number of doses is required to treat a complaint, not the larger quantities available on NHS.
I submit that there are no real health or medical reasons for their removal. As to the aspirin and codeine preparations, the following is stated:
As for aspirin, in addition the 8 mg codeine content is reported to be a sub-therapeutic dose suggesting the combination is inappropriate.

This is a joke. Almost without exception two or three tablets are taken as a dose, making the codeine content 16 or 24 milligrams. The British Pharmacopoeia lists the therapeutic dose as 10 to 60 milligrams for adults. It is strange that the dose and combination should be inappropriate when annually 949,000 prescriptions are written for pensioners and 216,000 are written for concession cardholders. Likewise, the reasons for the removal of the 21 antihistamines are obviously not health reasons:

The oral antihistamines are mainly used in treatment of mild or trivial complaints such as allergic rhinitis, mild urticaria and head symptoms of colds and influenza. The conditions are often self-limiting or at most only requiring a short course of treatment before the symptoms resolve. Most of the drugs are readily available from pharmacies without the need for the prescription of a medical practitioner.
The reasons for removal of the cough mixtures are just as convincing:

These products are used in the treatment of minor complaints supposedly to alleviate the symptoms of cold and influenza. All are available without prescription. A large number of proprietary products of similar action are available from food stores and pharmacies. Although these products may give some symptomatic relief of symptoms there is some doubt as to their efficacy in helping resolve the actual disease process.

With the deletion of aspirin, Paracetamol and associated analgesics, I predict substantial increases in the prescribing of Brufen-in 200 milligram and 400 milligram quantities-Indocid, Dolobid and Voltaren for joint pains and arthritic sufferers. These are more potent drugs and more expensive than the deletions. They are not, and should not, be first line treatment drugs, but with aspirin and Paracetamol off the list they could well become such.

Perhaps the Minister should check out the PBAC statement that arthritis, for which aspirin et cetera is extensively used, is a minor complaint. Arthritis sufferers will tell anyone how minor it is! The non-availability of on-list anti- histamines could result in the prescribing of the more dangerous and potent oral steroid preparations. Apart from the objective of shifting the cost to pensioners, the changes may well prove to be more of a problem and more detrimental to health than at first meets the eye. My final question to the Minister is: Why did he have to be so devious about the changes? Why not be honest and tell pensioners straight out that we need to cut costs and therefore they, the pensioners, need to pay more for some of these drugs? One might ask the question: Can the Minister for Health be trusted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to speak on a subject which is close to my heart. It is peace or, more particularly, the conflict that has been brought about by peace-the conflict that has been initiated by a few. I refer to what has been a continuous assault on those who wish to do no more than inform our children about the love of humanity which comes about by practising throughout our daily lives peace, not conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: The year 1986 is the International Year of Peace. Many worthwhile projects have been funded and I agree that a few appear to be questionable. The opponents of peace naturally pick out a few examples and place all peace projects in the same basket. The most vocal and, I believe, unwarranted attack has been directed towards the area of peace studies within our education system. I would like to give you a few examples of the types of criticism directed towards those who would have the effrontery to propose such a radical idea as the teaching of peace to our children:
Peace studies is a Marxist plot to exploit children.

Most Australians, I am sure, would regard `peace studies' as a disturbing program of educational subversion. The subject has emerged as a new method of subtly undermining foreign and defence policies.

Well researched and well documented examinations have clearly revealed that `peace studies' has been introduced into school syllabuses because of the conscious effort of Marxist and Communist-influenced teacher's unions . . . academic and peace movement activists to mobilise school children for their political operations.

Peace studies has been shown to psychologically disarm and damage children, while de-authorising parents-a pernicious form of indoctrination designed to exploit the psychological and political vulnerabilities of school children.
Another comment is headed `War on peace studies' and states:
Tragic purpose

The inclusion of `peace studies' in our school curriculum is a tragedy as it means that our education system is being used for a purpose foreign to democracy. Fear is being used as a psychological weapon to influence the young without regard to the ultimate harmful effect on them.
Another comment is as follows:
`Peace' studies target the Pacific
Anyone in doubt about the insidious potential of `peace' studies in our schools needs only examine some of the available literature and kits on the Pacific region . . .

Such publications first condition their young audiences to anti-Western bias by surveying the `sins' of European colonisation in the Pacific. The art is to blend legitimate historical detail with current radical left political objectives while glossing over, or ignoring, the legitimate interests of Western and other non-communist powers in the region.
Source material listed are overwhelmingly from the anti-American, Anti-development, anti-uranium, radical left lobbies.
There is still more:
Conflict over year of peace funding.

It is unfortunately a likely consequence of 1986 being designated as the United Nations International Year of Peace that there will be an increase in the amount of peace studies material being taught in Australian schools. Victoria has led the way in this development, with the Federal Government not far behind. The problem is that most of the peace studies material derives in one way or another from the peace movement and therefore lacks objectivity.

The peace movement takes a particular view of how peace can best be maintained. It is a view with a strong anti-nuclear component and with strong unilateralist and anti-American overtones. It is a view which has never won the allegiance of more than a minority of the community and has never been endorsed by Government or Opposition in Australia . . .
Activist political groups should not be funded by the taxpayer. Subsidising the peace movement is not a legitimate way for the Federal Government to spend our money.
Another article states:
Critical fallout as dollars for peace studies mushroom.
Critics point out that peace studies literature and resources kits tend, in their net results, to.
increase anxiety amongst school children;
deny students the right to evaluate issues indepen- dently;
undercut the relationship between student and parents;
turn schools into re-education centres whose purpose is to mobilise students as peace activists, and
subvert liberal educational principles by creating simplistic responses to complex questions.

What are all these people afraid of? What makes our national papers, our national magazines, and some of our leaders within the community rise up in such outrage at this idea, this dangerous idea, in fact this traitorous thing called peace? I will tell honourable members but not in my own words, not in the words of some great scholar or learned statesman. I will tell them in the words of our children, our future. I would first like to read extracts from remarks by some young overseas people between the ages of 15 and 24 years. From Bangladesh comes the following:
In the developing countries there is only one doctor for every 3,700 people but the figure for army personnel is one for every 250.
This contribution comes from Egypt:

When I ask a child who has not yet reached the age of five `What does peace mean?' he replies `I do not know'. If I ask him `What does war mean? `he says: `People fighting, that is dying'. The child knows much about war, but nothing about peace.
This is from Jordan:

Holding out a bunch of flowers the little girl said with a smile: `Buy flowers, sir. Flowers are the messengers of the heart'. `I do not want to buy' he said. `I would like to ask you a question. Do you think selling flowers is appropriate in present circumstances? Thousands of people are dying. Innocent people are being swept away. They are darkening childrens eyes. And you? You sell flowers! In a sad voice she said, `You are not the only one who is surprised about this. All the flowers in the world would not be enough to decorate the graves of those of whom you speak with such pity. The dew on the flowers reminds me of the tears of my young brother who lay in the dark sucking my mother's breast smeared with blood. I know why I sell flowers. Their beauty is the beauty of life. But it seems that you have not yet understood their message. . .'
The following is a letter from an Australian student. She is 13 years old and originally came from Portugal. Her letter to me is responsible for this speech-
Dear Mr Chynoweth, family, staff and electorate.
This paper crane was made by a student, teacher, ethnic aid, counsellor, secretary, general assistant or canteen lady at the Cleveland Street Intensive Language and Reception Centre.
It is one of one thousand paper cranes made in the memory of Sadako Sasaki a young Japanese girl who died of Leukaemia as a result of the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima.
In Japanese culture one thousand folded cranes will grant you your deepest wish. In 1986, International Year of Peace, we have folded our cranes for peace.
Are paper cranes, like this one-the dove bearing an olive branch-the insidious weapons of peace studies? If they are, they will surely win.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate to ask the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) to declare, as soon as possible, the Pacific Highway a part of the national highway system. It is essential to upgrade the Pacific Highway to a four-lane, dual carriageway, divided road standard. There are compelling economic, demographic and safety reasons for the Pacific Highway, one of Australia's busiest highways, being upgraded to that level to overcome its present state of chronic disrepair. The Pacific Highway has been ignored in favour of other highways which have benefited from substantial redevelopment and upgrading through expenditure on them by the Federal and New South Wales governments.

SPEECH.PARA: On the north coast, annual average daily traffic volumes in 1984 varied between 3,832 vehicles in Richmond River Shire and 11,341 vehicles in Port Stephens Shire. An average of 5,980 vehicles used the highway each day in 1984. These vehicles travelled an estimated 15,410 million kilometres along the highway in that year. Overtaking is impossible along 41 per cent of the highway north of Hexham and is effectively impossible along 53.7 per cent of the highway north of Hexham. The pavement condition on 47 per cent of the highway north of Hexham varies from very poor to fair.

The highway is of great value to the tourist industry. In 1983-84 there were an estimated 5,477,500 visits to local government areas through which the highway directly passed. Tourists spent 21,442,000 nights away on these visits and expended $1.119 billion. The highway is also extremely important to agriculture. In 1983-84, local government areas served by the Pacific Highway included 7,267 farms, which produced agricultural commodities valued at $256.8m.

Bad roads result in an increased likelihood of motor vehicle accidents causing death and injury. The cost of constructing, upgrading or maintaining roads at an optimum safety level can be offset against the budget set aside by government for the provision of medical, hospital and emergency services in the community. The Insurance Council of Australia has estimated that road crashes cost the Australian community nearly $3 billion per annum, or 2 per cent of the Australian gross domestic product. In 1983 this represented in human terms about 3,000 people killed and 100,000 people injured. Deaths caused by motor vehicle accidents ranked third, after heart and circulatory disease, as the main cause of death in 1983. By comparison with the cost of motor vehicle accidents to the whole Australian community the Commonwealth Government in 1985-86 allocated $1.25 billion for road building, maintenance and safety research. This figure does not include expenditure by the States or by the Commonwealth on the Australian bicentennial road development program. The Royal Automobile Club of Victoria estimated in 1983 that the cost of motor vehicle accidents was: For fatal accidents, $301,785 per fatality; for major injury accidents, $67,445; and for minor injury accidents, $7,760. Between 1983 and June 1986 the average weekly wage increased by 23.4 per cent, from $295 per week to $364 per week. Therefore, if one multiplies the 1983 figures by 23.4 per cent, the cost of motor vehicle accidents is estimated to be $372,403 per fatality for fatal accidents, $83,227 for major injury accidents and under $10,000 for minor injury accidents. Dollar values cannot be placed on factors such as pain and suffering, which are often the worst effects of motor vehicle accidents. In human terms, the average stay in hospital of a person admitted as a result of injuries sustained in a motor vehicle accident is approximately two weeks. This is twice the national average time for hospital admission from all other causes. Some motor vehicle accident victims spend months and even years in hospitals and attending rehabilitation centres. With an average stay in hospital of 13.4 days, motor vehicle accident victims require annually the equivalent of 1,000 years of hospital treatment, thereby absorbing resources which could be used for other people. This additional work load is placed on hospital, medical, ambulance, nursing and rehabilitation services. With already overtaxed health services, the additional burden caused by road accidents is unwarranted and indefensible.

One of the features of the National Roads and Motorists Association's 1986 survey of the Pacific Highway was the disclosure of the significant crash factors for motor traffic accidents on the highway. The survey stated that there were two predominant factors for accidents along the Pacific Highway, namely, wet weather and poor alignment of the road. Both of these are environmental factors, according to the analysis of motor traffic accidents carried out in an Indiana study. In New South Wales, 20 per cent of all crashes occurred in wet weather. However along the Pacific Highway north of Hexham the proportion of motor traffic accidents resulting from wet conditions varied from 31 per cent to 58 per cent of all accidents.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is very bad engineering too.
—Very bad engineering indeed. This is well above the State average-20 per cent of all crashes occurring in wet weather.
—It is also a high rainfall area.

—That is very true and special care is needed. In other words, along the Pacific Highway north of Hexham the driving conditions and environment do not facilitate safe driving in wet weather conditions. That is clearly unacceptable along a road which carries such heavy traffic volumes as does the Pacific Highway. Statistics compiled by the Traffic Authority of New South Wales indicate that in the seven years between 1979 and 1985 there were 24,406 motor vehicle crashes on the Pacific Highway. Of these 585 were fatal and resulted in the deaths of 698 people-an average of almost 84 fatal crashes and 100 fatalities each year.
—That is more than one a day.

—It is indeed. These are far, far higher figures than are experienced on either the Hume Highway or the New England Highway. But what about the cost of traffic accidents? If we apply the June 1986 estimate of motor vehicle accident costs, we find that between 1979 and 1985 the cost of all motor vehicle accidents was as follows: For 698 fatal crashes, $259m; for 15,122 crashes involving casualties, $451m; and for 14,000 accidents involving non-injury property damage only, $35m. Over a period of seven years, 1979 to 1985, the total cost was $746m. The cost of motor vehicle accidents was in excess of all money spent on the Pacific Highway and the F3 freeway during the period 1979 to 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: What is clear is that all governments and the taxpayers bear an unnecessarily high bill for mopping up after accidents because of the initial low road investment. In other words, miserly expenditure on roads costs not only lives but also an immense amount of money following accidents. In 1983-84, $49m or $93,000 per kilometre, was spent on construction works along the Hume Highway in New South Wales, excluding the F5, while $30m, or only $46,500 per kilometre, was spent on construction works along the Pacific Highway north of Hexham. It is clear that there is a fundamental link between expenditure on roads and the level of accidents. The more that is spent on roads, the fewer the dead bodies, crushed and maimed human beings that result from traffic accidents, and the fewer the devastated Australian families there are as a consequence. In purely economic terms, the more that is spent on roads the smaller the cost to tax payers of high medical, hospital and emergency facilities, the smaller the cost of the court and police system and the smaller the economic cost to the whole community, including insurance premiums.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to draw the attention of those in this place and the electors of the constituency of Barton to the fact that the vast majority of Australian pensioners are today manifestly better off because of the policies of the Hawke Government, directly and absolutely. Mr Deputy Speaker, I do so because I believe that in the past the Government has been a little reticent in discharging its political function of informing pensioners of its record of reform and assistance to the aged in a number of different areas. Pensioners can hardly be blamed for not realising this because in the past our public relations have not been the best. The facts, however, demonstrate that the average Australian pensioner is much better off under the Hawke Labor Government and, indeed, that the Hawke Labor Government has a record in regard to pensioners and the care of the aged that any Government could be more than proud of.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Fraser regime the pension fell from 24.7 per cent of average weekly earnings in December 1975, under the Whitlam Government, to 22.7 per cent in March 1983, when the Hawke Government was elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a disgrace.
—That happened under Fraser.

—As the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), two well-known defenders of pensioners' rights in this place, have said, that was a disgrace. While Labor has not raised the pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, it has turned this decline around so that pensions today stand at 24 per cent of average weekly earnings-a full 1.3 per cent higher, in terms of average weekly earnings, than was achieved by honourable members opposite. A second measure of this Government's attainments is the fact that since March 1983, in a period of three and a half years, the pension has risen by 7.3 per cent in real terms, that is, 7.3 per cent over and above the cost of living, as compared with 1.5 per cent in the seven years of the Fraser government. Those, I believe, are two statistics that leave this Government perfectly capable of saying that, insofar as the average pensioner is concerned, it has a record of which any government could be proud. The fact is that the Labor Party has not only retained the value of the pension but also actually increased it in real value terms. The priority given to the aged by the Australian Labor Party and this Government was demonstrated in particular in the last Budget-a Budget best described, I believe, as representing restraint with equity.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference between us on this side of the House and those who sit opposite is that we are asking every Australian to kick the tin a little, stating that every Australian should bear part of the cost of our national recovery-unlike those opposite who seek to put a picket fence around the most privileged in our community and demand of others, such as pensioners, that they pay more. Under the last Budget pensioners did not get the real pay cut that the wage and salary earnings of this country got. Instead they got an eight week delay in their pension increase. How contrasting that is to what happened in the Fraser period when, in 1978-79, in economic circumstances that were less onerous, the Liberal Party and the National Party effectively imposed a 12-month pension freeze. This Government did not do that. It felt that pensioners had a priority over and above other Australians. The alternative budget of the New Right-the New Right being the people who pull the strings that are attached to the arms, legs and heads of the front bench on the other side of the House-in the recently published document of Mr Brian Buckley, put forward a strategy under which pensions would be discounted by an export depreciation factor. We have seen, almost as a weekly occurrence, spokesmen from the New Right issue public instructions to the Leader of the Opposition and his front bench. It is notable that the most recent instruction, that of yesterday from Mr Andrew Hay, comes at a time when I am drawing the attention of this House to what the alternative budget of the New Right would have been and what it would have meant for pensioners. The author of that alternative budget, Mr Brian Buckley, is, of course, a very close associate of Mr Andrew Hay, both having served on the staff of the former Liberal Treasurer the late Sir Phillip Lynch.

In other areas of concern to pensioners, this Government has made massive progress. For instance, from December 1986, the threshold at which rent assistance to pensioners becomes payable will be increased from $10 to $15 a week. The maximum rate of rent assistance will apply if the rent paid is at least $45 a week. From 1 July of next year the separate income test for rent assistance will be scrapped. So pensioners who rent, pensioners who are most in need, will directly benefit from our policies. I could refer to a whole range of other achievements. The Government's indexation of pensioner fringe benefits, its introduction of the carer's pension, and the very real steps that it has taken in regard to care for the aged under the home and community care program and by way of nursing home and hostel care leaves those opposite looking bare indeed. They did not do any of these things. The Hawke Labor Government alone has taken these steps for the aged and it is about time that we started drawing more attention to that fact.

That leads me to the question of the assets test. One promise being promulgated by those opposite is that they will abolish Labor's assets test. That test, as we have seen, has caught 34 millionaires, 558 pensioners with assets in excess of half a million dollars and 51,000 pensioners with assets of more than $100,000, over and above the limit. When the assets test was first introduced the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), was not able to contain his real belief that he basically agreed with the concept of an assets test. It was only when the then Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), leaned on him in a semi-public manner that the honourable member for Bennelong's position shifted. Certainly, a belief in an assets test would be far more consistent with the Leader of the Opposition's other views on social security matters than would his present stance. The alternative budget of the New Right calls, of course, for a harsher assets test. That is very interesting because the assets test highlights the very cynicism of honourable members opposite. I believe that the Opposition is carefully leaving open the opportunity to introduce its own assets test should it be elected to government in 1988. I draw to the attention of the House an article in the Australian of 28 August 1986, headed `Opposition leaves way clear for assets test' part of which I will read:
The Federal Opposition yesterday left open the possibility of assets testing for aged pensions, despite a Coalition commitment to abolish the controversial test.
A member of the Opposition's new task force on the aged, Senator Susan Knowles, confirmed the test would be scrapped in its present form, but said the policy had not yet been fully decided.
Asked if assets could remain a criterion for determining aged pension eligibility, Senator Knowles said: `That may well be in the final analysis'.

I believe that that slip by Senator Knowles is consistent with the Opposition's advertising which, if we look at it very carefully, says that the coalition will abolish Labor's assets test, that the coalition will abolish Labor's fringe benefits tax, that it will abolish Labor's capital gains tax. Now I have no doubt that honourable members opposite will maintain their priority for the wealthy retired at the expense of the vast majority of pensioners who benefit from the assets test being installed as part of the system. The Leader of the Opposition, in replying to the Budget, cut loose from the plethora of promises that he had made around the country in the last 12 months and said explicitly that the only policy left to him was that of cutting Labor's assets test. Obviously he will be forced to change that promise, too, but I also believe that the Opposition is running a very cynical campaign, which seeks to extract maximum political advantage from the assets test while knowing well that its own secret agenda will demand that it will, in fact, take assets into account in the distribution of pensioner benefits-in the unlikely event, of course, that it should be elected to government. I would take this opportunity to call upon honourable members opposite to come clean, to be honest about this issue because, quite frankly, if they have no such an intention, why do they not change their approach?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity during the grievance debate to point out some of the enormous difficulties that are being faced by local government throughout Australia today. Many of these difficulties have been, and are being, created by the gross ineptitude of the Hawke Government. Such burdens as the fringe benefits tax, crippling interest rates and high fuel costs have all been brought about as a direct result of this Government's inept policies. I am particularly concerned about the enormous pressure that is being placed on the 530 local governments throughout rural Australia today. As we all know, there is a very real economic problem in rural areas. A great many farmers are facing crisis and it is estimated that approximately 6,000 throughout Australia will walk off their farms in financial ruin this year. Unsympathetic State and Federal government policy is forcing local government to turn to its ratepayers for increased funding to maintain services. The poor old ratepayer, who is also the poor old taxpayer, cops it every time. The ratepayer and taxpayer are the bottom line and suffer greatly when rotten government policies are implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the fringe benefits tax on local government will be enormous.
