The Federal Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, (Mr Uren), has admitted that the tax could adversely affect local government, while councils in more isolated areas may be particularly disadvantaged. The Minister has asked his staff to monitor the effects of the fringe benefits tax on local government councils, and I believe now realises the most serious financial effect that the tax will have. It is estimated that 14 per cent of the total tax collected will be generated from the combined payments, by Federal, State and local governments. As I have already indicated, the taxpayer and the ratepayer will be the bunny once again. By the way, it is estimated that an extra 590 Australian Taxation Office staff will be needed to administer the tax. It will certainly be very interesting to see what sort of a hole will be made in the tax collected by the need to pay such extra staff.

The extremely high interest rates prevailing in Australia today as a result of the Hawke Government's policies are naturally having a most detrimental effect on local government borrowings. Treasurer Keating's record, which has now had the effect of reducing our investment rating from AAA to AA1 will most certainly lead to a further drying up of loan funds. This, of course, will maintain high interest rates for some time to come. Once again, the ratepayer bears the burden. High fuel costs, particularly, affect local government adversely. The large amount of outside machinery required to maintain roads and other assets places a great cost on local government today. The fuel required to run this machinery attracts the same heavy Hawke Government taxes as does fuel used by industry, commerce and private motorists. No concessions are given to local government. The Hawke Government was elected with a promise, among many, to reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre. That promise too has been blatantly broken. Not only has the Hawke Government wiped out half the benefits of the 50 per cent fall in world oil prices this year. It has, by steadily increasing petrol taxes, imposed a further 3c a litre by way of fuel excise tax. This alone will give the Government $715m more in revenue. Petrol taxes this year have risen by nearly 14c a litre-representing a rise from 10c to 23.8c a litre or, in other words, an increase of 140 per cent. The Budget estimates that the revenue from petrol taxes will amount to 95.9 per cent more than it did in 1985-86. These colossal increases in fuel excise and loadings by the record taxing Hawke Government have created enormous increases in costs to local government. Once again the ratepayer must cough up hard-earned income in increased rates.

Roads and footpaths are traditionally the direct responsibility of local government. In recent times the Federal Government has played a most important role in providing funds to assist local government to construct and maintain roads within its individual areas. Largely as a result of State and Federal Government policies over the years, the cost of constructing and maintaining these roads has risen enormously. State and Federal governments have continually endeavoured to reduce their contribution to this funding, while blaming each other for being miserly and irresponsible. Individual councils and collective local government organisations have continually gone cap in hand to governments seeking increased funding for roads. For the year 1986-87 there is to be a 4 per cent reduction by the Hawke Government in road funding across Australia. In 1985 the Australian land transport program was introduced with much fanfare by the Minister for Transport, (Mr Peter Morris). It was hailed as a great step forward because it was indexed against inflationary movements, which thereby provided for local government a predictable basis for road funding over the next five years. In July, the Federal Government reneged on its promise-yet another broken promise by the Hawke Government-and the Australian land transport program suffered a reduction in funds of 4 per cent in real terms. These changes to the program have reduced funding to levels well below what is needed to keep pace with our high inflation rate and the rapid deterioration of a great many country roads.

Local government will suffer most severely from this alteration in funding. Allowing for inflation, this will be the third year in a row that local government has experienced reductions in road finance. It is vital for local government to have a predictable road funding budget in order to plan ahead and function efficiently. The construction and maintenance of our road systems should receive top priority, and it is essential that the Government recognise this and take a more constructive approach in its economic policy. It must basically reduce non-essential expenditure, which will enable it to provide more funding for vital areas such as road funding as well as give some tax relief. That, of course, would take some of the pressure off the poor overloaded taxpayer and ratepayer. Madam Speaker, when I refer to a reduction in non-essential expenditure, I refer to the quite extraordinary sums of taxpayers' money that have been forked out by the big spending Hawke Government. I refer to such things as `researching the Boab tree population and festival activities for Boab Week and Mango Mania' at a cost of $115,000, and the granting of $123,000 to gay publications co-operatives with which to produce the homosexual magazines Outrage and Gay Community News. These are but two examples of the wasteful expenditure that has been revealed by the efforts of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee. Many millions of dollars have been, and continue to be, dished out for projects which would be non-essential if we were experiencing an affluent economy, let alone the very serious economic problems that we are now facing. The future for local government funding is most serious and I urge the Government to face up to the problem and implement policies which will not only assist local government but also assist Australians as a whole.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I have just had handed to me a copy of a letter addressed by you and Mr President to Mr Barrie Cassidy, the President of the Parliamentary Press Gallery, referring to the behaviour of journalists at the main entrance to Parliament House. While I understand that, according to your letter, there have been some examples of behaviour which is `totally unacceptable and a poor reflection on the Parliament', the matter concerns me because in the penultimate paragraph of your letter you state:

SPEECH.PARA: If such behaviour recurs, we will have no alternative but to ban all journalists and camera crews from waiting or conducting interviews on the steps to Parliament House.

We on this side of the House find that suggestion totally unacceptable. We believe that members of this place have a right to be interviewed by people in the precincts of Parliament House and within Parliament House. I ask you, therefore, for an explanation of the basis on which you would propose such action, and perhaps you could explain to us the nature of the misbehaviour which would lead you to consider such extraordinary action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that I will report back to it at a later hour.
—My question is addressed to the Treasurer.
—Hooray! They have found the economy at last.

—The Prime Minister should make the most of it; he will not be there for long. I think I am being attacked by a troglo- dyte. I refer the Treasurer to statements in the Prime Minister's speech yesterday to the Business Council of Australia about the need to internationalise the Australian economy and the recognition that investment by Australian companies overseas can also be a spur to Australian exports. Given that Australia is a net capital importer and not a capital exporter like the United Kingdom, the United States, West Germany and Japan, that Australia will have one of the highest corporate tax rates in the world, and that Australia currently has a massive external imbalance and trading difficulties, how can the Treasurer reconcile the Prime Minister's desire to internationalise our economy with the introduction of a foreign tax credit system? Will not the foreign tax credit system make Australian companies internationally uncompetitive, be a disincentive to investing overseas, and therefore fly in the face of the Prime Minister's wishes?

—The answer is no, it will not, because most of the countries with which they compete operate under foreign tax credit systems and therefore there would be no competitive disadvantage. Of course, it will mean that tax avoidance driven decisions are no longer taken and the balance of decisions to be taken in the economy-that is, investment abroad vis-a-vis investment in Australia-are ones that will be properly taken in the face of the potentials of those investments rather than some tax driven incentive which existed in the absence of a foreign tax credit system, and which exploited tax havens and low tax countries. If we are to get a balance between investment in this country and investment abroad and truly internationalise the Australian economy, as the Prime Minister said, so that decisions of choice about investment opportunity may be taken, those decisions ought to be about the commercial value of the opportunity and not the tax avoidance value.
—Is the Prime Minister aware of recent calls for a 30 per cent top rate of income tax? Will the Government consider adopting this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of extreme elements in our society calling for a 30 per cent maximum income tax rate. Madam Speaker, as you will know, proposals of this kind are not new. Many members of the National Party of Australia have advocated such a policy. Indeed, it is the official policy of the National Farmers Federation. Ordinary Australians must be left wondering who those calling for such a policy actually represent. The facts ought to be understood. For the purposes of revenue neutrality, upon abandoning the tax free threshold, the flat rate of tax would need to be at least 25c in the dollar, which means, very simply, that anyone earning less than average weekly earnings would have to pay more tax. That is, 60 per cent of ordinary, average, honest Australian taxpayers, under this proposal from these extreme elements, would have to pay more tax.

ANSWER.PARA: In light of the fact that members of the National Party in this place, alleging that they represent rural interests, embrace this proposal, let us consider the farmers' tax position under such a proposal. We know that ordinary farmers are having a tough time. In fact, the National Farmers Federation estimates that average farm income is now $6,700 per annum. Under the flat tax proposal that has been put forward by these extreme elements, the average farmer would have to pay $1,675 more in tax than he currently pays. That is what is involved in the embrace of this proposal. The people who purport to represent farmers are putting forward a tax policy which would mean an increase in the tax impost upon farmers. Madam Speaker, when you understand this fact, you have to ask: Who would be the beneficiaries of this proposal? It is no coincidence, of course, that the beneficiaries of this proposal would be exactly the sorts of extremists who are putting it forward. They want the great majority of wage earners to bear a much greater tax burden so that they can bear less.

As with all of the extremist solutions that have been put forward, it is something for the elite at the expense of the average Australian. While these people, who are embraced to a very considerable extent by the Leader of the Opposition and those opposite, are adopting these sorts of policies, this Government is going carefully and equitably about the task of ensuring that the ordinary, honest Australian will have his or her tax burden relieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I remind him of his statement yesterday that he would make taxation not just an issue in the next election but the major issue. In the light of that declaration, I ask the Prime Minister whether he will make the opening contribution to this debate by telling Australian families whether, even after the promised tax cuts that are to be introduced next year, a man on average weekly earnings supporting a wife and two children will pay an average tax rate of 20.5 per cent, while the relevant rate when the former Government left office was 17 1/2 per cent.

—There are three simple points to be made in response to the Leader of the Opposition. The first is that, under the policies of the previous Government, for which in the economic area the current Leader of the Opposition had major responsibility, his contribution to the welfare of the average Australian was to throw him or her out of a job. People did not have a job from which they were able to obtain income upon which they could pay tax. So the first point to be made is that in the last year in which the previous Government was in office and the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer of this country 250,000 jobs disappeared. That was his contribution. The second point is this: Under the approach of this Government, by 1 July next year tax rates will be significantly lower than the tax rates under the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer. That is simply because he allowed the Commonwealth revenue to be deprived of billions of dollars as he callously allowed members of an elite minority in this country to avoid their taxation obligations. The third point to be made is that, if one is talking about the welfare of these people, what the Opposition would seek to do would be to impose an absolute wage freeze upon workers in this country. So as well as having the burden of increased tax rates, they would also have significantly lower levels of income and significantly less opportunity of ever being in employment at all.

—Has the Treasurer noted the broad support which exists in the community for the Government's 1986-87 Budget? Can the Treasurer comment on the clarity and correctness of the Government's fiscal and wages policies compared with the vagueness and irresponsibility of those of the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Opposition has attested, by obliging the Government in failing to question any of the assumptions underpinning the Budget, it has accepted the Budget for what it is, that is, a first class effort to make the economic adjustments which this country deems necessary and requires. My experience during the last three weeks since the Budget was brought down is that there is a very broad support in the general community, amongst the work force and Australian business for the changes proposed in the Budget. They understand that this Government has seriously attempted to put the major adjustments into place, that we have removed one of the two major imbalances bequeathed to us by the former Government, that is, the Budget deficit, which we have reduced from 5 per cent of gross domestic product to around 1.4 per cent, and that the cast of the Budget is such that it will assist the current account in changing back to a position which more equates with its levels over the last 10 to 15 years.

ANSWER.PARA: That is in marked contrast to the policies of the Opposition which has no fiscal policy and no wage policy. The Opposition seeks the leadership of this country without having any effective budgetary policy in prospect or any effective anti-inflation policy because it has no wage policy whatsoever. When quizzed about how it would balance the budget, as the Leader of the Opposition says he would, the shadow Treasurer said at the National Press Club:
It is not in the public interest that an Opposition geld itself by announcing in intricate detail which interests it might challenge with its expenditure cuts.

In other words, the Opposition will not lay down any outlays cuts which the Government has been forced to do for five months. The Opposition will not run the gamut of public opinion and interest groups by taking something from them. The Opposition claims it will have a decent fiscal policy but it does not have the courage or the decency to say where that fiscal policy will rest. The shadow Treasurer stated:
. . . thus inviting the maximum degree of opposition from the interest groups directly affected.

One has to ask the question: If the Opposition does not have the courage to announce outlays changes in opposition would it ever have the courage to outline them in government? The answer is it would not because it did not when it was in government and it never will. What would happen is that fiscal policy would again deteriorate. We have seen what happened when the former Treasurer took outlays up 3 per cent as a proportion of GDP to 29 per cent in his last three Budgets and in those Budgets he had tax receipts at a record 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product. That is what we would see.

We have seen the Opposition in government. We have seen the honourable member for Bennelong with his hands on the levers and we have seen the results. There was an increase of three percentage points of GDP to 29 per cent of outlays under his last three Budgets and receipts frozen at a record 24.5 per cent of GDP for the last three years he was Treasurer. When he was asked what he would do about fiscal policy, he said: `We will not tell you because we will be gelded by the interest groups'. So much for decency and courage on the part of the Opposition.

Of course that says nothing about the $5.9 billion of tax promises which are still standing in the name of the Leader of the Opposition. In one of the most glib statements on record, he said in this reply to the Budget, in a Nixonian phrase, that his outlays commitments were no longer operative but, by implication, he said that his receipts commitments were still completely operative. Let me just recount them. He would institute income splitting which would cost $2.7 billion; institute a flatter tax system by dropping the 49c rate to 40c for individuals and companies and this would cost $1.6 billion; abolish the fringe benefits tax which would cost $325m; abolish the capital gains tax which would cost $5m; abolish tax on lump sum superannuation which would cost $80m; reinstitute entertainment expenses which would cost $310m; reinstitute negative gearing which would cost $50m; have a full flow-on of world oil price reductions which would cost $400m; abolish sales tax on oils and lubricants which would cost $66m; abolish tax on new oil which would cost $165m; provide child care rebates which would cost $108m; restore income equalisation deposits and in-out averaging which would cost $23m and abolish the wine tax which would cost $107m. This totals $5.9 billion.

The Leader of the Opposition would have the public believe that with an extra $5.9 billion of standing and committed revenue policies in some way the coalition would run a decent fiscal policy. It would not; it would blow the gains of the last three years right out the door.

We have a joke of a wages policy by the Opposition compared with the wage flexibility which this Government has given Australia. It has given a greater change in relative wage outcomes in three years than has any country we trade with. Our position is massively different from that of any country we trade with. In contrast, what do we have from the Opposition? On 3 September the Leader of the Opposition said:
I can totally free up and deregulate the IR system for every firm with less than 50 people if you allow every employer that employs less than 50 people subject only to paying a minimum hourly rate.

In other words, if one employs fewer than 50 people one can pay an Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission determined wage. There is no downward flexibility; it is all up. This is the so-called flexibility! When the shadow Treasurer was asked at the Press Club about what he would do to get wage changes, he said:
We would have the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We would be arguing what would be sensible before the Commission. They would be handling the bulk of the wage settlements.

That is the old cake and eat it routine. The Opposition says: `The Arbitration Commission is for the big aggregate changes such as depreciation; the scourge of centralisation is okay. We will go to the Commission for wages depreciation but we will let people with fewer than 50 employees opt for a minimum wage determined by the Arbitration Commission'. That is the current coalition's wage policy. So on wage policy and fiscal policy the Opposition is a standing disgrace, a joke, and one would not think that it could hold up its head. Is it any wonder that the Leader of the Opposition squibbed the opportunity I gave him for a debate on Four Corners or 60 minutes to discuss these issues? The old grinner dropped straight out because he knew that he would be massacred with his wages policy and his fiscal policy. What he wants to do is stand up at Question Time and ask questions about my travelling allowance. Good on you, pal. You will need more than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his death bed conversion yesterday to the cause of eliminating restrictive work practices after the Opposition and those whom he takes pleasure in calling `lunatics and troglodytes' have been advancing that cause for years. In view of the Prime Minister's new found enthusiasm, will he now commit his Government to the removal of the most restrictive work practice of all, namely, the maintenance in Australia of a system of compulsory unionism which is clearly opposed by the overwhelming majority of Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hypocrisy of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, coming as he does from a profession which probably has the most restrictive trade practices of any union in the country, really takes some hurdling. What about the restrictive trade practices of the honourable member's trade union, of the barristers and lawyers in this country? Those restrictive trade practices give lawyers and barristers an income of $1,000 or $1,500 a day. What hypocrisy! Having nailed this hypocrite opposite, let us deal with this question of latter day conversion. I have for a very considerable period, before we ever heard of the New Right in this country, made it clear that, in the economic circumstances confronting Australia at this time, none of us-whether we be workers in the factory, managers in the factory, owners or shareholders-can assume that the practices that have emerged, not necessarily with fault on one side or the other, which have been considered to be appropriate to earlier, more halcyon days, can be regarded as appropriate today. I have been saying that for a considerable period, and I certainly said it before the New Right was heard of.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very significant that we should understand that those in the community who are really concerned about improving the situation in this country have welcomed the initiative that this Government has taken. The Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have indicated that, because they have a real concern about improving the condition of this country, they want to make a serious effort in this regard. The thing which distinguishes the people in the business community and the people in the trade union movement-the people who really want to get this country going again-is the fact that they have a real concern. The Leader of the Opposition does not want the country's position to improve. The essence of what he said in his New York interview when he saw what he referred to as the hard times was `These bad times will suit me'. He said: `These are the times for me'. It is no wonder that he is disappointed when he sees the responsible people in the community, the leaders of the business community and of the trade union movement saying: `Yes, tough times have been imposed upon this country and we regard it as appropriate and entirely possible that we can get this country going in a way which will enable it to meet and overcome these challenges'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now, what about the question?
—Order!
—That is why the business community, the trade unions and this Government-
—What about compulsory unionism?
—Order!
—I asked him about--
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has now been three times called to order.
—I am sorry.
—I suggest to him that he heed the Chair.
—I was just asking him to get on to compulsory unionism.
—I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He will not treat the Chair with disrespect.
—That is the distinction. The decent people--
—It is like South Africa.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I name the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the honourable member for Menzies be suspended from the service of the House.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Menzies is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for Menzies thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I conclude by saying that, neither under the law of this country nor under the policy of this Government, is there the practice of compulsory unionism in this country. In fact, one of the few areas in which compulsory unionism operates is in the profession of the honourable member who asked the question, and he has been a total and willing, involved participant in the compulsory unionism of his own profession.

—Is the Minister for Defence aware of the comments by the shadow Minister for Defence that he believes that the new construction submarine project should be suspended to allow consideration of buying nuclear-powered boats on the ground that they would have greater deterrent value than either of the submarines currently being assessed by the Royal Australian Navy? Is the Minister aware of any justification for this course of action, and what would be the effect on the submarine project, Australian industry, the defence budget and our military force structure if the shadow Minister's ideas were acted on?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice the comments that were attributed to the Leader of the National Party in regard to suspending the submarine project and acquiring a nuclear-powered submarine. He has also said on different occasions that, in covering for that suspension, we should refit the Oberons and set them loose again for whatever number of years this action would take. Naturally, I view those comments with considerable disappointment.

ANSWER.PARA: The propositions that the Leader of the National Party has put forward are in conflict with the advice given to us by the Navy as to what is the appropriate course of action to be pursued by this Government in regard to replacement submarines. Advice to me from the Navy is that modern diesel electric submarines were chosen in preference to nuclear-powered submarines for the priority tasks of surveillance, intelligence gathering, maritime strike and support for maritime operations in our region, and that conventional submarines are well suited to Australia's strategic environment and offer capability advantages over nuclear submarines. That is the advice of the Navy on the capability of the submarines we are seeking and the correctness of our course in that regard.

Of course, one can go a lot further than that in adopting a critical attitude to the views that have been expressed by the Leader of the National Party. In the first place, there is now very substantial support in the community for the industrial package which has come in with the submarine project and for the way in which we have taken that decision. The decision to acquire those six submarines is offering a considerable amount of encouragement, both to the heavy engineering sectors of Australian industry and to the electronics sector in this country. There is a substantial anticipation of both an improved capability in regard to those industries as a result of the submarines and a substantial anticipation of substantial resources going to those industries as a result of acquiring those submarines.

Because of the stop-go type policies that have been pursued in the past, understandably industry has a certain tentativeness in coming into defence projects. I must say that, in this case, that tentativeness has been set aside. Even though the Leader of the National Party can do nothing about this project, it is a matter of disappointment that he should seek to cast doubt on the project in circumstances now where a massive number of Australian companies are involved in its planning and, as I said, are anticipating acquiring substantial capabilities as they go about it.

He has suggested that we should refit the Oberons, which are now a very old technology submarine indeed, and put them into service which could mean that they may be in service for up to 30 or 40 years. By the time that is achieved, what we will have will be, instead of a very effective deterrent capability as well as a defensive capability, which we have now and which we will have with the new submarines, something akin to an underwater jazz band operating around our northern waters. He makes a great point of being critical of the Government in regard to whether or not we should pursue deterrent or defensive strategies. One of the few elements of our defence forces which are more than on the margin in the area of deterrence in fact happens to be the submarines, which constitute a very substantial part of our maritime strike component. That would be weakened by a decision to move away from them.

The Leader of the National Party was also critical as to whether or not this represented a small upgrade on the technology we already have in operation. It is a massive upgrade on that technology. When these submarines come into operation they will be, not only in their general operating characteristics but also in their war-fighting systems, state of the art submarines. When these submarines are in operation, they are going to be not only among the most effective conventional submarines in the world but among the most effective submarines all told. A very important commitment by this Government is locked up in the submarine project in ensuring that capable defences are going to be provided for this country in the long term.

Then we come to the question of cost, raised by the honourable member in her question. Nuclear submarines are some 30 per cent more expensive to acquire and would cost considerably more to maintain and support than do conventional submarines because of the need to provide a suitable infrastructure to build, maintain and support nuclear-powered submarines. Such an industry does not exist in this country. One could not possibly justify setting up such an industry on the basis of the purchase of half a dozen submarines alone, and without that industry we would be left with the same disadvantages we have experienced in regard to the Oberons. We do not have the effective support capability for the Oberons in this country that we feel we need. This new project offers us the ability to achieve exactly that. Go down any other road and the road one goes down will leave us still in a substantial situation of dependence.

Of course, the funds are not there to do what the honourable gentleman has suggested. The Opposition has made quite clear that, despite the complaints it has made about what we depend on defence, it will spend no more. The Opposition has managed to combine that commitment with a whole series of detailed commitments for increasing expenditures. Of course, once the Opposition comes to the position where it is obliged to compromise those two issues, what will come forward is its normal confusion in this area.

I say, in conclusion, that the project we have is on-stream, is on time and is a project which enjoys the support of a massive number of people involved in Australian industry. It will be achieved and contracts will be signed at the appropriate time. We will have defence capability that is effective, and that will be no thanks to the Opposition whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement last night and on other occasions that the Government has taken measures to reduce farm costs. I ask: Is it true that the 2 per cent interest rate since July and last weekend's 20 per cent hike in on-farm distillate costs have added $250m a year to the costs of the farm sector, which is equivalent to one-quarter of total net farm incomes? I further ask: What has come of the Prime Minister's commitment to ease the administrative burden of the fringe bene- fits tax on farmers?

—I am indebted to the honourable gentleman for his question. The facts are quite simple. When we came to office, the increase in farm costs in the previous year had been of the order of 11 per cent. We have more than halved that rate of increase in farm costs. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot rely on the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and the Bureau of Statistics half the time and quote their figures in support of its case and then, when the facts produced by those same sources show that the Government has more than halved farm costs, choose not to believe them. The Opposition cannot have it both ways.
—My question is directed also to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister advise the House what has been the Government's reaction to the disaster at the Kinross gold-mine in South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the House as a whole will have been saddened to learn of the disaster at the Kinross gold-mine in which at least 176 miners, the large majority of them black, lost their lives and 235 were injured. On behalf of the Government, I sent a message to Mr Cyril Ramaphosa, the General Secretary of the South African National Union of Mineworkers. I said that I was deeply shocked to hear of the tragic disaster at the Kinross gold-mine and that the human toll in terms of lives and suffering to the members of the union and other mineworkers in this, South Africa's worst gold-mine disaster, has profoundly affected all Australians. I extended my deepest sympathy and that of the people of Australia, to the relatives, friends and fellow union members of those killed and injured.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to Mr Ramaphosa's call for a commission of inquiry into safety in the mining industry, I expressed the hope that his concerns in this area could be addressed fully and that the chances of such an event occurring again could be reduced to a minimum. I hope that members on both sides of the House join me in this expression of sympathy and support to the victims of this massive tragedy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Prime Minister. The Minister for Trade was reported in the media recently as encouraging business to invest overseas. Does the Minister's recommendation, along with the down- grading by Moody's Investor Services Inc. of Australia's credit rating, prove that under Labor this country is no longer a good investment risk? Was the Minister's advice a suggestion to business that it should get any remaining funds out of the country before the Treasurer's banana republic predictions become a reality?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Fisher asked a question which included a reference to Moody's decision. I suppose it is as well that I try to get the message through to the honourable gentleman, though one must be somewhat of an optimist in trying to do so. I think a number of references have been made by my friend and colleague the Treasurer to the assessments that have been made. I refer to the statement by Roger Knye, the man behind the Australian desk at the New York rating agency. This is the agency's statement, not the Government's. Listen to it and, if possible, understand it. The quote is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Moody's think the Budget was a brave one. In a rating review we take into account the wisdom or lack thereof of the country's economic managers. One of the positive features of the Australian scene is the intelligent guiding of the ship of state.

There is the answer. There is the assessment from Moody's itself and from the commentators. That is one of the positive features that was contained in Moody's statement to set against the externally imposed problem for Australia, namely, the quality and character of the economic management in Australia. Those are the facts that make nonsense of the honourable gentleman's question and the assumptions underlying it.

If the honourable gentleman wants a further assessment of comparative quality of economic management, I refer him again to the assessment of the Opposition's own person, Mr John Hyde, who in his address in August said that this Government had provided better economic management for this country than that provided by his Government, the Government of the Liberal Party and the National Party. Those are the facts. Fortunately, the people of this country and the institutions of this country, the business community and the trade unions are going to set about the task, in co-operation with the Government, of meeting the challenge. The real Australians are about getting the country going and recognising that a challenge has been created for us. Together we can beat it, and real Australians treat with contempt the miserable attitude of Opposition members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Communications. Can he provide the House with details concerning the extent of Telecom Australia's cross-subsidy from profit- able to unprofitable areas, particularly bearing in mind the rural areas of this nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable members will be aware that during the last parliamentary recess I released a report, recently provided by Telecom, giving details of the extent and the direction of the internal subsidy provided within Telecom's charging structure. It is important to understand that Telecom's policy is directed at making telephone services available as widely and affordably as possible. That policy has the complete and wholehearted support of the Government. It is obvious that the cross-subsidy would be incapable of being sustained except in circumstances where Telecom's position, as the sole provider of public switch services, was protected. Yet in that climate the Leader of the Opposition, addressing the National Press Club last year, is on record as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: I think substantial portions of Telecom can be privatised. If ever there was a monopoly that was ripe for the busting, it is the monopoly now held by Telecom.
The honourable member for Mackellar said something similar on 28 July. He said:
If it is true that local calls are subsidised by overcharging on long distance calls, then that is hardly an argument for not allowing competition on long distance calls.

As the leading spokesman on these matters, the so-called economic spokesman for the Liberal Party is so hostile to the concept of cross-subsidy, applying as it has traditionally in this country, I thought it would be both interesting and necessary to have a look at the level of cross-subsidy per telephone service per year enjoyed by subscribers in the Telecom districts most referable to the electorates of members of the National Party. The reason for this is that their silence on this issue has been deafening.

I should like to examine the position of the Leader of the National Party first, the right honourable member for New England. The average subsidy of his constituents is $531 per year per service. The constituents of the honourable member for Kennedy are subsidised on average $13 a year. The constituents of the honourable member for Dawson receive an average subsidy of $14. The constituents of the honourable member for Groom receive a subsidy of $86. There is a subsidy of $90 for the constituents of the honourable member for Riverina-Darling. The subsidy for the constituents of the honourable member for Gippsland is $115. It is $246 for the constituents of the honourable member for Gilmore.

The constituents of the honourable member for Fisher and for the honourable member for Fairfax receive a subsidy of $278. The subsidy for the constituents of the honourable member for Farrer is $296. It is $302 for the constituents of the honourable member for Cowper and the honourable member for Richmond. For the constituents of the honourable member for Page it is $420. It is $431 for the constituents of the honourable member for Hinkler and the honourable member for Wide Bay. For the constituents of the honourable member for Gwydir and for those of the honourable member for Parkes it is $508. Finally, the subsidy for the constituents of the honourable member for Maranoa is $1,083. In the interests of total fairness and completeness it should be said that there are three National Party members whose Telecom districts are not subsidised: The district represented by the honourable member for Lyne barely breaks even; the district represented by the honourable member for Mallee is profitable to the extent of $9; the district represented by the honourable member for Murray, $19 a service.

It is interesting to note that the honourable member for Murray was the only one from the National Party who had the courage to stand up on this issue. In fact, his constituents were not being subsidised. What happened to him? There was a rebellious outburst from the honourable member, for which I congratulate him. It was a revolution which was put down very quickly by the dries in the Liberal Party.

It is also interesting to know that the honourable member for Goldstein has prepared a draft coalition policy on telecommunications, but it has yet to be adopted by the coalition leadership. Like so many of the secret documents in the Liberal Party, that document is about the place and I am able to inform the House that in its draft form it completely repudiates the privatisation nonsense as espoused by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). Certainly, there is no question as to why that document is still in a draft form and has not been adopted. The people of rural Australia had better understand that it is about time that the people here who purport to represent them stood up to be counted.

—I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—Please proceed.

—The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in the course of answering a question at Question Time today from his own side of the House, made the quite erroneous statement, that I had squibbed a debate with him about the economy on the Four Corners program. I would like to inform the House of the correct circumstances of that matter. I was approached by the producer of Four Corners, Mr Olle, a couple of weeks ago with a proposition that there be a discussion on the economy involving the Treasurer and myself and a number of private sector economists and some journalists. I indicated to Mr Olle that I would be prepared, as Leader of the Opposition, to engage in a debate about the economy with my opposite number who is not the Treasurer but the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I said that the correct person to debate the Treasurer from our side of the Parliament was my colleague the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). Mr Olle said that he would go back to the Prime Minister to find out whether the Prime Minister would be prepared to debate me. He came back to me and said: `John, we have a very difficult position. Hawke won't debate you and Keating won't debate Carlton; so I haven't got a debate'.
—Order! The honourable member has shown the House how he has been misrepresented. He is now debating the issue.
—Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation on the same issue.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes. I claim to have been misrepresented by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). I did offer to debate the Leader of the Opposition. Again, I offer to debate him any time, anywhere, any place.
—I want the organ grinder. I have dealt with you for years. Why don't you debate Carlton?
—Order!
—You have not got the courage to debate Carlton, have you?
—Order!
—Why don't you debate your opposite number? You will not debate your opposite number.

—I will not debate the block, I will debate the butcher. The honourable member for Bennelong is so gutless he runs away from a debate with me. When he gets a bit of guts back he should take me on and I will make a mess of him.
—The Treasurer should withdraw that or I will give him two up his. I will give it to him, the smart-Alick.
—Order! If the Treasurer said something offensive which I did not hear will he withdraw?
—I did not.
—I point out to the Leader of the Opposition that on several occasions he has refused to heed the Chair. I ask him for more co-operation in future.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that The House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Andrew,Mr Beale,Mr Blunt,Mr Braithwaite,Mr John Brown,Mr Carlton,Mr Cobb,Mr Coleman,Mr Conquest,Mr Dobie,Mr Drummond,Mr Dubois,Dr Harry Edwards,Ms Fatin,Mr Fitzgibbon,Mr Hawker,Mr Hollis,Mr Jenkins,Mr Kent,Mr Lloyd,Mr Mildren,Mr Mountford,Mr Nehl,Mr O'Neil,Mr Reith,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Rocher,Mr Ruddock,Mr Slipper,Dr Watson,Mr White,Mr Wright and Mr Young.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations. Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Dr Charlesworth,Mr Cobb,Mr Dubois and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum.''
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker,Mr O'Neil and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners, therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
Reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Hawker and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7 per cent in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5 per cent of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5 per cent of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular:
the failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;
the abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18, even those still at school;
the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many larger families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI;
the dependent spouse rebate be retained;
the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That families have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of their net disposable income through:
failure to index family allowances-resulting in a 50% loss in their real value since 1976
abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18-even those still at school
failure to increase the spouse rebate since 1982
discriminatory taxation system-which penalises single income families.
Recognising the cost benefit to taxpayers when the intact family unit itself delivers essential care to the extended family.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take immediate action to:
restore the lost value of family allowances and to index them to cover future price rises
introduce optional income-splitting for taxation purposes
retain the spouse rebate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker, Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia, respectfully showeth:
We totally reject any moves to cut funding to Australia wide English as a Second Language Programmes in Schools.
We request that the Australian Government restore funding to the 1985 levels in the 1986/87 budget.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown,Ms McHugh and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia, respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the closure of the Wollongong area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

2. That the impact of the closure of the office in Wollongong will be particularly felt by the non-English speaking migrants and community at large from Shoalhaven to Hellensburgh and as far as Wingecarribee and Wollondilly.

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that the area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Wollongong kept operational and fully staffed.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Hollis.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent change in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Mssrs Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act, refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act (as amended in 1985), and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell and Mr Drummond.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefit tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie and Dr Watson.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival;

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will: Propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the `First International Earth Repair Year'
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards and Ms McHugh.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should;
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
1. That the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 is having a detrimental effect on the car industry generally in South Australia, and more particularly, on employment in that industry.

2. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 contains many anomalies, inconsistencies and mistakes in drafting and its administrative implementation is an unwarranted burden on Australian businesses and the Australian taxpayer.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this House repeal as a matter of utmost urgency this regressive legislation which imposes a disincentive to economic and employment growth, thereby jeopardising the well-being and living standards of all Australians,
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors
2. its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes
3. its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance

4. in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Government's Fringe Benefits Tax is a vicious, punitive tax that unjustly affects employers, will have a major impact on small business and farm profitability, and will result in increased unemployment.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to: Repeal the legislation establishing the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely-depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth..
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because;
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations;
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their remuneration packages;
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business;
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the work force.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system of Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal the Bills of Rights legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights
that the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education
that the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate
that the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Lalor/Thomastown
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:
The lack of a Medicare office in Lalor/Thomastown is seriously inconveniencing the residents of the Shire of Whittlesea.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare office be established in Lalor/Thomastown as soon as possible.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing-related Poverty
PETITION.PARA: This petition of citizens of Australia shows that-
Approximately 100,000 Australians live on the verge of homelessness, dependent on Government resources to survive, or sleep out of doors or in refuges.
Over 700,000 households, or in excess of 2 million Australians are living below the poverty line after paying their rent or mortgage costs.
In addition, there are thousands of households with special needs, such as the disabled, who are not well catered for in the private sector but who nevertheless require suitable housing.
Waiting lists for public housing have almost doubled in the past five years to 146,000 by June 1985. The list is expected to grow to some 250,000 by 1990.
We therefore ask that the Australian Government, as a highest priority
undertake a campaign to bring the issue of poverty and, in particular, housing-related poverty, to the attention of the Australian public
increase expenditure on public housing through the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement, by at least 15% annually in real terms
increase rent relief payments for those on low incomes in the private rental market
use its influence with State and Territory governments to encourage them to increase their expenditures on public housing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners wish that all medicines prescribed by a registered Medical Practitioner be made available free of charge by the Government to all pensioners for the following reasons:
1. The enormous cost of some drugs, including pain relieving ones, not at present on the ``free list''.
2. That certain drugs essential for permanently disabled, such as epileptics are at present being charged for and therefore present a great financial burden to the pensioner.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will consider our wishes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth:
We most strongly oppose the use of the ``Special Broadcasting Service'' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

We are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on Radio 3 EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
We respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.

Your petitioners therefore, strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.
