PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs, Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled, the petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth opposition to cuts in English as a Second Language (ESL) teaching, the scrapping of the Multicultural Education Program, the amalgamation of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), and the abolition of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs (AIMA), as announced in the Federal Budget of August 19, 1986.
Your petitioners request that the Government will review and reverse its decisions on these matters.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Wyong, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the lack of a Medicare Office in Wyong is seriously inconveniencing the residents of Wyong Shire.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare Office is established in Wyong as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Tropical Rainforests, North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that the tropical rainforests of North Queensland, between Townsville and Cooktown, are of outstanding universal value and form part of our `natural heritage' as defined by the World Heritage Convention;
that these rainforests contain the richest concentration of `primitive' flowering plant families in the world;
that these rainforests contain over 1400 species of plants, of which 450 are found nowhere else in the world;
that the area has the richest assemblage of fauna in Australia;
that these rainforests and fringing tall open forests provide the only habitat for numerous rare and highly restricted species of plants and animals; and

that the High Court of Australia found that Articles 4 and 5 of the Convention for the Protection of the world Cultural and Natural Heritage imposed clear obligations on the Commonwealth Government to protect and conserve Australia's natural and cultural heritage.

Your petitioners humbly pray that: the Parliament of Australia will, in order to honour it obligations under the World Heritage Convention, protect and conserve the whole of the tropical rainforests in North Queensland, being a part of Australia's natural heritage by nominating the area for inclusion in the World Heritage List.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Sales to France
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell Uranium to France, against ALP policy.
The French are still nuclear testing in the South Pacific, despite world wide protests. We therefore call on you to reverse the decision to sell Uranium to France.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.

Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully showeth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.

Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Cowper Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Page electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Hail Mary
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

(a) The film Hail Mary (i.e. Je Vous Salue Marie) has been registered by the Film Censorship Board for public exhibition with a Restricted Classification; and is due to be screened in the forthcoming Sydney Film Festival;
(b) The film is a blasphemous and pornographic attack on Jesus Christ, the Blessed Virgin Mary, Saint Joseph and the Archangel Gabriel, as such it is extremely offensive to the undersigned;
(c) The film therefore breaches regulation 13 (1) of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives call upon the Attorney-General, as the Minister responsible, to prevent the exhibition of the film in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the Capital Gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and wealth creation, has contributed to Australia's economic crisis and contains many anomalies.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately repeal the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Act 1986.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Pony Clubs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we the undersigned are totally opposed to the Government's policy to tax pony club income.
Your petitioners urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to allow tax exempt status for pony clubs.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's proposal to bring about a reduction in the amount payable under the present Family Allowance Scheme, that the House of Representatives assembled oppose such a move, on the evidence of its impact upon the family unit.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek to restore payments to the former level.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant products to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliament of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
(1) That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction by the Hawke Labor Government of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
(2) That the impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Hawke Labor Government to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. We are concerned by media statements that the Government intends to restructure the family allowance payment in a form that will reduce its assistance to families.
2. Remind the Government that the family allowance payment is not a Social Security payment as such but a replacement payment for a tax rebate once enjoyed by families for their responsibilities.
3. Whereas the tax rebate would be indexed to the CPI the present family allowance has lost real monetary value since 1976. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
(i) The family allowance payment be indexed to the CPI.
(ii) That there be no adverse adjustments to family allowance payments in the 1986-87 Budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
that the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
that the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gain Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
that the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
that consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
that unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

that the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizen of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair;
It will severely disadvantage both employees and employers;
Employees will clearly lose many fringe benefits as a direct result of the additional heavy taxation burden being imposed upon employers;
Employers will be forced to pay even higher levels of taxation to provide fringe benefits for employees.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Immediately abandon the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAX CHANGES: INCENTIVE FOR AUSTRALIAN FAMILIES AND BUSINESSES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government's tax changes to provide more incentive for Australian families and businesses.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, to the considerable surprise and delight of the Opposition, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in answer to a question, said that the Government intended to make tax not only an important issue in the election campaign but also the important issue. On behalf of the Opposition, I say that we are delighted that the Prime Minister wants to make taxation such an important issue in the next election campaign, because the Prime Minister's record on taxation is deplorable. We will welcome 12, 15 or 18 months of campaigning on the issue of taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought that my good fortune had finished when the Prime Minister made that declaration, but I was mistaken, because he immediately took off for Sydney and, once again bypassing Parliament and choosing another forum to make important announcements, addressed the Business Council of Australia. On the first page of his speech he made a very interesting declaration about the Budget. It has not received any coverage this morning, but it is the most important element of the speech as far as this taxation debate is concerned. He said:
Accordingly the Budget is designed to slow the growth of public and private sector consumption and-
this is significant-
raise public sector saving.

What he is saying is that it is a deliberate aim of the Budget and the deliberate budgetary policy of this Government to increase taxation. That is what the Government set out to do. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) can scoff as much as they like, but the facts speak for themselves. This Treasurer is not only the Treasurer who, to his eternal shame, squandered our AAA rating and who presided over the downgrading of this nation's international credit rating. He is not only the biggest-spending Treasurer in Australian peacetime history, and he not only has double standards when it comes to manipulation of entitlement, but he is also the Treasurer who has presided over the largest levels of taxation in this country's history. He can fulminate, snort, interject and guffaw as much as he likes, but the facts are contained in documents published with his authority, under his name, when the last Budget was brought down. They record in unmistakable terms that he is the biggest-taxing Treasurer this country has ever seen.

Yet his Prime Minister would have his Party fight the next election campaign on the issue of taxation. If the Prime Minister wants to do that, may I suggest that he take a bit of instruction on the fundamentals before the campaign starts. Yesterday and today he was asked three questions on taxation by the Opposition. All of them should have been capable of a straight answer from the Prime Minister. Not one of them was answered by the Prime Minister, for the very simple reason that he does not know anything about what has happened to taxation under his own administration.

My colleague the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks)-one of the great marginal seat heroes in this Parliament-asked him a very simple question: `What happened to your promise to ease the administration of the fringe benefits tax when you went to Canowindra'? The Prime Minister had plenty of television cameras there, plenty of public relations stunts and plenty of grandstanding, and he said to the farmers, `My fellow Australians, I will go back and I will do something about it.' He has done nothing about it, and he did not even have the honesty and the common decency to give a straight answer to the honourable member for Riverina-Darling who, with many other members of this House, knows how difficult it is in the rural areas of Australia.

Just as bad an example is that yesterday I asked the Prime Minister whether it was a fact that an average taxpayer, somebody on average weekly earnings, even after the taxation reforms of the Government are fully implemented next year-do not let anybody put his money on those tax changes going through because there is a good chance that they will not-will be paying a higher average rate of tax than was a person on average weekly earnings when the Government came to power in March 1983. No wonder the Prime Minister rattled on about tax avoidance and made false allegations about breaking the law. He was asked by me today whether it was a fact that a taxpayer supporting a wife and two children would, likewise pay tax at an average rate of 20.5 per cent after the great Keating reforms when in March 1983 he was paying tax at only 17 1/2 per cent. Once again, he rattled on about something that had absolutely nothing to do with it. For a political leader who wants to fight the next election campaign on tax, the Prime Minister has an enormous amount of homework to do.

The reality is that the Government has been a disaster on the issue of taxation. It has abandoned any attempt to control the outlays of the Commonwealth. It has abandoned any attempt to bring down the overall levels of taxation. As a percentage of gross domestic product and as measured by average tax rates, the Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history since the foundation of this country at Federation. We are delighted that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have chosen to fight the election on the issue of taxation. A Prime Minister who says that he wants to fight it on taxation and then an hour later nails his colours to the mast by deliberately increasing taxation receipts in a Budget must be a heaven sent opportunity to any kind of opposition.

Not only the level of tax but also the complexity of taxation under the Government and the unfairness of the fringe benefits tax are at issue. I say again, on behalf of the Opposition, that the Hawke Government's fringe benefits tax will be thrown out, lock stock and barrel, by the coalition in government. I am absolutely delighted to see that my old friend the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) is in the chamber. Do honourable members know which State electorate is partially enclosed within the electorate of Barton? Do not say it too loudly. It is Rockdale, the seat held by the Premier of New South Wales. I am absolutely delighted to see that the honourable member for Barton is in the chamber.

I do not want Australian Labor Party members who are present to feel that we are neglecting their policy. Therefore, I shall take the House through a little exercise. I have before me a copy of the Prime Minister's policy document. Honourable members might remember that, before the last election, the Prime Minister did not have a tax policy. Yet the Government has the temerity to ask me, 18 months before an election, for a detailed taxation policy. What taxation policy did the Government have for the 1984 election? It was a policy of: `Trust me. Don't bother me with any of your questions. If you really get in my way I'll feed you with a whole lot of nonsense, as did the French kings of old'. Let us run a test over the nine principles in the policy document. Let us see whether the Government scores a pass, a fail or an average for its attempt. The first principle is an absolute ripper, but they get better as one wears one's way through them. It states:
There must be no increase in the overall tax burden, as measured by the share of . . . gross domestic product
The Government has failed totally in that respect.
The second is:
Any tax reform must . . . provide . . . cuts in personal income tax.
The third is:
Taxation changes must contribute to smashing tax avoidance and evasion.

The reality is that the Treasurer has not introduced one significant anti-tax avoidance measure in his time as Treasurer. The real job of smashing the tax avoidance industry in Australia was completed by the former Government. The real work in killing the tax avoidance industry was completed by the former Government. The fourth principle is the best of all:
any reform must lead to a simpler system which . . . all Australians can understand
Do honourable members remember that? The sixth principle is:
any tax reform must not disadvantage recipients of welfare benefits, and should reduce or remove `poverty traps' . . .

What happened to the poverty trap proposals in the Budget? They were put off, despite the efforts of the honourable member for Barton. No doubt, the honourable member thumped the table and said that the proposals must go through. However, he failed again and they were put off. The seventh principle is:
if any reform package which includes changes in indirect tax is contemplated, it must be acceptable to the various groups in the Australian community
Once again, that represents an abysmal failure. The eighth principle is even better:
any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment in Australia
Honourable members should listen to the ninth principle:
any reform package must have widespread community support

The Treasurer and the Prime Minister have got nought out of nine on each of their nine principles of taxation. That comes from a Prime Minister and a Treasurer who would have the next election campaign fought on the issues of taxation. All I can say to the Treasurer and his colleague the Prime Minister is that we welcome with open arms fighting the next election on the issue of taxation.

The Government's record on tax is that of a high taxing government. It has not only presided over a rise in overall tax levels, it has not only introduced inequitable, unfair and punitive taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax, against the small business community; it has also introduced taxes that are contrary to the need to internationalise the Australian economy. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the shadow Treasurer, asked the Treasurer at Question Time how he could justify a foreign tax credit system in the light of the desire to internationalise our economy. The Treasurer's limp answer was that all of those countries against which we compete have a foreign tax credit system. What he did not acknowledge was that almost all of those countries are capital exporters rather than capital importers. He did not understand that elementary and fundamental difference.

Even worse, the Treasurer's tax regime has brought about a positive discouragement to business investment in Australia. The Treasurer and his colleagues are wringing their hands and shaking their fists at the business community and are saying: `Why won't you invest? We have given you a 35 per cent depreciation. Surely that is enough incentive for Australian business to invest'. What they do not say in the same breath is that they have also given the business community a 49 per cent corporate tax rate. The Treasurer has given the business community higher corporate taxes when competing countries are giving their corporations lower corporate taxes. He has not only introduced a 3 per cent rise and an imputation taxation system, which will result in many companies paying a higher primary rate of tax, thereby reducing their dividends by an equivalent amount, but also he has loaded, lock, stock and barrel, an additional 3c to give an all time peace time corporate tax record in this country of 49c in the dollar.

The real test of whether business will invest in Australia is not the profit share that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister keep prattling on about. That is not the real test of whether people will invest. The real test of whether people will invest in this country is the after-tax return on their investment. The after-tax rate of return on investment in Australia is at a deplorably low level. It is now at a much lower level than the level that existed for most of the time that the coalition Government was in office. It is absurd and irrelevant for the Treasurer and the Prime Minister to keep talking-as they did to the Business Council yesterday-about the profit share. That is an economic irrelevance. The real test is what return one gets for one's investment.

While we have record high interest rates, record corporate tax rates, a rate of inflation 16 times that of our best customer and an unemployment level approaching 9 per cent, we have a zero investment climate. That is why we will never get decent investment in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one thing about the Liberals is that they have no shame. One would swear that anybody who in 1982-83 sent the country into its first negative growth period in 30 years, who put 400,000 families into the poverty of unemployment, who smashed companies and caused massive bankruptcies, who left Australia with the biggest Budget imbalance and current account imbalance in its history, would not dare raise his head about incentives and taxation. The only tax incentive to Australia he provided in his years of office was the incentive to the tax avoidance industry. Yet the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is not shamefaced. The thing about the Liberals is that they cannot be shamed. Here he is, back talking about his record in taxation. He should hang his head in shame at the revelations of the Costigan report, the McCabe-Lafranchi report, the massive tax evasion he permitted, the telephone book of letters from the Commissioner of Taxation, almost every week, imploring him to take action about it, imploring him to take action about the massive tax rip-offs which he let occur. Guess who carried the burden of the 60 per cent tax rate he left them and the other massive tax rates? It was the ordinary members of the public, while other people escaped through massive and rampant tax avoidance. Fancy him daring to get up and speak about incentives when we had the massive destruction of the economy, the massive disincentive of massive unemployment, an 11 per cent inflation rate, unemployment at nearly 11 per cent, and unfair and prohibitive double taxation of dividends. This is the record of the former Government, this is the record of the former Treasurer.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the jokes of the current Opposition is that we have to watch the words used by the Leader of the Opposition in respect of the fringe benefits tax. He and his shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), must have rehearsed this in the office. They always say: `The fringe benefits tax of the Hawke Government will be thrown out lock, stock and barrel'. It is always the Hawke fringe benefits tax or the Hawke Government. They do not say that they will not tax fringe benefits. They say-it is a sleight of hand-that they will throw out the Hawke Government's fringe benefits tax. But in 1980 the former Treasurer had this to say:

Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash-and most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax and thus effectively subsidise those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds.

What a quantum shift we have seen from those sentiments. That was said when he was trying to put his own fringe benefits tax on the Queensland miners. He said that fairness demanded that people paid solely in cash should not carry all the burden and that these other valuable forms of benefit were taxed. Then when asked on the Carleton-Walsh Report on 30 July this year about the fringe benefits tax he said:
I said when I made the announcement about the fringe benefits tax that what we were going to do was get rid of Mr Hawke's fringe benefits tax-
it is always the same words--
and that abuses in the area, and there were some, are some, would be some in the future, that they would be dealt with in another fashion.

In other words, the dishonesty of his claim is that he will not have a bar of the Hawke Government's fringe benefits tax but he will have one of his own, and he will have one where he taxes it in another fashion. The duplicity of it is that on the one hand he was talking in 1980 about the unfairness of people escaping the tax net by non-cash fringe benefits, but now he is saying: `Oh, isn't it shocking. There is the Hawke Government's fringe benefits tax. We will throw that out'. But he goes on to say: `We will have one of our own and deal with it in another fashion'. Does he think we are all silly, that we do not understand the words he is using, that we do not understand what the sleight of hand is?

It is the same for his deputy, the shadow Treasurer. He said much the same thing: `We will throw it out entirely and do it in another way'. He said: `We would remove the FBT of Mr Keating's entirely, with its 139 pages. We would be back to the old law, which in fact imposed a tax on employees'. How is it going to tax the employees? Apparently the Opposition thinks that this is a vile tax, but it is all right to tax the employees. It is going to have its own fringe benefits tax. The blatant dishonesty of that frankly is sickening. When one looks at the Hawke Government's record on this, it can be seen that we have tried to make the tax system clean, decent and fair for most Australians.

I notice that in another piece of rank dishonesty the Leader of the Opposition said that he does not believe that tax cuts will be given, when he knows the Bills are coming into this Parliament, to be passed during this session, for a tax cut in December and on 1 July 1987. That will take the Howard 60 per cent rate down to 49 per cent, the 48 per cent rate and 46 per cent rate down to 40 per cent, and the other rates below that. They represent the greatest tax changes in the history of the Income Tax Assessment Act since 1936, the largest set of remedial and equitable changes in the tax system on record.

The Leader of the Opposition talks about unfairness to business. `Ignore the profitability', he said. Let me make this clear about the fringe benefits tax and profitability: In the last three years total incorporated and unincorporated business after tax profits were $14 billion-$10.8 billion from incorporated business, up 60 per cent in the Government's three years in office, and $8.3 billion from unincorporated enterprises, a total after tax profit of $14 billion, of which the whole tax package is roughly $700m; $700m out of $14 billion. We hear about how other countries around the world are reducing corporate tax rates. Yet the whole United States tax reform proposal is based on a dramatic increase in corporate taxation. The whole United States proposal which the Opposition is touting is based on a massive increase in corporation taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just torn up the Act into pieces, the same as you. You're a tax bandit.
-Order! The honourable member for Denison will cease interjecting. He has been interjecting throughout this debate.
—You're a tax bandit.
—I warn the honourable member for Denison.

—When one looks through the tax record of this Government, we find that in December 1984 we provided tax cuts of $7.60 a week to the typical taxpayer. There are to be tax cuts in December 1986 and July 1987 worth $1.4 billion and $4.5 billion respectively. We have an imputation system removing the previous coalition Government's onerous policy of the double taxation of dividends. We have abolished the Division 7 profits retention tax on small business. They are tax reforms to ensure that everybody pays their fair share of tax as needs be.

SPEECH.PARA: On this question of tax rates and corporate tax rates, Australia will be only the second country in the world, after West Germany, to have a full imputation system removing the double taxation of dividends. West Germany provides it with a corporate rate of 56 per cent. Australia will provide it with a corporate rate of 49 per cent. It is a corporate tax revolution where for the first time we will be taxing equity once and debt once, instead of, as under the Howard system, taxing equity twice and debt once. Is it any wonder we saw inadequate equity in capital formation in this country and a loss of dynamism in the economy when we were taxing equity twice and debt once. This Government is removing the double taxation of dividends and is doing it at a corporate rate of 49 per cent, seven percentage points less than the only other country which does it, West Germany, which enjoys one of the most robust private economies in the world.

The Opposition should not lecture us about corporate tax changes. What it did about the corporate tax system was nothing. It had 30 years of pleas by business to remove the double tax on dividends and it did nothing about it. It had small business trying to remove the Division 7 retention burden. It left it there for years and years. We have abolished it. Now the closely privately held company which wishes to distribute its earnings by way of dividends to its shareholders can do so without paying any personal tax on the dividends. In other words, they will be taxed once at the company level and that is it. To put it another way, if they pay the personal tax they will get a rebate for the company tax which is paid. It is a corporate tax revolution.

I am quite happy to debate with the Leader of the Opposition anywhere he likes the whole question of changes to the corporate tax system. Of course, he went on to talk about another major distortion, saying that the Government had done nothing about tax avoidance. Apart from the massive changes of the tax reform exercise, let me read into the record the things the Government has done. The Government's bottom of the harbour recoupment legislation, worth $270m, was rejected four times by the coalition parties in the Senate, attempting as they were, and as they still do, to protect tax avoiders. We implemented the law on the prescribed payments system to deal with the black economy in the building and transport industries. We introduced legislation to deal with abuse of superannuation-the cherry-picker schemes; the taxation of lump sums to deal with short term employees who were evading tax by taking remuneration in the form of lump sums; the reduction of the tax threshold for unmarried minors; the removal of the tax exemption for friendly societies; the removal of the tax advantages for short term life insurance policies; the removal of the basic flaws in the capital gains provision of section 26 (a), which is now section 25a; the abolition of unfair tax concessions in automatic in-out averaging provisions; the major overhaul of tax penalty provisions; and a major increase in compliance staff.

We closed off the tax loopholes contained in the interest withholding tax provisions; terminated tax advantages for deferred interest securities; introduced retrospective legislation to recoup moneys lost through new generation trust strips; removed tax advantages for non-monetary benefits received by business taxpayers; and removed the tax advantages associated with leasing by non-residents. We also re-presented the bottom of the harbour legislation. That is the proud record of this Government in regard to tax avoidance. On top of that, there is our record in regard to tax reform.

Fancy the Leader of the Opposition talking about incentives for families! He has been arguing for three years for cuts in their real wages. He has been arguing for three years for a wage freeze. He would deny them any justice in the labour market. He would put the whole burden of economic adjustment on them. Yet he talks about incentives while crushing them by pushing this load on them. The history of the coalition is massive expenditure.

The other great furphy which the Leader of the Opposition keeps pushing is in regard to the Government's record on receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product. He knows full well that, when he runs private health payments through the tax system, he is including them in the tax system. The fact is that, with the extraction of payments for Medicare, which are only a substitute for private health payments, the biggest taxing Treasurer in Australian history is the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong. In his last three years in office he increased tax receipts to 24.5 per cent of GDP.

In his last three Budgets he increased outlays by 3 per cent to 29 per cent of GDP. In 1982 he gave a tax cut which he knew he could not afford, which blew the Budget deficit out to $9.6 billion. He did that because he thought he would go to an election and he might sneak through if he introduced a phoney, fraudulent tax cut which he could not pay for. It was just like the phoney, fraudulent tax cuts of 1977 which he took away from taxpayers after they had been promised a fistful of dollars in the election campaign. In 1977 people were told: `Ring up and find out how much your tax cut is'. He snatched those cuts away in May 1978, five months later. That is the Howard tax record. That is the record of tax incentives for a nation which was smashed to pieces by negative growth, massive unemployment, massive inflation, smashed companies and massive bankruptcies. He talked about incentives and the tax system. He ought to hang his head in shame.

I wind up my remarks at the point at which I started: It is only shameless Liberals with hides like elephants who could propose a matter of public importance of this variety. They have an appalling record of neglect and lack of concern for taxpayers, families, and any other category of Australians, who were smashed to pieces by their cowardice and policy ineptitude between 1975 and 1982. I reject their matter of public importance out of hand. It is just another sleight of hand by a dingy party, to try to get some cheap credibility by making false and fallacious claims which they could not possibly defend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Treasurer (Mr Keating) seeks pathetically to deny it, spending by the Commonwealth and accompanying taxation under this Government have done more to crush incentives for family and businesses than any other single act of this Government. Forced as they are to concentrate on vast and complex changes to tax laws, distracted as they are by unprecedented costs incurred by way of administration expenses and other overheads, overwhelmed as they are by the need to get professional and other advice on how to cope with the additional work load brought about by an avalanche of new laws and regulations, individual taxpayers, families and business managers in this country could be forgiven for asking what they could possibly have done to deserve the miserable treatment they are getting under the Hawke Government. I think they well might ask: `What did we do that was so wrong?' My colleagues and I ask: Why is there all of this preoccupation over the life of this Government with new and more taxes? Every morning people awake to the realisation that they are being mugged by the taxes of a rhetorically sympathetic Government. If the Government spent a fraction of the time it devotes to squeezing more tax out of the incomes of people striving to maintain a decent standard of living on curbing its own profligacy, we would all be much better served.

SPEECH.PARA: This indecent concentration by this increasingly lame duck Government on taxing more rather than axing expenditure simply must stop. There is no sign of it. Commonwealth spending is rampant and the prospects are very dim under this mob. It is the product of the Government's deliberate, cold-blooded series of decisions which see Australia as a nation living beyond its means. Those decisions have seen Commonwealth outlays increased over its first four years in government by just under a massive $26 billion. That is an increase in expenditure of a staggering 53 per cent in just four years. In order to cope, the Government has embarked on a tax regime that seems to know no bounds. It has adopted and threatens new and more taxes, all of which are not part of a coherent tax package, as some would have it, but stem from a series of unrelated money-grabbing measures.

The tax element of the much vaunted trilogy of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was, of course, an inevitable casualty at the altar of sincerity. Does anyone remember the trilogy? It has been conveniently forgotten by the Government. We do not hear much from the Government about that little deception any more; and who can blame it? The taxation component of the trilogy of promises has been broken in its first two years. It was $400m over the odds in the last financial year, and it promises to be at least-and I emphasise, at least-$1.4 billion over the odds this year. So, the so-called trilogy commitment-the key to this Government's fiscal policy-has been unceremoniously aborted.

Tax revenue in real terms has increased under this Government at an annual rate of 4.9 per cent over the full four years, compared with 3.3 per cent during the seven years of the Fraser Government. Let the Treasurer bite on that fact. Tax receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product were increased to 25 per cent in 1984-85 under this Hawke Government-a record high. They have increased even further since then, of course, in the subsequent two Budgets, rising to 25.2 per cent in 1985-86 and 25.5 per cent in 1986-87. In case those opposite want to delve again into the irrelevancies of the past, let me say that the four-year average under the Hawke Government has been 24.8 per cent compared with an average of 23.4 per cent during the Fraser-Howard years. That is a big difference. If one expresses it as a percentage increase, one will understand what I am saying. Government expenditure, even if measured in real terms, has increased by 3.9 per cent a year under this Prime Minister and this Treasurer. That is almost double the seven-year average of 2.1 per cent under the previous coalition Government. Government expenditure as a percentage of GDP is budgeted to be 29.4 per cent in this financial year-the fourth highest figure in post-war history. The other three figures came about during the first three years of the Hawke Government.

It is clear that this Government has set its priorities and it is determined to tax to the hilt to feed its addiction to spending more and more. The priorities of its back bench are not nearly so clear. We see the Victorian Left worrying about the value of the full bob and at the same time it is talking a lot about a halfpenny. That is about the measure of the Left's contribution to economic debate. Members of the Left do not even come into this place; they are not allowed in here. It is good to see the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch). I do not blame the Government for not allowing members of the Left here. They are rarely let loose in this Parliament to debate anything these days. While some on the back bench have legitimate, moral positions the Government is less pretentious.

Remember how the Treasurer and the Prime Minister liked to blame traders in the currency market for the demise of the dollar every now and then. Remember how, in sarcastic terms, traders have been belittled from time to time for simply pursuing business consequential to the refloat of our currency, a decision with which we agreed. There has not been any complaint from the same Prime Minister or the same Treasurer about the Reserve Bank of Australia being in the same market boots and all. We have not heard as much as an apologetic whimper from anyone in the Government about the Reserve Bank bailing it out with a cool $2.6 billion dividend, a dividend available as a direct result of the Bank's punting in the foreign exchange market. It is all right for the Government but it is not all right for businessmen. The double standards mount up and up. Without that dividend of $2.6 billion this year's deficit would be $6.2 billion or taxes would have to be increased by $4 billion instead of the $1.4 billion we now have to swallow. Either way Australia would have been in hock further, and that should not be forgotten.

Some of the budgeted tax hikes deserve a brief mention. The medicare levy has increased from 1 per cent to 1 1/4 per cent which will put another $325m in government coffers over a full year. Motor spirit and diesel fuel have increased by 3c a litre. The Government will make another $715m out of that at the expense of Australian taxpayers and consumers. Alcoholic wine and cider is good for another touch of 10 per cent and it seems that the Government will get another $60m from that. The Government then gets into the kids who drink flavoured milk and fruit juices. The Government says: `Non-alcoholic beverages have been doing all right. Packaged flavoured milk and all previously tax exempt fruit juice products and non-alcoholic wine and cider should bear an additional tax load of 10 per cent'. The only reason those products have to bear that load is that the tax will yield another $75m to this Government's pockets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stealing the kids' milk.

—It is stealing the kids' milk. It was just yesterday the Prime Minister said that it is critical to lift investment in this productive country. Let me tell honourable members and anyone who cares to listen that it is difficult-bordering on impossible-to concentrate on lifting productivity and lifting investment when one has just been whacked about the head by a veritable raft of new tax measures. It is hard to concentrate when one has to work out what one is supposed to do with the fringe benefits tax and when one has to devote the resources necessary just to pay one's taxes-a tax on employment. It is very difficult to concentrate on what one should be doing and getting this country going with investment and productivity. On top of that we have the capital gains tax. What this Government does not seem to understand about that tax is that it has a very strong psychological effect on the business community generally. It will hinder the growth of new investment in Australia which is essential for the development of our economy and consequent growth in employment.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by thanking the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for his courteous and well-timed mention of me twice in his speech. I am pleased that I am so actively on his mind. The sad feature about the rise of the honourable member for Bennelong to Leader of the Opposition is not the Facial cosmetic changes with the clipped eyebrows but that he has become a politician with cosmetic policy stances and clipped credibility. This afternoon we have heard in this tax debate more furphies than a crooked statistician in senility could possibly come up with. Whoever is digging up the Leader of the Opposition's figures ought to re-examine his mathematics. Let us look at a few of the facts. This week the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development released a report on taxation in member countries. An examination of that OECD document reveals that of the 23 OECD countries out of the listed 24 Australia's tax burden, as a percentage of gross domestic product in 1984, was the sixth lowest, not among the highest. The OECD report states:

SPEECH.PARA: As since 1971 the five countries with the highest total tax are Sweden, Denmark, Belgium, Norway and the Netherlands. France, Austria, Luxembourg, Italy, Ireland and the United Kingdom constitute the other high tax ratios. The ratio is around average in Germany and Finland and rather below average in Greece, Canada, Switzerland, Portugal, Australia and New Zealand.

That is how we stand on an international comparison. Let us see how we stand in historical terms. The average tax rate for a person on average weekly earnings is a good guide, perhaps the best guide. Prior to the income tax cuts in November 1982 a person on average weekly earnings faced an average tax rate of 23.1 per cent; that is, under the treasurership of the Leader of the Opposition the average tax rate was 23.1 per cent. The tax cut of 1982 reduced this figure to 20.9 per cent under the Leader of the Opposition's then treasurership. Following the income tax cuts in November 1984 by this Government the average tax rate faced by a person on average weekly earnings fell to 19.9 per cent. In December of this year, with further tax reductions, the figure will further fall to 19.7 per cent and that is before the further income tax cut in July next year. So if we want to talk about the average tax and the average person, the Leader of the Opposition should get hold of these figures and then he would see why we on this side of the House are only too happy to participate in a full scale debate on taxation in the next election campaign.

Another worrying matter which those opposite have to contemplate is that the public at last is starting to see what the alternative agenda would be. Andrew Hay, in his weekly instructions to the Leader of the Opposition through the New Right, has given further tax advice today, but what would its alternative budget be? Mr Brian Buckley's alternative budget would tax the family allowance at the chief breadwinner's marginal tax rate and would cut it out completely for the first child. It would tax veterans' disability allowances. We have seen other fellow travellers of the Leader of the Opposition and his shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), advocating a consumption tax without compensatory measures. The public across Australia has to ask itself what is the alternative agenda of those opposite because it looks pretty horrifying to me.

Much has been made of the increase in tax receipts that has occurred under this Government. Of course there has been an increase in tax receipts under this Government. Some 630,000 people now have jobs who did not have them earlier. A great many of them would be paying taxation instead of taking from the tax system through dole payments as they were under the administration of the Leader of the Opposition. Of course many thousands of people are now paying tax who were not paying tax earlier. Most of those equate quite readily in their political passions with those opposite. That is the equation of those opposite and their mutterings about the various tax measures which this Government has introduced to restore equity and fairness to the system that previously saw those most able to pay paying little or nothing. That situation has changed.

If we look at the Budget Papers we can see, when we compare 1980-81 with 1983-84, that after one year of the Hawke Labor Government 573,171 more individuals were paying tax. There were also 7,114 additional companies paying tax. Of course, much of that is due to the employment policies of this Government-there are more people in jobs paying taxes-and a damn lot of it has to do with the crackdown on tax avoidance that those opposite refused to do when in government. The Leader of the Opposition will be haunted by those figures for the rest of his days in this place. He will also be haunted for the rest of his days in this place by the fact that remaining on the record, on the public agenda, is $5.9 billion of tax promises which he and the shadow Treasurer know must be funded by tax increases that they refuse to name, by spending cuts that they refuse to detail or by a massive blow-out in the Budget deficit of the proportion of the $9.6 billion deficit that the Leader of the Opposition, when Treasurer, left us with.

We can talk about incentive: Where was the incentive, when the Leader of the Opposition was the Treasurer, of the tax cuts which were promised in 1977 and taken away straight after the election in 1978; the incentive when unemployment was doubled from 5 per cent to 10 per cent; the incentive when inflation hit 12 per cent; and the incentive when we had the unfair and prohibitive double taxation of dividends? The only incentive the Leader of the Opposition brought to the system was the incentive to make the tax avoidance industry the fastest growing industry in our nation-a national shame. By contrast, the most far-reaching tax reform in Australia's history has been undertaken and is now being legislated for by this Government. In December 1984 we gave tax cuts that were worth $7.60 a week to typical taxpayers. We will give tax cuts in December this year and in July 1987. They are not just being promised, as the Leader of the Opposition implied a few moments ago. Better than that, they are now being passed into law.

We are cutting the top marginal rate of tax from the former Treasurer's 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. What better incentive can a government give to a nation? We are ending the coalition's onerous policy regarding imputation, the double taxation of dividends. What better incentive can a government give to the business community of this nation? I refer to the abolition of the Division 7 profits retention tax on small business. What better incentive can a government give to the small business sector? We are instituting tax reforms which insure that everybody will pay his fair share of tax in this nation from now on. In all there are tax cuts worth $4.5 billion for the families and businesses of this country. That sum is almost half the deficit which the Leader of the Opposition when Treasurer left to this nation. So in regard to taxation and incentive, this Government has the runs on the board. Honourable members opposite politic and postulate for businesses, individuals and families. We on this side of the House have acted decisively in our 3 1/2 years of government as opposed to the 7 1/2 years of inaction and ineptitude and the corruption of the taxation system over which they presided.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was adjourned I read on to the record a letter which was written to me in response to communications I made to the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. The letter was written by the Secretary to the Commission on instructions from the presiding member. I do not think it necessary to put on record all that I put in the communications that preceded that, save to say that I had sought, amongst other things, to confirm that there were real limitations on what could be provided within the terms of the Act regulating the Commission concerning its actions in winding up the Commission. Effectively what we received is a confirmation of that. The letters have been made public and I do not need to say anything more about them.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the Secretary's letter to me is the fullest statement of the detail of the winding up of the Commission and that the Government did not attempt to get from the Commission a full and measured statement of the steps taken by it in winding up its work and its position under section 34, that is, the section of the Act which provides a power to refer communications to relevant law enforcement authorities. A number of points of importance emerge from the Secretary's letter written on behalf of the Commission, and I shall go through them quickly. First, the Commission's view of its role under section 34 was that it was not required to conduct an analysis of material in its possession for the purposes of communication to persons and agencies specified in section 34 of the statute, that is, persons and agencies responsible for the enforcement and prosecution of criminal offences under Commonwealth, State and Territory laws. That is an important fact, as we now know precisely what the Commission understood its role to be. It certainly did not understand its role to be that of conducting an analysis of the material in its hands. The importance of that is that a great deal of material has been collected by the Commission and has been dissipated as a consequence of the Commission's imminent winding up.

Secondly, while the question of the Commission's role under section 34 was generally addressed by it, it was not done in the same depth as would have been the case, to quote the words of the letter, `had the Commission gone to finality'. The Commission said that a good deal of the material in its hands was inchoate and, in that form, unsuitable for reference pursuant to section 34. Generally, it said, to be suitable for that purpose such material would need to be enhanced by further investigation and/or cross-examination of witnesses. We know that that further investigation is not to take place, because the Commission is to be wound up and the Government has resisted any further investigation of the material.

Thirdly, it seems clear that because of the terms of the Commission's statute and the Repeal Bill itself, it will be impossible to know in any detailed sense what happened as far as the National Crime Authority is concerned. All we know is what the Commission has said on that question, which was:

However, when it became apparent that the Commission was to be wound up by the Parliament, it consulted the National Crime Authority over materials in its possession that the Authority might require. Those requested by the Authority were provided to it.

We know, of course, that the Authority is a body of a limited charter. It can only investigate certain kinds of offences. It cannot investigate other offences. We have not the least idea of what kind of consultation took place between the Commission and the Authority. However, we do know that in the Commission's view much of the material was in an inchoate form; that is, it was not properly ordered. That would have made the task of anyone looking at it from the point of view of law enforcement more difficult. It needed to be ordered. It needed to be further investigated so that any question of criminal activity could be followed up.

I repeat, so that there can be no doubt on the subject, that I am most certainly not referring to Mr Justice Murphy. I am, and have at all times been, referring to other parties. This very Government contemplated that there might be evidence of criminal actions by third parties and that was the reason why section 34 was put in the Act to regulate the Commission's work.

Fourthly, the material sent to the Parliament will not include all of the material that came into the hands of the Commission. In particular, material provided to the Commission on a confidential basis-from whom or from what organisations we are not allowed to know, and I say that without being critical of the Commission; it is the position and I accept it entirely-has apparently been returned to source. It is impossible to say what kind of reference to this kind of material will be contained in the records of the Commission which are to be sent to Parliament.

Fifthly, effectively the body of material gathered into the hands of the Commission from various sources will be dissipated. Some of the material-counsels' personal working notes-has been destroyed. It will cease to exist as a concentrated body of material in the hands of one single investigate body. Anyone who has had anything to do with the conduct of investigations-I believe that I am the only person in this House who has; I spent a good part of two years investigating failed companies-would know that it is important, once the material is gathered together, that one person or one group of people look at it because that person or group of people can get a concentrated knowledge of it and an understanding of it which will be lost when the material is sent back to its various sources.

I wish again to make it plain that nothing which is said here or elsewhere is intended as a criticism of the Commission or of those assisting it. Quite the contrary; they must operate within the constraints of the Commission's statutes and are to be commended for undertaking the difficult task that Parliament gave to them. I say that particularly in reference to the three retired judges who took on a most onerous job out of a sense of public service and public spirit. But the necessary consequence of the Government's intentions and the repeal Bill in its present form is that a detailed and exhaustive investigation of the whole of the material that came to the Commission for the purpose of determining whether further information exists which may be evidence of the commission of criminal offences or which may lead to the uncovering of criminal offences or evidence relating to them will never take place. It was and it remains our view that it is in the public interest that such an examination take place. We are not here talking about Mr Justice Murphy. We are not here talking about anything which bears on Mr Justice Murphy's reputation. We are not here talking about allegations concerning Mr Justice Murphy becoming public. What we are talking about is one simple proposition. That material was gathered from many sources. From what the Commission has told us we know that some material was provided to it in confidence and on the basis that it would be returned, and that that material has been returned. We know the files have been returned to their various sources. It is a simple question of public interest. If there was evidence on further investigation of criminality, that criminality should be uncovered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—In that event, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will sit down, since I do not think I have anything further to say on the subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Committee, but I welcome--
—Unless my colleague is provocative.

—It is unusual for me to be provocative. I welcome the fact that the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), leading for the Opposition, said that he in no way intends that there should be any suggestion of pursuit of matters that in any way might affect His Honour Mr Justice Murphy. I am grateful for that because it has taken some time to get that position clear in the debates that have preceded this one. A number of accusations were made, not necessarily by the honourable member for North Sydney but certainly by others. The point I want to make is that this is a parliamentary commission. The honourable member made reference to the fact that the Government had not sought to do this or that with the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. It never has. It is a parliamentary commission and the Commission does not report to the Government; it reports to the Presiding Officers. I think that point ought to be made very clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission, in its report to the Presiding Officers, made it clear that it really could not carry on its functions because of the dreadful illness of the judge. It made the point:
No evidence has been heard and therefore nothing decided.
That is a quote from the report given to the Presiding Officers. In that report the Commission said further:
To continue the hearings if the judge was too ill to take place-
it is known that he is--
would be contrary to established practice and to natural justice.

I want to place that on record. That is known to the Opposition and it was known to it at the time. This further matter was known to the Opposition. The Commission talked about the previous report given, and it went on to say:

I should add that senior counsel assisting the Commission is of the view that in the present circumstances little would be gained from pursuing the costly exercise of continuing investigatory and related work.
That happens to be a statement which I received on 1 September. The letter is undated, but it was sent to the Presiding Officers by the presiding member. I think it was sent in August.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the basis that the Commission was winding down.

—Yes, but it made the point that senior counsel was of the view that little would be gained. The other point that the honourable gentleman might address his mind to is that if there is any information or evidence it is still available, in that if it was with a person it might have been returned to that person, or if persons have information themselves they can certainly give evidence about it. The point he emphasised, quite fairly, is that a good deal of the material is inchoate and in that form is unsuitable for reference under section 34. So what particular piece of material are we talking about or what statement requires further analysis that cannot be obtained? It is not confined or removed from further analysis elsewhere. In this case the issue basically was to prevent allegations, for which there was no supporting evidence, being actually published. I am sure they will be, and it will be a dreadful thing when they are because the unfortunate judge will not be able to answer them. That will be the position-that it does sleight his character and affect his family. That is the point.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986 will prevent steps that persons who have supplied any information or documents wish to take to supply information to law enforcement agencies. The Commission has already passed material to the National Crime Authority. There is no question of anything not being made available which is going to be pursued, not in respect of the judge but in respect of, as the honourable member for North Sydney says, other matters. That can still be pursued. There is no problem there at all. I understand that the Commission consulted the National Crime Authority over the materials in its possession and that those requested by the National Crime Authority were provided to it. We do not need to belabour the point. The honourable gentleman took the course of having discussions or correspondence with the Secretary of the Commission, who has replied to him, but I think it is fair that if senior counsel made the point that there was no purpose really in pursuing the exercise--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was in relation to the Commission's inquiry into Mr Justice Murphy, wasn't it?

—I do not know that it was. I do not think so. The point is made that senior counsel is of the view that little would be gained by continuing investigatory and related work. I am sure that if there had been some suggestion of a criminal offence pursuant to section 34, senior counsel would have pursued that. He would have referred the matter and would not have just abandoned it. Furthermore, I notice senior counsel destroyed his notes on this matter. I am aware of that because of correspondence that the honourable member for North Sydney has received. There is no suggestion of the Government giving any directions or of being involved in this matter. No one has suggested that senior counsel would have so acted without having given consideration to the obligations under section 34.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand those who say that this is an unusual matter. Indeed, it is unique; it has never happened before in the sense that we have had a commission that could not commence its work. If there is any evidence-I emphasise this-it will be made available. In fact, if there is any evidence, it has been made available. Much of the material is inchoate and not of any value.

Reference was made in a previous debate to His Honour being some sort of KGB agent. That suggestion came from the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), who suggested that there was a security risk. I am aware from another source that there were a fair number of lunatics wandering around making all sorts of statements, and that would be one of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bruce? I would agree with that.
—No. I was talking about the statements. The Commission was able to sift the matter and that was its description of the submission. It considered that it came from someone who was not well balanced.
—Where did that come from?
—It was mentioned in an earlier debate by the honourable member for Bruce. He wanted to know why we were winding up the Commission when there might be some sort of problem.
—Where did the Commission's view come from? I have not seen that.
—It did not come from the Commission. It came from somebody who was given this bit of material and who took it to the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: There are plenty of people who want to continue to produce all sorts of sensational accusations that have no foundation. We must be careful about that. However, if there is any evidence at all, it will be dealt with. We are faced with an issue that is not related at all to His Honour, and the honourable member for North Sydney acknowledges that. I am sure that senior counsel would have pursued any matter that he thought worthwhile. He would not have destroyed his notes simply because he thought that he should destroy them. If there was any material available, it was referred to the National Crime Authority. I think that that ought to be the end of the matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the sixth report for 1986 of the Committee relating to the refurbishment of Taxation Building, Brisbane, and seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I shall not delay the House unduly. I wish briefly to inform the House that the Public Works Committee has addressed this parliamentary referral on the taxation building and has come to the conclusion that the Brisbane taxation building falls short of contemporary accepted standards for office accommodation.
