Furthermore, an analysis of comparative costs between a number of options which would rectify the standard of present accommodation indicates the refurbishment option to be the most effective. The disruption to work occurring during the period necessary to complete this project will be minimised by relocating staff whose floors are being refurbished to the adjoining Statistics House. SPEECH.PARA: The extent of the proposed refurbishment is necessary and appears generally to meet Taxation Office and Commonwealth office accommodation guidelines. DEBATE.TITLE: ACCOMMODATION AND WAREHOUSING FOR 51ST SUPPLY BATTALION, GUILDFORD, WA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the seventh report for 1986 of the Committee relating to the construction of working accommodation and warehousing for the 51st Supply Battalion, Guildford, Western Australia, and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In addressing this referral, the Committee concluded that there would be advantages in terms of operational efficiency and control if the headquarters elements of the 51st Supply Battalion were to be located with the major warehouse complex and the control and purchase offices. It was evident to the Committee that existing buildings at Midland are old and inadequate and that the site is unsuited for contemporary warehousing activities.

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth, State and local government authorities, in the view of the Committee, should hold urgent discussions aimed at ensuring that the preservation of the railway spur line easement is not compromised in the light of adjacent land use development planning, thereby denying the facility access to requirements in future. The extent of the proposed work can be justified on the ground of the nature of the Midland facility, which needs to be replaced, and the advantages identified in locating headquarters, administration and stores functions in the one complex.

It is considered by the Committee that the Guildford site is suitable for the type of development that is proposed and provides sufficient space for expansion. The limit of cost estimate for the project is $8.2m at April 1986 prices. The Committee therefore recommends to the House construction of the work in this reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee entitled `Patronage, Power and the Muse: Inquiry into Commonwealth Assistance to the Arts', together with copies of the minutes of proceedings, the transcript of evidence and submissions authorised for publication.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I take pleasure in presenting this report to the House. The report is the outcome of one of the largest and most complex inquiries undertaken by the Expenditure Committee during the seven years that I have been a member of it. Some sections of the report cover ground that had previously been traversed in a controversial Industries Assistance Commission report which was issued in 1976. I found it interesting that the first of 133 submissions to the present inquiry claimed that the IAC report had been rejected because of `the insensitive way in which it was written.' I hope that my well-known sensitivity shines through in this report, but I suspect that some parts of the arts community will disagree with my conclusions.

SPEECH.PARA: Like the IAC, the Expenditure Committee believes that subsidy to the arts is intended to benefit the public at large and not only artists. This goes to the heart of a long-standing dispute between two broad philosophies on arts assistance. There are those who believe that a limited range of so-called high arts is good in itself and that these arts should be assisted because of their merit. Others argue that a wide range of cultural activities can benefit different people at different times. That means anything from opera to rock music or from Picasso to Patrick Cook.

The Committee adopted the second approach. It did not reject the value of the so-called high arts but it did not accept either that they are the sole repositories of artistic merit. Following this line, the chapter of the report dealing with the performing arts flagships-the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and their orchestras-is balanced by a chapter on contemporary music, the most widespread and influential art form in modern Australia.

Much of the report is concerned with the Australia Council which is the agency responsible for direct grants to the arts. The Committee acknowledges that the Council has some important achievements to its credit. The growth in the art forms the Council subsidises has been massive over the 15 years of its existence. Nevertheless, the Committee also has some important criticisms of the Council. These could be summarised as resulting from two causes. The Committee believes that the Council has been partly captured by its clients and that it has not adapted enough to changing circumstances. In particular, the Committee believes that the Council has not adapted to the growth in the arts industry and the massive increase in State and local government arts support.

A large part of the report considers two sacred cows of Australian art assistance: The arm's length principle and peer review. Under the arm's length principle the Australia Council has been largely free of government control of both its policies and its administration of grants. The Committee accepts that a high degree of independence is desirable in grants administration. However, we do not accept that the Council should establish policy independent of government. The peer review principle has been taken to mean that arts grants should be under the control of, in the Council's words, `artists and their colleagues'. Apart from the difficulty of deciding which artists or colleagues should make the decisions-a difficulty that has led to much contention among artistic factions-this principle ignores the public interest in the direction of public funds. In reviewing this issue the Committee was fascinated to find that artists could give politicians some pointers on factional in-fighting.

The Committee has recommended changes to the structure and operations of the Australia Council which we believe will correct these problems. We have recommended that the relationship between the Council and the Government be clearly defined to establish that the Council is independent in deciding between applicants for grants, but that the Government controls policy. We believe that the Government should explicitly control the Council's priorities through approval of the allocation of funding to each of the Council's programs of support.

We recommend also that the Minister should have the power to direct the Council on matters other than particular grants. The Committee acknowledges the value of review by peers in an area of technical and subjective judgments such as decisions on arts grants. We do not accept, however, that the present Council structure represents true peer review. The small number of so-called peers on the Council and its boards, compared to the diversity of art forms and issues they deal with, work against true peer review.

The Theatre Board, for example, deals with the Australian Ballet, large State theatres and a host of small locally based theatrical companies in such diverse fields as community theatre, children's theatre, dance and puppetry. The Committee does not believe that seven members of the Theatre Board can properly be called the peers of such a diverse range of interests. Even if they could, we believe that the public interest should also be represented in these decisions. We have recommended a number of measures to resolve these difficulties.

First, the Committee has proposed that grants to major organisations be grouped into one program as these companies have more in common with each other than they have with small arts organisations. Secondly, we recommend that responsibility for decisions between applicants for most small grants be decentralised to State and local government or to selected locally based organisations. Decisions on how much to allocate to each program of assistance and the processing of applications and payments would remain with the Council and the Commonwealth department.

The Committee sees these two measures as enhancing peer review by grouping like programs and by diversifying decision-making on artistic merit. We have also recommended that the broad public interest be more strongly represented on the Council and its boards by the appointment of members from outside the arts community. The community believes that these changes should lead to reductions in the numbers and the status of the staff of the Council's art form boards. The savings from this ought to be applied to increasing arts support to cover the cost of decentralising decisions on small grants and to improve the Council's central organisation. I stress that although these changes depart from recent practice they largely represent the intentions of the Whitlam Government when the Council was created. They also address problems which are not unique to Australia but have occurred in arts councils overseas.

The Committee ranged well beyond the affairs of the Australia Council in this inquiry. In particular we were concerned with the lack of co-ordination in cultural policy. Who decides, for example, that there is a correct balance in the allocation of $50m to the arts through the Australia Council; $25m through the Australian Broadcasting Corporation orchestras; more than $100m through tax concessions to film, to name but a few? Cultural spending in Australia is on a much larger scale than it is generally recognised and the Committee believes that there has not been adequate co-ordination of these important programs. We have therefore recommended a stronger co-ordinating role for the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment.

Turning to some specific issues, the Committee took a close and perhaps critical look at the so-called flagships: The opera, the ballet and their orchestras. Honourable members who know my personal views on this may be surprised to hear that I have recognised the value of these institutions to the Australian community. I have no doubt that the opera will be surprised to hear that too. We recommended, however, that the flagships should be accountable for the large public investment they represent. This accountability can be achieved by closer scrutiny from the Australia Council and by a clear recognition that even the biggest arts organisation will be allowed to collapse if it proves unable to manage its affairs. We have recommended that the flagships be funded on a triennial basis which the companies claim would considerably reduce their operating costs. In return we have also recommended that funding for these organisations be frozen in real terms for three years. The report also deals with tax concessions to the arts. The scale of these concessions particularly to film may surprise many people and the Committee recommends tighter control of this method of assistance to the arts.

I have previously spoken to the House on the cultural value of contemporary music-in particular, rock music. In fact, some of my colleagues still talk to me about my speech asking for a fair go for rock and roll. In this report the Committee argues that contemporary popular music is both an art form and an industry that has been unjustifiably neglected. This is the art form that reaches the widest segment of the Australian community. It is a labour-intensive industry with significant potential for export earnings and for import substitution. Australia, as an English-speaking, industrialised nation, has natural advantages in the contemporary music industry and Australian contemporary musicians have already registered important international achievements. The Committee has recommended a package of simple assistance measures, most of which would be self-funding, which could be of great benefit to this art form. I particularly commend this section of the report to the House.

I have already mentioned that this report results from one of the largest and most complex inquiries undertaken by the Expenditure Committee. It could not have been concluded without the competent and dedicated assistance of the Committee secretariat and the members of the Committee. I thank the members of the Committee for the time and effort they gave to the Committee in travelling around Australia to talk to various interest art organisations and to take evidence. The members of the Committee secretariat were also of great assistance. Mr Peter Ratus of the secretariat very efficiently handled much of the complicated organising of public hearings and inspections. Miss Penny Maher coped admirably with many urgent requests for typing. I would also like to commend Mr Andrew Crocker of the Information Systems Office of the Department of the House of Representatives who provided a computer database for the Committee's evidence and supervised the typesetting of the body of the report.

I would particularly like to commend the work of Mrs Sue Harlow who was Secretary to the Committee until a few weeks ago and of Mr Peter Hamburger, an adviser to the Committee, who was of great assistance in the research and drafting of the report. Mrs Harlow served the Expenditure Committee exceptionally well in her three years as Secretary to the Committee. During my three years as Chairman of the Committee I have greatly appreciated her intellectual ability and her capacity to enthuse both the members and the staff. Reports such as this are testimony to her skills. On behalf of the Committee I would like to wish her well in her new job. I am sure we will all miss her as time goes on. I suppose I should not have said `as time goes on' as she is sitting here in the gallery.

This inquiry dealt with some very complex and controversial issues. The Committee acknowledges in the report that there is little likelihood of achieving consensus on many of them. I believe however that this report will give some focus and direction to the continuing debate and that the Committee's specific recommendations have real merit. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I would like to make just a few additional comments in supporting the tabling of the report from the Standing Committee on Expenditure. First, the chairman of the sub-committee, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), who has just spoken, is to be congratulated on steering this long and complex inquiry through to a conclusion. I also add my support to his comments about the Secretary and the Committee adviser and express warm appreciation to both of them for the excellence of their organisation, research and drafting for the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The report was difficult to prepare because, as it shows, there are widely different views in the community about the nature of the arts, the role of government in arts funding, the extent of government funding and the strategy for the arts. The Committee concluded that there are substantial public benefits from the arts and that these justify substantial government support. Few Australians would disagree that the arts enhance our national identity, influence the way in which we perceive our world, entertain us and help us to relax, increase our understanding of the past and contribute to preparing us for the future. They inspire and analyse and offer both vision and criticism. The arts are an essential enriching aspect of human life. For the same reasons as government is concerned for security, justice and peace, it must also support the arts.

Government support for the arts in Australia has increased substantially since the beginning of the 1970s. The Committee has not made an independent study of arts funding levels, but the report quotes a study commissioned by the Australia Council which estimated that government cultural expenditure, which is a broader concept than arts expenditure, totalled $775m in 1981-82. However, this includes expenditure on the Australian Broadcasting Commission, as it then was, and many other activities which could not be classified primarily as the arts. About half of that expenditure was by the Commonwealth and about a quarter by each of the State and local governments. State expenditure has increased significantly in the last decade as arts centres have been built in several cities.

Comparisons among countries of expenditure on the arts, which I emphasise is only part of cultural spending, is difficult because of the variety of forms of support. However, on the basis of the inadequate data available to the Committee, it seems that grants to the arts in Australia are well below those in comparable countries. About $9 a head is estimated to be spent on the arts in Australia. This compares with about $14 a head in Britain, $38 a head in West Germany, $43 a head in Austria, $54 a head in France and about $60 in Sweden. These figures come from an article in the Economist of 6 September. If the comparison is valid, it suggests that Australia has considerably further to go if support for the arts here is to be comparable with that overseas.

The Committee's report also raises the issue of the balance in expenditure on the various arts in Australia. In particular, the Committee questions the use of tax expenditures as a means of support. Tax expenditures hide the extent of subsidy being provided, so one of the recommendations proposes more detailed analysis and tighter control of the cost of these concessions. The tax concession for film was estimated to cost $95m in revenue forgone in 1984-85. This is more than double the total grant to the Australia Council, which supports music, theatre, literature, crafts and Aboriginal and community arts. This is severely unbalanced. Film would be more appropriately supported by grants, but at a lower level, allowing increased allocations to all the other arts. Increased support for the arts in total would be justified, but whether or not that occurs, the proportion going to film should be reduced and the proportion to all the other art forms increased.

The honourable member for Grayndler has summarised the main recommendations of the report. I would like to underline the importance of the preparation of a national cultural strategy. The proposals about relations between government and the Arts Council are also important. Those proposals would enable the Government to suggest broad guidelines to the Council while retaining the principle of arms length funding so that the Council continues to make decisions about individual grants. The suggestions about training and other modest support for contemporary music are also important.

I hope that the report will contribute to further discussion within the arts community and that the Government will consider it seriously. I look forward to hearing the responses of both the arts community and the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, on the tabling of this report I would like to thank all members of the sub-committee and the Committee secretariat for the effort that they put into it. The sub-committee Chairman, the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), has commented on the complexity of the task. The sub-committee took evidence at formal hearings from almost 100 witnesses and collected more than 4,500 pages of written evidence in the form of submissions, exhibits and transcripts of oral evidence. Sifting through this mountain of paper was a daunting task. I am sure that honourable members will appreciate the work that went into this inquiry when they read the report. It is fitting that a Labor government be in office to receive this report, as it was the Whitlam Labor Government more than a decade ago which began in earnest the task of financially assisting the arts after years of neglect by previous conservative governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Before dealing with the enormous body of evidence on arts funding, the Committee had to consider the fundamental questions of the basis for the funding of the arts in the first place. The Committee's recommendations were based on a broad definition of the arts, which includes not only the more traditional areas of music, opera, ballet and the like, but also contemporary music and more popular and folk culture. This is in accord with the lack of a clear consensus on the meaning of the term `the arts'. The Committee concluded that the basis for arts funding was the ability to maximise the benefits to the community of what Gough Whitlam called `the writing and humanising force' of the arts. Suggestions that Commonwealth assistance is a right of the arts because of some elitist merit were rejected, as was the view that arts assistance should take the form of welfare for artists.

I take the opportunity to draw attention to a few aspects of the report. Most public comment on arts assistance focuses on the $50m allocated to the Australia Council. Important though this is, it represents only about 10 per cent of total Commonwealth cultural spending. As this report shows, other Commonwealth cultural spending-on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, on education and in several other areas-dwarfs the allocation to the Australia Council. Total government cultural spending in Australia has been estimated to exceed $775m. More than half of this is contributed by State and local government.

The Commonwealth contribution to culture has grown enormously under successive governments since the early 1970s. In the Committee's opinion, the arrangements for managing this large public investment have not kept pace with the growth. The Committee found that there is remarkably little co-ordination of the many programs that account for this large figure and we have therefore recommended a significant strengthening of co-ordination in the area of cultural policy. I see this as one of the most important features of the report. The report also commends three small cultural assistance agencies-the International Cultural Corporation of Australia, Artbank and the Public Lending Right Committee. Although these are not large organisations, the Committee was impressed by the high quality of their performance.

I have mentioned that the Committee took evidence from a large number of witnesses. I was impressed by the dedication to the arts of witnesses at those hearings I attended. Finally, perhaps I should comment on the title of the report. The Committee found that much of the contention in the arts assistance field stems from disputes over power-the question of who decides the direction of public patronage. The interaction between this question of power and the creative impulse-which we have loosely termed the muse-was fascinating to observe. Again, I thank those involved in the inquiry, especially the sub-committee Chairman, the honourable member for Grayndler, whose place in Australia's cultural history is no doubt now secure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch Delegation to the Thirty-first Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference, held in Saskatchewan in October 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Thirty-first Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference was held in Saskatchewan, Canada, from 1 to 11 October 1985. A total of 165 delegates, 33 secretaries, three official observers, 36 unofficial observers, together with 20 members of the executive committee, attended the Conference. Ninety-six branches, including States branches, were represented, of which 47 were national or Federal branches.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth of Australia Branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association sent a delegation of six to the Conference, together with an officer of this House to accompany the delegation as its secretary and to serve on the Conference secretariat. The delegation comprised: Myself as leader; Senator Archer as deputy leader; the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite); the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear); the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher); the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott), and Mr I. C. Cochran, Senior Parliamentary Officer, Table Office, House of Representatives, as secretary.

The Canadian provincial branch of Saskatchewan hosted the Conference under the leadership of its President, the Hon. Herb J. Swan, Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of Saskatchewan and President of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. The Saskatchewan Branch was the first non-national branch of the CPA to host a conference. Saskatchewan is the central Canadian province and it has a relatively small population of 1,029,000. Its largest cities are Regina, where the Conference was opened, and Saskatoon, where most of the Conference was held. Each city has a population of approximately 173,000. Conference tours of Saskatchewan were conducted over three days-on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, 4, 5 and 6 October. Delegates and their spouses were divided into four groups for that purpose and the four different tours covered most of the settled parts of the province.

No delegate would have left Saskatchewan without clear memories of the size of the province and the enterprise of the people in withstanding the rigours of the climate and in turning virgin prairie of marginal agricultural value into one of the great granaries of the world. No effort was spared throughout the tours to make delegates feel welcome and `at home' and to provide a detailed briefing on the districts, towns, farms, national parks and other points of interest visited.

Each of the four tours terminated in Saskatoon, where all delegates were accommodated in the recently completed Ramada Renaissance Hotel. As this hotel has convention facilities in which both plenary and panel sessions could take place, it was possible for the Conference to be held under the one roof and without the need for delegates to be transported regularly from one point to another.

As leader of the Commonwealth delegation, I was the opening speaker at the first plenary session. The topic of my speech was `The United Nations: How can the United Nations be strengthened to enable it to preserve peace and promote disarmament'. I argued that nuclear disarmament should not remain as the principal preserve of the United States and the Soviet Union. I said that all states must participate in arms reduction talks through the United Nations so that all nations could have confidence in future peace arrangements. The speech was well received and was complimented.

My deputy, Senator Archer, served as a panellist on the topic `Agricultural prices, production and distribution' and summarised the discussion on behalf of the participants at its conclusion. All members of the Commonwealth delegation participated conspicuously in the plenary and panel sessions and, with Australian State delegates, ensured that a worthwhile and significant Australian contribution was made to the Conference. The briefs provided to our delegates by our Government were of a very high standard and, indeed, members of the Canadian delegation asked for copies of the briefs for the information of their branch secretariat.

A former Premier of South Australia, the Hon. David Tonkin, was elected as Secretary-General designate to assume duty on the retirement of Sir Robin Vanderfelt this year. The Rt Hon. Bernard Weatherill, MP, Speaker of the House of Commons, United Kingdom, was elected President of the Association for 1985-86, to succeed the Hon. Herb J. Swan, MLA.

Seven new regional representatives were elected. Included in those was the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), the Government Whip in this House and a member of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch. He was elected a regional representative for the Australia and Pacific region. The election of Mr Humphreys follows changes in the regional representation arrangements agreed to at the 1983 Conference in Nairobi. This Branch is now represented on the executive committee during the years leading up to and during 1988, when the Australian branches will host the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in Australia's bicentennial year. Now that agreement has been reached among the branches in the region, the Papua New Guinea, New Zealand, Fiji and Commonwealth of Australia branches will be regularly represented on the executive committee.

When delegates gathered in the capital of Regina, they were told that Saskatchewan people were renowned for their western hospitality. Speaker Swan and the Saskatchewan Branch interspersed throughout the Conference a program of hospitality and entertainment that gave all delegates first-hand experience of the genuineness of that claim. Delegates were, therefore, able to share in Saskatchewan's heritage year and enjoy performances by various groups representing the province's rich cultural background. An interesting and complementary program was also arranged for the accompanying spouses. During the Conference at the Ramada Hotel in Saskatoon, the Commonwealth of Australia delegation hosted a very successful and well-attended reception for delegates from the Australian States and the Northern Territory, the Pacific islands and the South East Asian branches.

I wish to record my appreciation of and admiration for the work of the members and officers of the Saskatchewan Branch, who contributed so much to the success of the Thirty-first Conference. I pay special appreciation to Duane Weiman, MLA, and Bob Myers, MLA, both of the Saskatchewan Legislative Assembly, and their spouses, for their many kindnesses and their hospitality. Great credit is due to the Government, legislature and people of Saskatchewan for their efforts, extending over many months, to make the Conference such an outstanding success. The contribution made by Mr Ian Cochran, the Secretary of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch delegation, was outstanding. His conscientiousness, devotion to duty and attention to administrative detail ensured that the requirements of all delegates and their spouses were adequately catered for.

In summary, the Conference was most successful. Discussion of agenda items was informative, educational and useful, and provided an excellent opportunity for delegates from a great number of Commonwealth countries to exchange views on many subjects of mutual interest. It was a privilege for me to lead the Commonwealth of Australia Branch delegation. I thank the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for appointing me leader of the delegation. I wish to thank co-delegates for the support, friendship and assistance they provided to me and my wife, Maria, throughout our stay in Saskatchewan, Canada.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I add my commendations to those expressed by the leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). I pay a special tribute to him for leading the delegation and also leading the debate about the United Nations, which was, incidentally, made at the time of the fortieth anniversary of the United Nations. I had the pleasure, later, of attending the United Nations when some of the speeches were made. I can attest to the fact that the comments made in leading the debate at the first session were well received and well commented upon.

SPEECH.PARA: I go a little further than did the honourable member for Herbert in my commendations and include, in particular, the President of the proceedings, the Hon. Herb Swan. Our tour visited his farm at Beechey, where we were shown how the great wheat industry works in that area. Surprisingly, except for the chill from the prairies in the north, it could have been an ordinary Australian wheat farm. I pay tribute to Mr Swan for his hospitality on that occasion. I also pay tribute to Mr and Mrs Swan for, on the day of our departure, making themselves available at the airport to farewell every outgoing delegate who travelled by aircraft that day. I met them five hours after their vigil had started. I understand that they were to be there for a further seven or eight hours. I thought that that was a great gesture. I pay tribute to Mr Swan for his sincerity in inaugurating, during the Conference, a prayer breakfast for those delegates who wished to enjoy the spiritual sense of togetherness that the occasion afforded, in addition to the sense of togetherness enjoyed as members of the Commonwealth. We had people from every part of the Commonwealth gathering together in the early hours of the morning to share in that prayer breakfast. I pay great tribute to the Hon. Herb Swan and his wife. I would also like to mention that an Australian, Dr David Tonkin, is now the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. The position was contested but the nomination committee came out quite overwhelmingly for him. I believe he is an appropriate appointment in view of the fact that Australia will host the CPA conference in 1988 as part of its bicentennial celebrations. Of course, he has much to do to live up to the efforts of the previous Secretary-General and the Government Whip's position as regional representative.

I found it a great experience to visit Canada and to investigate Saskatchewan and its rural basis, particularly in regard to wheat. Those who believe that Australian wheat farmers are the only farmers who are badly off because of their efficiency in producing for an oversupplied market are mistaken. We could see how the wheat farmers in Canada are trying to compete on a world market which pays very low prices, and where there are large stocks of wheat. Canada, the host country, is very similar to Australia. It is a resource rich country in many respects, not only in rural areas and we had an empathy with them in many of these areas. Some of the subjects which were of interest during the conference were trade and development assistance, the special obligation that membership of the Commonwealth implies, and the debt crisis and international currency fluctuations and what can be done to stabilise the global economy.

When we look at the trade and resources of Canada and its debt structure we see that Australia and Canada have much in common. A lot was contributed in those sessions that was of mutual benefit to all. There were the sceptics who thought, that, in the aftermath of the discussions earlier this year about sanctions being applied to South Africa, the CPA meeting in Saskatchewan might have been the last one. I am pleased that that rift did not eventuate and that, far from what the sceptics thought, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association can make contributions. It is interesting to note that the special trip made by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, together with a parliamentary delegation to the United States, was firmly supported by Canada in relation to the wheat subsidy. I would like to think that in some way our contribution at the CPA meeting helped in that regard.

As trade is my particular interest, I mention that in dealing with trade the Commonwealth nations can help each other. In fact, at one stage, when we were asking how we could help the developing nations within the Commonwealth, a free trade area within the Commonwealth was suggested. That is a dream and perhaps nothing will eventuate from it, without looking at the nuts and bolts, but that was the feeling of the Conference. Only a few weeks ago five of the nations at the CPA Conference in Saskatchewan came together with others at Cairns in a meeting, which resulted in the Cairns Declaration of the 14 fair traders. Those five countries were Canada, Malaysia, New Zealand, Fiji and Australia. I must compliment the Ministers responsible for bringing together those 14 countries in a common purpose to try to put unsubsidised products-22 per cent of the world market in agricultural products-on to those world markets. I am sure that the Commonwealth played a large part in that.

Unfortunately, the very positive thrust that was achieved at the Cairns conference-I think it was more positive than that other conference we hear quite a lot about, which resulted in the accord from the Swiss-Columbian draft, which I understand was a lot weaker than the result they were seeking in that area-has been watered down a lot. Perhaps if Canada had clung a little closer to the Commonwealth in that regard the discussions now going on in Uruguay might have been more powerful as a result. It should have taken the high ground-I will not say the pure ground-and accepted nothing less. I think we and Canada have compromised that Cairns accord to some extent.

I believe that the Thirty-first Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference did achieve its aim to discuss matters and spread good will. It is one of the very positive aspects of the CPA. Anybody who goes to a meeting will realise that the good will is spread across all colours, all races, all climates, all sections of the globe, and that the Commonwealth has a very important role. I believe that if we can talk frankly about our trade, our debt structuring, sanctions and so on, we can increase our own performance in the world and certainly we can have closer ties with those countries. I compliment the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who led the delegation, Allan Rocher and the other members who have been mentioned. The trip was a great eye opener and it was something that my wife and I will remember for a long time.
