SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Repeal Bill seeks to dismiss the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. I indicate that the Opposition is opposed to that measure. The Council was set up in 1976 as an act of faith of the Fraser government. It was felt that if federalism was to play its full role in Australia a body must be put in place whereby the States could meet with the Federal and local governments to discuss the workings of federalism. There is a model for this in America which has the same name and it has had some success over the years. The Fraser Government believed that the establishment of this Council would do much to improve inter-government co-operation, and its purpose was to inquire into, keep under consideration and review matters relating to inter-government co-operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Council consists of 24 members-three from the Commonwealth Government, two from the Commonwealth Opposition, one parliamentary member, one non-parliamentary member from each State and the Northern Territory, five citizens appointed by the Governor-General, and one observer representing the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly-these days that might be difficult. The secretariat for this function was established in Hobart, and it has a permanent staff of 12 and a current budget of $556,000. This funding is divided into 45 per cent from the Federal Government, 45 per cent from the State governments collectively, and 10 per cent from the Australian Council of Local Government Associations.

The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations has worked hard at performing its role in applying itself to the areas in which it was given authority. I think there would not be one member of the House who did not see a duplication of services between the Federal, State and local governments, and I shall quickly mention health services. In Brisbane a person can receive medical attention for immunisation, for example, from either a Federal department, a State department or the Brisbane City Council-all within the space of one mile. I do not think there would be one taxpayer in Australia who could see a justifiable reason for having those three duplicated services. That was but one area in which the Council ought to have looked at rationalising a service. But from the beginning it was evident that the States would not be co-operative in this area. States have regarded local government as their preserve, and quite rightly, because under the Constitution that is the case.

The power vested in the Minister under the local government Act gives him complete and almost dictatorial powers in the way in which he can intervene in the affairs of a local government. As a consequence, the Council has not really been able to show its benefits. Indeed, during the Council's first three years of operation, the Queensland State Government failed to send a representative to Council meetings. Despite this, the Council has produced what I would regard as a number of major improvements in the area of intergovernment relations. I will briefly outline these. The infrastructure forum in 1985 recommended that something be done to look at the respective roles of the three spheres of government in the provision of infrastructure. It said that this would show how governments could co-operate better in the building and maintenance of roads, bridges, hospitals, libraries and community centres. All of those areas have a multi-government input. On top of that, the Environmental Protection Agency made overtures to the ACIR on three or four occasions to compile an intergovernment study. Once again, it is hard to define the role of the Federal Government in environment matters, State governments in environment matters and also the local government bodies which have their particular interest in environmental aspects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking to me?

—I am pleased to see that the Minister is present. I thought I would make it interesting for him. Because of that, the ACIR was a body which had a unique opportunity to be able to study the relationships between governments in relation to the environment. While the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) is present, I mention that the Australian Heritage Commission was urged, in conjunction with ACIR, to study the advantages to local government authorities of the Heritage Commission and their involvement with it. The preservation of buildings and the like do impact on local government.
—I am stunned. There is Liberal interest in the environment.
—I am talking about the ACIR.
—ACIR?
—The honourable member will address the Chair.
—I am sorry. There is a difficulty, Mr Deputy Speaker, when Ministers are not too sure what they are talking about. I was talking about the ACIR.
—I have an ACIR-the Australian Council on International Research.
—That is not quite right, but I suppose the Minister will get it right if he guesses again. Nevertheless--
—Tell us.
—It is the Australian Council for Inter-government Relations.
—Oh, that one.

—That one. It is the one that the Minister could use to make sure that the Federal Government, the State governments and local government get their acts together, in environmental matters, rather than acting against each other, which we see a lot of.
—It would be a pretty good Minister who could do that.
—I thought you all thought that you were. On top of that, the ACIR was invited--
—Do you want some speech notes?
—Order! The honourable member will again address his remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. These Ministers keep providing me with material and asking me questions. Other possibilities to which the ACIR could have addressed itself were education funding-in which all three levels of government have an input-and community assistance. Indeed, one of the most significant results of work by ACIR came about in this area. I refer to the home and community care program-HACC-which came about as a suggestion from an ACIR paper. Four services were put together to provide input from all three levels of government. It came up with an answer which I am quite sure would have saved everybody a lot of money. We believe that, when one looks at the multitude of services that are provided in a whole range of areas across the board-environment, community services, transport, roads, education-in which local input is important, and is felt to be so, this Council is of particular benefit. The Federal input of $250,000 or thereabouts is a rather small amount of money to be cut out when one thinks that, if the Council were made to work appropriately, its programs were seen to be practical and orientated towards problems within local communities, or State, Federal and local government relationships, the money spent on the Council would save millions of dollars in duplicated services and other features of intergovernment relations. Instead, what has happened? In March 1985 the Federal Government moved to review this body. At that stage the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sought, through the States, to review the Council's effort to that point. The terms of reference for the review, as agreed, by the member governments, were as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: - the views of the contributing parties about the value of ACIR's role overall in intergovernmental relations;
- whether the membership, structure and functions of ACIR are appropriate to present needs;
- whether the financial resources made available to ACIR are adequate and are being effectively deployed; and
- assessment of ACIR's research effort to date, its relevance and possible future direction.

Only a few months later, in August 1985, the Prime Minister wrote to the States again, indicating that the Commonwealth now believed that it would be more effective and economical for the review to be undertaken by a small group of Commonwealth officials who would be asked to examine three items: Firstly, whether the continued existence of ACIR could be justified as an effective means of improving intergovernment relations; secondly, whether ACIR, by some reorganisation, could be made capable of a more relevant contribution to the understanding of longer term intergovernment issues; and, thirdly, whether acceptable and viable alternatives to ACIR exist or could be developed.

The Task Group found that ACIR had made a significant contribution. It found that, indeed, it had built up over a 10-year period a substantial library of knowledge which was available for the States and local government. It had built up within its organisation a considerable degree of expertise in an area in which such expertise was sadly lacking. There would not be one person who did not think that intergovernment relations could not be improved. Despite these particular references--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are really making hard work of this, aren't you?

—We will wait to hear from the honourable member. Through the contribution that ACIR has made over the 10-year period, local government has developed. It has been able to approach the Council and put its point of view without being stood over by State Ministers for local government. I think that the discussion papers developed by the Council have made a very significant contribution. The Government set up the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance to review payments to the States and what programs could be set up. That inquiry was based very largely on the workings of ACIR. I have not seen figures outlining the cost of the Self report, but I would be prepared to wager that any difference between that cost and the $250,000 that was contributed by the Federal Government to ACIR would have been fairly marginal. Because of that, the value of ACIR stands up far better than the value of the Self report.

SPEECH.PARA: One might wonder why the Government moved so quickly for the disbandment of ACIR, because it is quite clear that the States have not been behind it. Only Tasmania and the Northern Territory were in favour of its retention; all the other States were not. I wonder why. Quite clearly, it is not in the interests of State governments, and particularly the interests of the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren), who have the total, autocratic power over local government, to have another body which gives people an opportunity to air their views and to know they are getting a fair deal. It is the only body to which the Commonwealth can contribute its views and thoughts and have some accountability for the many millions the Commonwealth now puts into local government. That in itself is worth while.

However, one has to raise the question of where the Government really stands in relation to local government if this body is to be disbanded. In the last two years we have seen the development in the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services in Canberra of a section which has no constitutional power in relation to local government. It has grown in staffing alone from 20 in 1984 to 45 in 1986. That is a substantial growth. Compare the benefits of that section, whose administrative costs must now run into some millions of dollars with the benefits of ACIR at which all levels of government are represented, in which 10 years knowledge is resident and which has built up a library of interests. What benefits will there be if it goes? Yet the Federal Department of Local Government and Administrative Services continues to expand. Where is the benefit in that to the people who are the recipients of Commonwealth money, the recipients of advice and care from State and local governments?

I think that the role played by ACIR can be justified, that it has made a contribution in this period, that it has provided local government with a forum to put its points of view and that it has been able to assess openly and without intimidation the areas in which there has been massive duplication of services. ACIR can be improved in the future. Millions go into it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it operate better in Albury than in Hobart, though?
—The location of the Council is something that ought to be looked at. There is no doubt that there is a question about its location. Council meetings are mainly held away from Hobart.
—Who put it in Hobart and why?
—Order! I ask the honourable member to address his remarks to the Chair.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is all these constant interruptions-
—I appreciate that. It is a very trying time.

—Indeed it is. What has the Government proposed as a result of taking away from local government a valuable research centre? It has offered the Australian Council of Local Government Associations based in Canberra $10,000 to replace the ACIR. Well done. What can we do with that? It is hardly enough to sponsor one program. Am I to assume from that that all wisdom will come from the Federal Department of Local Government and Administrative Services? Am I to assume that it will provide all the programs that have been worked out by the ACIR? Will the Council replace that body and have the co-operation of local government within the States? Is it too much to assume that State Ministers for local government will not interfere more rigidly than they have in the past when meetings were held on common ground?

SPEECH.PARA: What I see is quite clear. State Labor Ministers for local government have had enough. They have come to their mates and said: `This is a major problem to us. There are occasions when local government associations have gone around us to the Federal Government for money. They are now going to the Government through ACIR and getting good ideas on how to rationalise some of the services'. In rationalising some services they are cutting out the State governments and the duplication. They are cutting out the good old pork barrel which so many State governments are particularly adept at using. It seems to be their principal stock-in-trade. That is the real crunch in this situation.

Labor Ministers for local government have thought: `This is not a bad preserve for us. Let us keep it that way. Let us advise the Federal Government, particularly through the Prime Minister, to knock out this body and leave it to us. We will take the money, distribute it and exercise the effort that goes with it. We will leave the Federal Government with a department for local government. It ought to be nothing more than a payment agency because it has no role'. However, instead of that happening, that role is bound to increase. Funding will be used in some way to get around the corner to local government through State governments. Programs will be worked up by the Federal department and the independence that has been preserved for 10 years in this body will be lost. Instead of going down that track we ought to address ourselves to the ACIR's work. There is no doubt that, like everything else, it can be improved. Some of its reports strike me as being overacademic, voluminous and sometimes not altogether oriented towards problems that are of immediate concern. Nevertheless, if the Government were to approach the ACIR problem on the basis of what it can do to improve the organisation, rather than what it can do to knock the ACIR out of the road, we would find that the local government associations of this nation and the people who represent their community at the most local level would be far happier. The Opposition opposes the measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) not make hard work of that? It strikes me that honourable members opposite are caught up in the rhetoric of Fraserism. During those years and even now the Opposition continually calls for the breaking down of the bureaucracy and cuts in government expenditure. The Waste Watch Committee is supposed to be looking at all these sorts of things. This Government is winding up an organisation that is almost universally accepted as irrelevant-I say this without referring to the work of the people concerned-and cutting back expenditure; yet the Opposition is opposing the measure. Why? What did the Opposition do? When it identified the need to examine all the waste and extra resources that go into the duplication of government, its answer was to set up a body to study the matter and to put it in Hobart. At the time there were pressures for the Fraser Government to demonstrate that it was not a centralised Federal government, that it was a government committed to breaking down centralism. Therefore it set up that body and stuck it in Hobart.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Ryan talked about the fact that the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations has produced some wonderful recommendations. However, in the period 1976 to 1983-seven years-the former Government failed to act on any of them. The former Government went down the track of setting up this great body, this extra bureaucracy, and putting it on the path of finding ways to cut expenditure. It oversaw a massive growth in public sector expenditure by the Federal Government, left us with a $9 billion deficit, and honourable members opposite now complain when this Government bites the bullet and says: `This organisation, in spite of all the good work it is doing for local government'-I acknowledge that-`is irrelevant because nobody takes any notice of it and nobody acts on its recommendations'. In the seven years the previous Government had in which to act on its recommendations, it failed to do so. So instead of honourable members opposite honestly accepting a hard but reasonable Government decision, we are back to the usual stuff of opposition for the sake of opposition. I am sorry to say that the honourable member for Ryan made very hard work of putting up his case. All the people out there driving home at the moment in `drive time' who were listening to the honourable member have no doubt changed from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation station to commercial radio, because he did not give them much to listen to.

Let us consider the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. I am one of the members of the Government who have met with the people at ACIR and looked at the work they have done. I recognise that the ACIR has provided a forum for local government. Unfortunately, the Fraser Government failed to act on any of the Council's recommendations. This Government has taken very substantial steps to demonstrate a real commitment to local government. I will turn to that matter in a moment. The purpose of this Bill is to wind up ACIR. I turn to the report of the task force that considered this matter and quote the response of government to the recommendations:

Most State governments and Commonwealth departments were sceptical about ACIR's efforts. It was clear that there are significant areas of the bureaucracy, including areas with major responsibilities for inter-governmental relations that were virtually unaware of the existence of ACIR.

I ask Opposition members at least to come into this chamber and be honest. They have called for the Government to cut back government expenditure. They have called for the Government to undo the massive bureaucracy that they left behind. We have tackled that very substantially. Now, with another very clear example of the winding back of the bureaucracy, Opposition members attempt to present a case against it.

I want to consider a couple of the comments by the honourable member for Ryan, particularly in relation to our commitment to local government. Let us first consider his comment about the establishment of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services under the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren). Councils all around Australia have unanimously welcomed this Government's commitment in two parts-the first the decision to establish a department to administer local government specifically under the Minister and, secondly, the decision taken from the Australian Constitutional Convention to provide specifically for local government in any revamping of the Constitution. Our commitment was welcomed by local government. When the Department was established the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) received hundreds of telegrams from local councils asking him to appoint the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) as the Minister. The Minister has achieved a very significant rapport with local government.

The other point that is worth making in this debate is that this Government-not the Opposition, during the seven years in which it had the chance to act on the ACIR, after having set the thing up in Hobart-instituted the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance and has acted upon the recommendations in its report. We are not in the game of setting up reviews for the sake of reviews and then sticking the reports in a pigeon-hole and taking no action. If we set the bodies up, we look at them and listen to them. The Self report's recommendations have been adopted by this Government. The most significant area one can turn to at the moment for evidence of that is the last Federal Budget, because in it the allocation of funding under general purpose funding to local government has been maintained in real terms.

At a time when this Government has bitten the bullet and reduced the deficit from the $9 billion left by the previous Government to the $3.5 billion it is now, when this Government has set about breaking down the bureaucracy and set about a review and a restructuring of the Australian Public Service, it has also found the means to maintain in real terms general purpose revenue to local government. Out there, among all the councils, it is the bottom line that counts-`How much do we get?'. Over two-thirds of the revenue raised by councils in Australia at the moment comes from grants by Federal and State governments. Honourable members opposite should not mount a nonsensical case for the retention of the ACIR when their Government failed to act on its recommendations and took no notice of it. They should not complain on behalf of local government when they know that this Government is providing in real terms for their continued funding and is demonstrating in the most significant way its commitment to local government, because it is the bottom line that counts.

Some of my colleagues from time to time call me `Mr Local Government' because I have 21 councils in my electorate. Honourable members opposite just happened to pick the wrong issue to take up. Just this week general purpose funding of over $12 million has been announced for the councils in my area. That money helps to provide services directly between State and local government and helps to keep rates at a minimum. We are on about reducing the bureaucracy and about getting value out of the public dollar. We are on about doing what the Opposition talks about. The Opposition talks about cutting down the bureaucracy and in fact it increases it. It talks about cutting back government expenditure and in fact it increases it. It talks about being honest in opposition. I seem to remember the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) saying at one stage: `We will give credit where credit is due'. Honourable members opposite remember it; I remember it. That is where he got the tag `honest John'. Yet, when the Government is putting into effect a very real and significant cut-back in the bureaucracy and in expenditure, Opposition members bring forward drivel as opposition to the Bill. I do not think the case needs any further advocacy. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this debate and delighted that I should have this opportunity to follow the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). The honourable member for Burke has had the audacity to stand here, hands in pockets, as the only Government member, if you please, to provide any sort of defence for the Government's decision to wind up the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. The honourable member for Burke says that Government members call him `Mr Local Government' because he has 21 shire councils in his electorate. There would scarcely be a member on this side of the House with fewer than 21 shire councils. Most honourable members who represent rural electorates such as mine-I have 48-have more than that. Local government happens to matter to rural constituents and to rural members of Federal Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Burke had the audacity to say that out there among all those councils-21 in his case; 48 in mine-it is the bottom line that counts, and so it is. The bottom line of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Repeal Bill is the removal of the only body in Australia that brings local government, State government and Federal government together. What is the commitment of this Government to local government? It is to save a miserable $556,000 by removing the one platform that all levels of government share. We all know that the great problem that Australian parliaments face, whether they are State, Federal or local, is the problem of duplication. It takes no imagination, but probably more imagination than the honourable member for Burke has, to make the simple observation that, if one were to eliminate duplication in one area of State, Federal or local initiative, one would easily save more than the budget of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations.

We have a reputation for being a nation that is overgoverned. Horrifically, we have 821 members of State and Federal parliaments. As a result of this system of wall to wall politicians, we have a focus on State and Federal parliaments and we forget that there is every bit as much wisdom currently being spoken in the chambers of local councils around this nation as there is in State or Federal parliaments. Local government has an essential role, but it is a role that can be effectively fulfilled only if its dovetailing role with State and Federal governments is recognised.

The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations was designed to allow that dovetailing to take place and to remove some of the awful duplication that occurs between the roles of State, Federal and local government. We propose that this Council, if it is ineffective, be looked at and made more effective. We recognise that the Council has not been perfect, we recognise that its location may not have been an ideal one; but, in truth, that is no reason to abolish it. The Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations has an essential role to play and we want to see it remain in place to play that role.

Look at what happens wherever there is any element of duplication. Look at the way that we, as a Federal government, deal with the States. We rarely wholeheartedly hand to them responsibility for any one area. We maintain our control of health issues without handing them over to the States. We maintain our finger in the education pie without handing it over to the States. We retain an interest in inspectorial services without giving the States full responsibility for them. This afternoon in the Parliament the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) advocated our maintaining control over the arts, even if we decentralise them to State and local government.

That is bad enough, but it is even worse when one looks at the duplication that occurs between State and local government. I cannot speak authoritatively for all States in Australia, but in my own State of South Australia local governing bodies cannot even control dogs in their own areas without referral to some State Act. They cannot even maintain their own rubbish dumps without referral to some State Act or some sort of State committee. In South Australia, as in all other States, there are State committees that determine the way local government jumps on building regulations, planning controls and almost any issue that local government has under its de facto control. This duplication costs money. The ACIR is the only body by way of which the three tiers of government can get together, look at the duplication and determine to have a greater level of confidence, one in the other, and to allow each a greater degree of independence.

I find it alarming to cast an eye over Budget papers and notice that, as a proportion of gross domestic product, in the last 10 years the cost of Commonwealth government has grown by 33 per cent, the cost of State government has grown by an astonishing 36 per cent and the cost of local government has grown by a mere 19 per cent. I put it to the people listening that local government has the capacity to deliver services in a way which is far more accountable and efficient than is ever open to State or Commonwealth governments, simply because local government is closer to the people. We need to give local government a higher profile and we can do that only by maintaining a council where State, Federal and local governments can meet.

I am very conscious that the Government's lack of interest in this legislation is such that only one back bencher is to speak on it. It is inappropriate for me to take up a great deal of Opposition time, given the number of Opposition members who want to speak in support of the ACIR and therefore I conclude my remarks by pleading with the Government to reverse this decision. I point to the fact that, without this body, local government has no platform on which it can share its aspirations with Commonwealth and State governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the 830-odd local authorities in this country which provide where it counts most a very basic form of government-local government-to the people. Over many years-since before Federation-the work of government has gone from property-type services, which the rates were then inclined to pay for, to what we today call people services. As a result, local government no longer stands alone as a government throughout Australia; it stands solidly as one of the three tiers of government.

SPEECH.PARA: My interest in defending local government comes, not from representing many shires and councils throughout the electorate, as the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) has suggested-councils he obviously does not consult or listen to; it comes from five years experience as an alderman on a city council before I entered this place. They were five very valuable years of experience-experience which I would recommend to anybody seeking office in either State or Federal government. This defence also comes from working for two years with the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. They were two years in which I met with people from local government who felt, for the first time, that they had a window into the affairs of the other two tiers of government-two tiers of government which they had been made subservient to for so long-and also that they now had an opportunity of participating in guiding their own future. Those people representing local government-one from each of the States-had a dedication which had a profound effect on me, as one of the members on that Council representing the Federal Government.

The honourable member for Burke mentioned just a little while ago the need for honesty. I suggest to him that there is no honesty in his suggestion that the ACIR has failed, that it has not performed and that the task force has found the quality of research material wanting. If he reads the Council's annual report for 1984-85 he will find that there is no honesty in his statement. In 1981-82, in real terms, the ACIR has been allowed to wither at the end of the vine for lack of adequate funds to conduct proper research projects. Thus the aspersion is cast. I suggest to him that if he wants to come into this House and talk about honesty he should look at his own performance on television a couple of weeks ago and his comments in support of the fringe benefits taxation, when he had the audacity to suggest, in what he called honesty, that the fringe benefits tax was designed to destroy a rort being perpetrated by the business people of Australia. It was a deliberate untruth. If he wants to come in here to lecture on honesty, I suggest that he look at his own morals in this connection.

I have found a very wide acceptance of the ACIR in local government. The ACIR is further removed from members of local government than are the personal income tax sharing arrangements, because they are something they deal with directly, but I just remind the House that the ACIR is part of a Federal package, along with personal income tax sharing. The honourable member for Burke takes credit for dispensing personal income tax. The ACIR was part of a renewed recognition of the way in which local government in Australia performs its duties, not only in terms of those property services but also in terms of duties it performs on behalf of the States and the Commonwealth, as has gradually become the situation over a period of years.

I find the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Repeal Bill extraordinary in many ways. The Council's 1984-85 annual report lists the membership as at 31 August 1985. These members, appointed from the Commonwealth, the States, local government and the community, have appointments that expire, for instance, in the case of the Government member, the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), on 12 March 1988. It is extraordinary that these appointments were made to a date in the future, giving the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations the idea that its forward planning would go ahead, when this Bill, on receiving royal assent, will have the effect of destroying the ACIR.

The task force has referred to the quality of the ACIR's work, and I assume that the assessment has been made by those who have not been identified in the publications. It so happens that I was part of the ACIR at the time of the publication of discussion paper No. 15 on the intergovernmental aspects of major resource projects and their infrastructure. An unfortunate feature of the ACIR, which I suggest would have been the subject of some correction in the normal course, was that it had the power to make recommendations but no power to implement them. If the reports have not received the support of the States and the Federal Government, it is not the ACIR which is to blame. Responsibility rests with the Federal and State governments for their neglect and for not allowing the references and recommendations to pass into law. The ability of the ACIR to look into all aspects of government intervention in the infrastructure of Australia is to be lost to us, and there was much that was worth while in the ACIR's role.

The relationship references dealt with revenue sharing for local government, and I have in mind a submission to the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance. I ask: Who made a submission to the Self inquiry? I can tell the House that not one Government member did that. Their disinterest is obvious. I was one who suggested that an appropriate function for the ACIR would be to conduct a review into the relationship between the Commonwealth and local government based on revenue sharing. The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), the shadow Minister, has asked how much of the yearly contribution that is made to the ACIR could have been used to fund the revenue sharing review, the conduct of which was an additional expense to the Commonwealth. I cast no aspersions on Professor Self, whom I met, or on his recommendations, but we know that the recommendations have not been carried forward in full. However, the ACIR was overlooked when it had the opportunity to carry out some work-work which I suggested to the Minister should be undertaken.

The costing arrangement is something which is fairly fundamental. During the time that the ACIR has been left to wither there has been a growth in the local government division within the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. I am not sure of the number of employees in that area but I suggest that it would be 40 to 50. For the year ended 31 August 1985, the Commonwealth's contribution to the work of the ACIR required the involvement of an average of eight public servants at a cost of $252,000. I suggest that the eight public servants would be better employed within the ACIR than within the Department. The States' contribution in every instance would be less than that for the Secretary to the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services which they fund and which has the personnel and the servants to carry out their orders. The important criterion is the amount of money that could be properly applied. We find at page 31 of the ninth annual report of the ACIR that expenditure at 1979-80 constant prices has been allowed to diminish since 1980-81, to the extent where the funding for 1984-85 was only $359,000. That is peanuts.

As I have said, I am here to support the ACIR and local government and I am concerned that the best value for money is obtained. I believe that local government knew that it was getting value for money, in spite of the protestations of the Commonwealth and the State governments. I am sure that those who represent the States appreciate that there is more value attached to the ACIR examining intergovernment relations than there is in any number of ministerial councils that operate between the Commonwealth and the States whose work leads to the double collection of information, something which is entirely unnecessary. Ministerial councils are no substitute for the ACIR. The work that is undertaken by the councils could be performed much better by the ACIR. Over three years the Government has diminished the lot of local government throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many government members are in the chamber now?

—The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) is here, but not one of the other 82 Government members is present. That reflects their interest in these matters. Surely it is important that local government knows where it stands. As I have said, the standing of local government has been diminished. The Self Committee was appointed, but contributions from the Commonwealth go against even the Government's own policy, which was that a 2 per cent increase in real terms would be granted. Local government dipped out on $29m worth of grants up to the time when I became shadow Minister for local government, and last year $60m was dropped from its allocation. It seems that that is to be the basis of personal income tax sharing in future.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the ACIR and the work it has done over a period of years. Unfortunately, it has not been given a fair go and has been left to wither on the vine for the past three years. The repeal of the ACIR following the enactment of the Bill will destroy a mechanism that will not be available to the Commonwealth in any other form. Worse than that, it will destroy the data base, the knowledge and other useful functions that the ACIR has been able to build up. All that will be lost, and that will have a bearing on the good relationships that should exist between the three spheres of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in opposing the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Repeal Bill. The Labor Government has brought about the abolition of the Constitutional Convention which created local government history in the constitutional development of Australia. Under Liberal and National Party governments, local government was involved in the Constitutional Convention. We are now faced with a Bill which proposes the abolition of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the honour to serve on the Council for a period from its commencement and I have had the pleasure again to serve for a short time over recent months. Those who suggest that the ACIR has not been a success have not understood its work and the impact it has had. The protestations of those who claim that it has not been successful are, in some senses, evidence of the very reverse. Those who seek now to abolish the Council are doing so because it came close to the bone in a number of important areas relating to both Federal and State governments.

State governments did not want some of the cosier arrangements that exist under our unbalanced constitutional federal system to be exposed. They protest that the federal system is not working effectively but they are the ones who seek to preserve some of the inadequacies of the system. I believe in a federal system. I believe that a federal system is right for Australia, historically and democratically. It is right historically because we became a nation by the joining of six provinces, each of which was an independent political entity at the time of Federation. Bearing in mind that history, I think it important that we retain the federal system.
But it is more significant that we retain the federal system and improve its workings because of the value of preserving a system of government that involves the distribution of power.

In any country, in any community, it is very important to preserve checks and balances that guarantee the continuance of the democratic system. I believe that our democratic system has, in the federal system, one of those guarantees. As a result of the way the federal system came about we have divided legislative responsibility. At the time of Federation the States gave up some of the powers that had formerly been theirs and conferred them on this Parliament. The checks and balances between Commonwealth and State parliaments are an important part, in the long run, of achieving a far more effective system of government. I know that there are rough edges, difficulties and problems, but those problems are sometimes part of the process of working out what is in the best interest of the community. Furthermore, it ensured that there were parliaments close to the communities of the States. Maybe that is a third reason why a federal system is important. Wherever possible government should be brought, and kept, as close as is possible to the people who are being governed. When the States were provinces they established local government for that very purpose. They wanted local communities to have the opportunity of determining some of the local issues.

One of the things uncovered by inquiries of the ACIR was the fact that in some instances local government was established by State governments because they wanted to shift responsibility that they did not want to handle themselves to local government. They wanted an at arm's length money raising body that would look after roads and collect rubbish, and it was not then the purpose of taking government closer to the people. But over the history of Australia local government has become an important entity in our social fabric. It is often said by State parliamentarians in particular, but sometimes by members of this Parliament, that local governments are creatures of the State governments and therefore that is where they should remain. They can be created and they can be abolished. I do not see constitutional development in that way, for if I did I could rise here and say that this Parliament created the governmental arrangements for the Northern Territory. Having created an assembly for the Northern Territory, this Parliament could technically and legally abolish that governmental arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —And so could the House of Commons for us.

—Indeed, but not so much us, because by the Statute of Westminster the British Parliament and Government committed themselves not to do that for Australia. Interestingly, the States of Australia are not parties to the Statute of Westminster and its related conventions. So technically and legally the Westminster Parliament could abolish the parliaments of the States. It would be a joke to make such a suggestion. It is an absurdity. But what I am saying illustrates that once parliaments start creating representative government in areas such as local government, or as the Commonwealth has done in the Northern Territory, there does come a time when it is politically unrealistic for the creating Parliament to abolish the assembly or legislative body that it has created.

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitutional Convention and the ACIR were giving to local government the opportunity of underpinning the guarantee that local government could not be abolished. But the Australian Labor Party here in Canberra, in concert with State Labor Party governments, is abolishing a body that is providing for local government one of the guarantees-limited though it is-that States will not use their ultimate legislative power to abolish and abandon local government, either on an area by area basis or totally. Having spoken at some length on local government, I believe that this is a backward step as far as local government is concerned and that local government is losing, and will lose as a consequence of the abolition of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations.

I now turn to State-Commonwealth relations. The federal system does not always work in an efficient way. One of the major reasons why it does not work in Australia as effectively as it should is the major fiscal imbalance between the Commonwealth and the States. For government to work effectively governments need power to legislate, but they also need a revenue base for which they are responsible. It is my view that, for there to be effective government, the government that spends the money should have the responsibility to its electors about the spending. But equally the government that spends the money should have the responsibility of raising the money it spends.

The States do not raise the money they spend. Changes should be made in our constitutional arrangements so that States have that responsibility. Those States protest that they would like the revenue-raising powers but when they get close to having that power they walk away from it. I cannot help feeling that that is just what has happened in relation not only to the ACIR but also to the Constitutional Convention. The ACIR was studying the Loan Council and opening the closed doors as to the machinations and mechanisms of how the Loan Council operated. It was having an effect in the dialogue that was occurring in the relationships that had developed in the Loan Council and could have gone on doing that. Had this Labor Government given the ACIR the resources to enable it to continue that line of investigation, we may well have had an improvement in that area of our Commonwealth-State relationship.

At the last Convention everyone said that the Constitutional Convention was a failure and that it never does any good work. Yet, as a member who attended a number of Constitutional Conventions, I believe that the reports that were before the last Constitutional Convention were some of the best that had been submitted to any of the Conventions held. It is interesting that in the report that dealt with the relationships between States on fiscal powers, there was a very serious debate about fiscal balance or imbalance. The report of a committee that involves State and Federal parliamentary representation concluded that there should be fiscal balance, that governments that spend the money should raise the money. Who then wanted the Constitutional Convention abandoned? It was the Labor State governments and a Labor Federal government because they did not want to face that fundamental problem that confronts the federal system and its operation in Australia. I think that is the case with the ACIR.

I have been asked to be a little more brief in my remarks than I would normally be because other colleagues of mine want to speak. I just draw the attention of the House to the very significant reports that have been prepared by the ACIR. Many of them are regarded as significant text-book works, and many have had a significant influence upon public thinking on vital issues affecting the structure of government in Australia.

I conclude by saying that some fine Australians have made a great contribution through the ACIR. I refer particularly to the chairmen who have taken responsibility for guiding that body-the first Chairman, Professor Russell Mathews, and his successor, Professor Ross Gates. I worked for long periods with those two chairmen, and I commend them for their dedication, their sense of purpose and their contribution to the development of greater understanding within our federal system through the work that they did on the ACIR. I did not have the same opportunity to get to know Terry Purcell, the last Chairman, but from what I saw of him I believe that he was a man who believed that the ACIR had made and could still make a contribution to the advancement of government and parliamentary arrangements in Australia.

My final task is to commend the dedicated staff, some of whom were there on contract terms for relatively short periods, and others of whom worked with the ACIR for longer periods. Time does not permit me to identify them individually. It is unlikely that the Opposition will be successful in a debate such as this in this House, but we may find that we can gain the support of sufficient senators to prevent this Bill going through. But in the event that it goes through, I think it is appropriate to have placed on the parliamentary record the appreciation, at least of someone who was on the Advisory Council, of the work of the staff in establishing for the ACIR a record of achievement which has been somewhat denigrated in recent times by those who have simply pointed to some of the weaknesses without being prepared to look at some of its successes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a Bill to repeal the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Act. That Act established the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. The Council, established by the Fraser Government in 1976, was created to improve intergovernmental relations and co-operation in Australia. Its functions were to inquire into and to keep under consideration and review matters relating to intergovernmental co-operation. In the course of its work the Council was to investigate areas of intergovernmental concern and to recommend to governments accordingly. Such investigations were to involve research, commission studies, public submissions, seminars, public hearings and the preparation of information papers, reports and the like. State and local government as well as Commonwealth representation were involved on the Council. It brought together people from each of those areas of government to consider the way in which the responsibilities of each of them might be adjusted appropriately to minimise the overlap of powers and responsibilities, to ensure that there was no duplication and to keep bureaucracy to a minimum.

SPEECH.PARA: Anybody hearing of those objectives would understand that they were very desirable and important and would wonder why Australia should not have a body which is dedicated to ensuring that overlap among governments is kept to an absolute minimum. I suspect that in the battles about power, which are often conducted in the bureaucracy in true Yes Minister form, this body was largely without power in relation to itself and was unable to save itself as people were casting around to find whether they could save a mere dollar or two as we came towards consideration of the recent Budget. If we look at the way in which the project was initiated, we can see how consideration of the abandonment of the ACIR emerged. The ninth annual report of the Advisory Council sets out in chapter IV the circumstances in which an external review of that body was to be initiated. It states that the Prime Minister first wrote in March 1985 suggesting that:

. . . the review would be conducted by four persons knowledgeable of intergovernmental problems, chaired by an `independent' and with the other three members representing each of the spheres of government.

The terms of reference, set out in the report, were to obtain the views about the value of the ACIR's role in the future, whether its membership was appropriate, and whether it had adequate financial resources to enable it to do its job and to assess its research. That was the task-a proper review of the body. That review was welcomed by all those involved. Yet, in August 1985, the Prime Minister wrote again, saying that the Commonwealth now believed it would be `more effective and economical' for the review to be undertaken by `a small group of Commonwealth officials', who would be asked to examine whether the continued existence of the body was justified as an effective means of improving intergovernmental relations-a charter for its abolition if I have ever heard one-whether by some reorganisation the ACIR could be made capable of a more relevant contribution to the understanding of longer term intergovernmental issues and whether acceptable and viable alternatives existed or could be developed.

That was a charter for the Council's abolition. I was not present when the officers were given their brief, but with those instructions it is hard to imagine that they would produce anything other than a report counselling the abolition of the ACIR. Of course, it was that very report that the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) cited in his second reading speech as the basis upon which the Government sought the abolition of this organisation. When the Deputy Prime Minister introduced this Bill into the Parliament, he told us that it was on the basis of the recommendation of the task group report that this body was not to be continued. I read that document closely. Under the heading `Consideration of the Issues', the first question asked was:
Has ACIR been fulfilling the purpose for which it was established?

In the area of publications, it was seen to be an industrious body. On the question of whether its publications achieved an effective result, the reviewers were equivocal, but of course they looked at whether recommendations had been implemented. That says more about the governments of the States and the Commonwealth and less about the ACIR, as was suggested by some of my colleagues who spoke earlier in the debate. That was one of the points made by the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). The report went on to assess attitudes to the work of the ACIR. I wish to record the following for the benefit of all those who read the speeches made in this debate. About local government the report said:

. . . we think it should be accepted that ACIR's work has been of significant benefit in bringing information together on a national basis, often for the first time; in improving understanding of local government systems, their problems and potential; and in stimulation ideas for possible improvement. This in itself is no mean achievement.

When one goes to the final conclusions, one finds that the recommendation that this body be abolished was not borne out in the discussion. The conclusions were not balanced in terms of the discussion of the report itself. The recommendations were not put in terms of simple abandonment of this body; the reviewers themselves recognised that alternative approaches should be adopted. The Bill before us simply abandons the ACIR, yet the reviewers in their recommendations said this:

If ACIR is disbanded, some increased capacity for the study of inter-governmental relations could be provided in the Local Government Ministers' Conference; and/or in the ANU Centre for Research on Federal Financial Relations. Additionally, Ministerial Councils other than the Local Government Ministers' Conference could be encouraged to take a greater role in this area.

That is one of the positive suggestions made, if the body were to be disbanded. Yet, in the Minister's speech we find that no further aspect of research is provided for and no further funding of activities regarding those important research conferences is proposed. If the body is to be retained and reformed, the reviewers suggested in paragraphs 6 (a) to 6 (h) specific programs that could be put in place to ensure that the body was able to function effectively. They drew particular attention to the funding arrangements and said that it should be able to do research in areas recommended by ministerial councils. It suggested the streamlining of research procedures and so on. That is the basis upon which the task force itself recommended reform. There were only two alternatives-that it be disbanded and alternatives put in place, or that it be retained and reformed.

What has the Government done? It seeks to abolish the Council as if it had no purpose at all. When one looks at the Hansard record of speeches on the Council made in past years, one sees that a number of very distinguished parliamentarians from the Government benches have spoken. They include a former Prime Minister; that former Prime Minister's son; the President of the Senate, the Hon. Douglas McClelland; the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt; and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). One clear principle emerges from each of those speeches: The then Opposition was never opposed to the establishment of the ACIR. In fact, it endorsed it. Senator Douglas McClelland said:

The Opposition does not oppose this Bill to establish an Advisory Council for Inter-Government Relations. In fact we welcome the conservative parties' new found realisation that local government is an important facet of any federal system of government.

I do not have time to quote fully the remarks made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. He made some considerable comments. I shall pass the record of them over to my colleagues to see whether they find any value in them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Denison might like to have them.

—The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) might like to have those comments so that he can quote them. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was very clear in his support for that body. He saw that it should be retained. He considered that it had an important and fundamental role to fulfil.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not a waste of government funds to look at the way in which duplication of function might be rationalised. Substantial savings could be made in government expenditure if some of the recommendations of the body were taken into account, accepted as clear recommendations and implemented by both the Federal Government and State governments. However, each has specific interests, as I mentioned earlier, in Yes Minister fame. Important bureaucrats in Canberra do not want to see functions lost. They are not keen to see any rationalisation of education that might limit the Department of Education, at a Federal level, or the Schools Commission, and so on. Equally, the State governments, with their bureaucracies, are not terribly anxious to see any devolution to the Commonwealth of the functions that they fulfil. Therefore, the Government says that the body that costs a mere half a million dollars and makes recommendations in that area ought to go. It does not consider the substantial areas of saving. That is the very reason that the Opposition is of the view that the body should not be abolished but should be retained. That is the reason that, when this legislation reaches the Senate, we will oppose it. We hope that we will achieve the support of the Australian Democrats and that the Government and the States will have to find the funds to ensure that this body is able to continue.

The Deputy Prime Minister mentioned that the State governments have agreed to the Commonwealth's request for the abolition of the Council. I suspect that they did so more under duress than by design. I suspect that they were told: `We intend to get rid of it, fellows. You have to agree to this'. I suspect that the politicians involved were carried along. I am sure that, when we reject the proposal and the Commonwealth has to write and say `We still have a Council', the States will be willing participants, with local government, in ensuring that that worthwhile body is able to continue its constructive work. I say that as a person who has not been a member of the Council. I make my observations merely as an interested parliamentarian and as one who has a particular interest in local government matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose most vehemently the repeal Bill which seeks to abolish the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. The Council has performed extremely well. There has been a surprising, and perhaps even amazing, turn of events in this debate. Including me, seven members have spoken, six of whom are members of the Opposition. They were my colleagues the honourable members for Ryan (Mr Moore), Wakefield (Mr Andrews), Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), Sturt (Mr Wilson) and Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and only one Australian Labor Party member, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) is waiting to join the list of speakers.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleagues' contributions were succinct and to the point. I was amazed when I heard the mind boggling statements by the honourable member for Burke. Preening himself with a bit of a smirk, he proclaimed that he was known as `Mr Local Government'. He has the hide of a saltwater crocodile if he can stand in this place and tell the people of Australia that he is `Mr Local Government' and say, in this Parliament, to the people of Australia, that there is no support for the ACIR from local government. I should like to read extracts from one or two letters.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is the member for local anaesthetics.
—Order! The honourable member for Dawson will cease interjecting.
—But he puts everybody to sleep.
—Order! The honourable member for Dawson will not trifle with the Chair.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I can see that I need your control.
—You need my protection from your colleagues, no less.
—`Protection' is, indeed, the word. A letter dated 22 July 1986 from Kempsey Shire Council states:

SPEECH.PARA: As you are aware Council recently supported moves by the Local Government and Shires Associations by making representations to you, for the continuation of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations.

However Council recently received a Circular from the Local Government and Shires Associations, which stated that the Associations were disturbed to learn that the Federal Cabinet had decided to recommend to the State Governments-
mark that--
that ACIR be abolished.
The Associations have urged Councils to make prompt representations to both local, State and Federal members of Parliament in a further endeavour to ensure that ACIR is retained.
The honourable member for Burke said that there is no support from local government for its retention! A letter from Coffs Harbour Shire Council, dated 29 April 1986, states:
It has been reported that the Advisory Council for Intergovernment Relations is to be disbanded and that a decision on this is imminent.
Council views this action with some concern as it has served the process of local government well since 1976.

That is the crux of the issue: It has served local government well. It has served Australia well. The honourable member for Burke sneered, in his own inimitable style, at the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee. We are concerned about waste. However, he is wrong to suggest that the ACIR, with a total budget of $556,000, is a waste of money. Only 45 per cent of that comes from Commonwealth funding-a mere $253,000. It is worth much more than that. I refer to the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). He said:
As noted in the Task Group report, ACIR has not established a reputation for high quality research generally . . .

I refer briefly to some of the publications and the research work done by the ACIR. I mention two reports in particular-`Responsibilities and Resources of Australian Local Government 1984' and `Implications of Constitutional Recognition for Australian Local Government 1985'. Many information papers and discussion papers were written, all of which have been of great value and significance to local government. The Attorney-General went on:
Nor have its recommendations on the whole been acted on by participating governments.

Strike me pink, it is not the fault of the ACIR that State and Federal governments do not want to act on any of those reports. The recommendations of the ACIR have been useful and it is not its fault that they have not been fruitful. The Attorney-General went on to say:
As a result ACIR has had limited success in improving inter-governmental relations, particularly Commonwealth/State relations.

I think it is fairly well accepted that the main thrust of the ACIR was in the direction of local government. After all, State and Federal governments have many opportunities for getting together to discuss matters, from the Premiers Conference down, but a voice, a window, for local government was provided with the ACIR. It will be against the interests of local government in Australia for it to be abolished because local government has benefited a great deal from it.

I mention in passing that the honourable member for Burke made the point that the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) has considerable respect from local government in this country, and I share that respect for the Minister. I think he is a straight shooter. We know exactly where he stands. I am sure he would never willingly harm anybody. He said in a letter to me dated 17 June 1986:
I am aware of the valuable work that the ACIR has done in the field of Local Government relations both with the States and the Commonwealth Government.
I will be pointing to this contribution when this matter is discussed in Cabinet and arguing for the continuation of this area of work.

Regrettably for the interests of local government and for the interests of Australia, the Cabinet rolled the Minister on this. It will not do any good here because we do not have the numbers, but I urge honourable senators in another place to use their prerogative to defeat this Bill and send it back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke socialist centralist Government stands condemned for bringing this legislation into this Parliament to kill the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations. That body was established following an election pledge of the Fraser-Anthony Liberal-National Party coalition in 1975 after very careful consideration by our joint parties. At that time I was a member of the committee on federal policy. We went to the people of Australia with it in our platform in 1975, when we were elected. We brought in the legislation in 1976 and it was passed through the Parliament and supported most eloquently by the former Prime Minister, the then member for Werriwa, the Hon. Gough Whitlam, QC. Amongst other things, in his remarks reported in Hansard on 7 October 1976, he said that the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations Bill accorded some recognition to the place of local government in the federal system. For that reason he supported it. It was also supported by the present Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) and by the then Opposition at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of every federalist in this Parliament, and sadly they are all on this side of the House, on behalf of every Tasmanian member of the House of Representatives-I note the presence of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck)-and on behalf of those who know that the municipality of Kingborough is the fastest growing municipality in Australia's south island, Tasmania, and that Logan City, which is so well represented by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), is the fastest-growing shire in the north island of Australia, I protest against this decision. I think it is a wrong decision. The cost to the taxpayers of Australia is a mere $600,000 per annum. Do honourable members know where the headquarters of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations are? They are in the electorate of Denison. They were put there by Prime Minister Fraser to signify to the whole nation the commitment of the Liberal-National Party coalition to a federal system. He determined that it would be placed in one of the less populous States. Naturally, when it came to the judging Tasmania was the selected site, and Australia's most beautiful State capital city has hosted this distinguished Council since 1979.

The arguments put for its abolition are specious. It is incredible that it is claimed by this incompetent Hawke socialist Government that the ACIR has not established a reputation for high quality research. That is wrong. It has. It is about time the Hawke socialist Government realised what high quality research is.

TALK.START.PARA: —They hate Tasmania.

—They hate Tasmania. The Government has said that the Council's recommendations on the whole have not been acted on by participating governments. That is not so. Tasmania has the best State Government in Australia and Tasmania bitterly opposes the death of the ACIR. The Government further said that the ACIR has had limited success in improving intergovernmental relations, particularly Commonwealth-State relations. The Hawke socialist Government does not even mention local government. The ACIR is the only statutory body in Australia in which local government has a place. It mirrors the Inter-government Advisory Council in the United States, which has operated since 1969 with great success. There is a similar body in practically every federal system in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: We are having another rushed debate, but we will not have time to call a division. I say-and I mean this-thank God for the Senate. I believe the Senate is the States House. A Senate committed to federalism will throw out this rotten piece of legislation neck and crop. I appeal to the Australian Democrats to join with the Liberals, the National Party and Senator Brian Harradine in defeating this legislation. As the time ticks away, both for me in this debate and for the Hawke socialist government, I say that this is typical of a government which treats local government with contempt, which is not committed to the federal system, and which is prepared to repudiate the things it stood for when its distinguished leader was the former member for Werriwa. I oppose this Bill. I hope it is defeated in the Senate and I hope that this rotten Hawke socialist Government is thrown from office at the earliest possible opportunity.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
