SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In concluding my remarks on the Budget, I would like to draw people's attention to remarks made by one of the eminent people in our society, one who has an awful lot to say these days, one who tends to like the centre stage-the very eminent John Stone. In 1979, when he was Secretary to the Treasury, he said that there was really no need for a manufacturing sector in Australia, that all Australia needed to do was to export minerals and have a farming economy. This was at the height, of course, of the Liberal Party mining boom which did not eventuate. That was John Stone's professed view in 1979. It is also the professed view of many other people of his ilk. This is simply a rerun of Australia's history. This is what we have done, certainly since the last war. This was one of the great tragedies of the Menzies era. Australia today is more of an economic colony of the United States and Japan that it ever was of Great Britain, principally because the British transferred technology and, of course, Japan and America are much more reluctant to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia must look to the area of reindustrialisation, for it is only through reindustrialisation of this country that we can secure the jobs that will secure a worthwhile future for our children. I believe that shorter working hours and job sharing are simply palliatives to the middle class. Job sharing is more about more leisure time than spreading the available work. People in our society at this stage need to work. There may come a time in the future when it is not so important, but right now we must have jobs. It must be the priority of any government. Certainly, it is the priority of this Government, which has been very successful in that regard.

In choosing industries, we must develop the expertise that Australia has for innovating or inventing and we must capitalise on this intellectual property. We have been very remiss in doing this in the past. (Quorum formed) I thank the Opposition for giving me the audience that I obviously deserve. It is a pity that a few more members of the Opposition are not present to hear a little bit of plain speaking. I was saying, before I was so rudely interrupted, that reindustrialising this country must be our main objective. This is the vision that Australia needs. This is the vision which I believe can unite this country. We must do away with the years of the cultural cringe that we inherited from the previous Government, when it was thought that Australia simply did not have the capacity to do these things. It is very important that the Government's policy of allowing the dollar to float has led to the revitalisation of industry. While the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) gloats and says that it will not work, the truth is that it is working. The J-curve is real. Industry in this country is starting to reawake.

TALK.START.PARA: —They just want to talk the country down.

—As my very good colleague says, they are trying to talk the country down. They believe that that is in their short-term interests. We have seen examples of this from the Leader of the Opposition. In Western Australia, one member of the State Liberal Party actually wrote to the United States Secretary of State, Mr Shultz, urging him to try to undermine the Australian economy further.
—Was that Ross Lightfoot?

—That was Ross Lightfoot. I believe that his actions were treasonable. It is interesting to note that his statement has never been fully repudiated by the Liberal Party, either federally or at the State level. Members of the Liberal Party think that they are born to rule. They believe that anything is acceptable in their pursuit of power. It is an obscene pursuit of power. Had they been successful, there might be some justification for their trampling on our traditions; but there is no such justification because under their rule industry in this country was slaughtered. Because they had no policy on wages, the Australian dollar was overvalued. One after the other, industries were driven to the wall, and not a word was said by those opposite. They thought it was quite acceptable to extend unemployment for the people of Australia, simply because of their policy failures.

SPEECH.PARA: People talk about poverty in the community. I am concerned about poverty. But the palliatives that are often suggested are nothing when compared with the creation of employment. The best antidote to poverty is a job. It must be the objective of this Government to continue our efforts to generate employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not doing much good.

—That is the sort of comment to which I have referred. The truth is that Australia is starting to awake. This country can become an industrial giant if we attend to the things that we are good at, if we allow the full play of initiatives that our people have displayed over time. We must stop allowing our initiatives to be sold overseas for a few shekels when they can be kept here and developed to provide jobs for our people. Some things are dependent on industries that already exist. Obviously, we would be foolish to ignore our natural advantages.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say a few words about the gold-mining industry. I am often accused of being parochial on this matter. There is no doubt that it is of great personal concern to me. However, it is also true that heavy engineering in this country is in a very depressed state and right now the gold-mining industry is driving heavy engineering. The workshops in Sydney, Melbourne and the Hunter Valley are not making anything except material for the gold-mining industry. One of the things about the gold-mining industry is that it has a very high Australian content. The gold-mining industry is an engine that must be used to drag along Australian manufacturing capacity. It would be very foolish in the extreme to put any impediment in the way. While the people in Treasury often have a predilection for putting what they call some form of conformity or equity into the taxation system I say to them: `This argument is not about equity in the taxation system; it is about industry policy and we must now attend to it'. I represent an electorate which has by far the greatest divergence of mineral exports; it certainly has the greatest total of mineral exports in Australia. I know that these industries will not employ people. They are efficient industries simply because they do not employ very many people. That is where their efficiency is derived. We must have the manufacturing sector.

People talk about Chifley's light on the hill. This was a great vision of Chifley's. Unfortunately today it is not enough. The division of equity and equality in society, which we all seek, is not enough any more. We as a government have to give direction; we have to show the people of Australia how we can get there. I believe that under the stewardship of this Government we are getting there, but more needs to be done. We need to be out there promoting at every opportunity. It saddens me that on occasions Australian companies have striven mightily to develop a marvellous product and government departments-State and Federal-have gone overseas to buy equipment available in Australia. One of the sad things is that with the current value of the dollar they often pay more for an overseas product which is of an inferior nature to that produced in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Give examples.

—One example I can give is a company in Western Australia that has the most advanced system in the world for making micrographic film. It is a very versatile system, works in colour and is not limited to any format. It is completely flexible. That company is selling its products in the United States, France and Germany but it has not yet been able to sell them in Australia. In the meantime two State departments have bought German machines which are certainly of inferior quality. It is true that in that instance the machine was slightly cheaper but it certainly lacked the capacity of the Australian one. Of course with the devaluation in the Australian dollar that situation has changed. That company is just one example. I can give examples all night, some of which, I fear, may be a little embarrassing to my Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me look at one of the most shoddy incidents that took place in Australia. I ask members of the Opposition to cast their minds back to 1963. This was the year when their leader, Mr Menzies, decided that Australia would no longer be a colony of the United Kingdom; it would become a colony of the United States. By cutting our apron strings with Britain he immediately tied himself to the United States. Remember the reprehensible election campaign of 1963-`put your hand in the hand of big brother America'. That election gave us the F111, A British designed aeroplane sold to the Americans and subsequently bought by us. The consequence of that action was that we destroyed the Australian aviation industry, an industry which had a proud history. The British wanted a joint venture with us regarding the TSR2. That plane was at the forefront of avionics. The British are probably still at the forefront of avionics. We could have been there but that was denied us because Mr Menzies sighted some sort of golden era in Australia and was prepared to sell the future of this country for his own short term political gains. The history of the Liberal Party is fraught with that sort of behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Wamira aircraft that you killed last year?

—If the honourable member wants to give a better example he would be better off looking at helicopters. I am not saying that this Government is beyond reproach. In fact I am on record as being very critical of what has happened in this area. Overwhelmingly that ethos developed in Australian society. Our cultural cringe is a product of the Opposition's term of government and we are desperately trying to rid Australia of it. Unless Australia can get rid of the inferiority complex which it has developed I do not believe that we can develop the golden future that is ours.

SPEECH.PARA: I hear people talk of the doom and gloom and about how bad things are, but this is simply not so. Often one finds that is the case. Today Australia is on the edge of a great opportunity. It is a great opportunity not only for the people of Australia but also the people of the world to see what we can do. We can show the world how, through our own initiatives, we can take ourselves through this time of trial we are in into an era when we can provide a future with surety and dignity for our people. There will be a time when Australia can set an example to the rest of the world. I certainly hope that this opportunity will not be missed or stifled by short term thinking that emanates from some circles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to confine my remarks to the Federal Government's cynical and ill-conceived equalisation and aggregation commercial regional television policy.
—What?
—Aggregation. Remember the corruption, the sell out to Murdoch and Packer.

—The honourable member for Gippsland is right in his better description of what the Labor Government's policy is with regard to commercial regional television. The story is that the Government will make a final decision in the very near future. There will be a Cabinet meeting to decide whether regional television, as we know it, is to have a future in this country. I have also been told that the Caucus rural and primary industry and regional affairs committee met today to determine its attitude to this proposal and I have also been told that it agrees to aggregation. If anyone on the Government's side disagrees with that information that has been given to me I would be very pleased to hear it. As I understand it, that committee has sold out to the Sydney television networks, to the views of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and has given away its basis of representation in regional electorates.
—Which electorates? Bendigo, Ballarat?

—I will come to them. We should remember that the coalition tonight and tomorrow, whenever debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 continues, will be commenting on this ill-conceived policy. It is a part of Budget expenditure but it is also a very critical time for regional television. I will be followed on this side by the shadow Minister for Communications, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), and others who will speak on this issue. The supplementary licence scheme, which provides an extra channel for regional television viewers, was introduced by the coalition Government in the early 1980s. When the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) were the responsible Ministers, they very much supported this policy. When the Australian Labor Party was successful in March 1983 there was a nine-month delay while the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) determined whether that was the suitable policy. After a delay he decided that it was, and I commend the Minister for so doing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that the supplementary licence scheme was bogged down. There was no progress because of two factors: As I remember, there was a series of broadcasting and television tribunal hearings concerning Perth as well as those in relation to the supplementary scheme. We required basically two hearings, double applications. But the delay that occurred in the determination of the policy is no reason for the policy which this Government is to foist on regional and rural Australia. The coalition policy, which was recently confirmed by the shadow Minister-and details of which will be given by him-indicates that in government we would provide an immediate supplementary or, if you like, multi-channel system licence for each commercial station which could viably have one to provide that much needed and overdue second channel for regional television viewers. That second channel would be reviewed after some years.

An alternative is what the Regional Television Association is proposing at present with its multi-channel system scheme; that is, a second channel for the existing licensee as soon as possible, another by 1990 where viable, and aggregation by about 1996. It can be said by the Government that it has the multi-channel option in its television policy but its option is, as others have described it, very much a Clayton's option because only one television licensee in the potentially aggregated group needs to decide that it does not want that option and aggregation must follow. So it is not really a policy option at all.

Why did the Government announce this equalisation policy? We had it from the Minister for Communications in his statement in May. In my view it comes down to a battle between the Minister for Communications and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That is no secret around this place. The Minister was aware of regional needs and priorities. The Prime Minister was aware of only one thing, and that was the desire to gain for the Sydney television networks the effective, if indirect, control of all commercial television in this country. The networks and the Prime Minister had been frustrated in attempting to achieve this aim by the Satellite Program Service decision the Minister had made at an earlier stage.

Why is the Prime Minister so anxious to have the television networks dominate Australian commercial television? The question has been put by certain honourable members on my left, who are also, I acknowledge, very much to the Right. The answer is that the Prime Minister wishes to maintain his favourable image with those television networks, hence my original statement about the cynicism of the whole policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the honourable member is working on a supposition. He might bear that in mind and stick to what he knows to be facts.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, for my education and that of fellow members, may I ask you which standing order you are following?
—There is no point of order.

—This policy has been foisted on country people. There has been no consultation with them as to the determination of their priorities. If one asks country people about their priorities in communications, one finds that their No. 1 priority is a telephone that works all the time and telephone bills that are not exorbitant. Their second priority in communications is greater choice in radio programs whether it be more commercial radio programs or Australian Broadcasting Corporation FM programs for regional Australia. Their next choice is a second commercial television program or, in some cases, that other alternative, the Special Broadcasting Service. I am presenting to Parliament a petition from my area with over 4,000 signatures requesting SBS for the Goulburn Valley and northern Victoria. Earlier investigations by the Department of Communications ascertained that country people do not want three television programs that are identical. That is what will result from aggregation. Furthermore, the policy will bring the loss of localism, which is tremendously important to regional communities, and a loss of independent ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: The equalisation policy of this Government is uneconomic in relation to ownership and regional stations. Hence the indirect networking which will occur, which I have seen in operation in the United States of America. Only now has a decision been made that Perth, a city of one million people, can sustain three commercial television stations with a single studio and a single transmitter. Of the different combinations under the proposed aggregation system, not one has one million people in its potential viewing audience. Even in the larger proposed combinations there is an overlap with the metropolitan stations. There is a requirement for multiple transmission systems and multiple studios. The cost to regional television in Australia is to be about $600m-all imported. Honourable members should think of that in relation to our balance of payments. The cost of aggregation or equalisation to the eastern States, which form the basic centre of the Government's program, is to be $335m, and it will be $85m if there is to be the one supplementary or multi-channel station-a $250m difference. That is four years' worth of uranium exports to France. It is fascinating! Exports from this country are important, but this policy is completely unnecessary and will involve a minimum of $335m in imports or possibly $600m over the life of the program.

It is stated that the three stations can get their money from increased advertising-all of them with markets smaller than the smallest of the metropolitan stations and with rural and regional economies and advertising revenue in regional Australia stagnating. If this Government is really talking about viable markets for television, there should be six commercial television stations in Melbourne and Sydney. There is already better television choice in regional Australia compared with Melbourne and Sydney than there is in other countries. In other countries it is the major cities where there is the largest number of commercial television stations.

One can once again ask: How genuine is this Government with that sort of attitude? There will be a delay in the implementation of this policy. If we were to have the single supplementary program station with orders-which could have been placed 12 months ago-the regionals have guaranteed that they could have that genuine alternative program up and running. In regard to the eastern States section under the Government's equalisation policy there are 24 stations, 48 transmitters and 48 studios. The delay in ordering this equipment once again will further delay the implementation of this program for the people of regional Australia. The people in regional Australia are reacting with anger against Labor Federal members of Parliament in regional seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bendigo.

—I will name them: Bendigo, Ballarat, McMillan, McEwen, Calare, Hunter, Capricornia, Herbert and Leichhardt. It is interestingly coincidental that the seats where this policy will have its greatest effect happen to be the marginal Labor Federal seats. The Government can change as a result of basically this one issue. My advice to the regional television stations of Australia is to turn up the heat on those Federal Labor members, to scorch them where it hurts and make the point very clear that there are more votes to be lost by this Government's equalisation policy than there are votes to be gained by the Prime Minister with the networks in Sydney. My advice also is that, as legislation will be necessary, the legislation should be rejected in the Senate, because the more we can delay the introduction of this policy the greater will be our ability, when we win the next election, to overturn the policy and revert to a more genuine, acceptable and viable one.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some sympathy for the Minister on this matter because I understand that he has been quoted-I apologise if I do not quote him correctly-as referring to some of his Labor regional members as `lions in their electorates and lambs in Canberra'. How about that? I would like to quote from the Melbourne Age of Wednesday, 27 August. The heading was: `Government urged to delay introduction of country TV plan'. I quote:
Two Victorian Labor backbenchers yesterday called on the Federal Government to defer its policy of providing rural Australians with a choice of three commercial television stations.

It is believed that about six Labor backbenchers have approached the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, seeking a delay in the policy which would encourage swift aggregation of regional television into areas each with three networks.

Yesterday, the Labor member for Bendigo, Mr John Brumby, said that while he fully supported the goal of aggregated services it was extremely difficult to justify the cost in terms of the country's balance of payments.

He said the plan was a ``lovely notion'' but one that was going to cost $400 million. ``Can you justify that? I don't think I can. Most of the broadcasting equipment required to introduce aggregated services is fully imported.
The Labor member for Ballarat, Mr John Mildren, said he would also write to the Prime Minister requesting that the policy be deferred.

Where are these lions in their electorates? The ultimate and correct policy for commercial regional television is to defer any further action by this Government and return to the policy promoted by the Opposition, which was promoted by the Minister and which I believe he still wants to promote, and which is promoted by the Regional Television Association, to have a genuine supplementary alternative program with a viable system for the future of an independent and locally based regional television system in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The approach which I will be taking to the Budget is fundamentally different from the sterile and intellectually bankrupt approach proposed by the Liberal Opposition. The comments of honourable members opposite on the Budget have all been directed to calling for more sacrifices and more taxes on the workers and their families. They want to magnify the current strategy many times over so that this nation will be torn asunder, with the rich becoming much richer and the poor being driven into total despair. Under the extraordinary prescriptions of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) there would be a dramatic reduction in the standards of living of the Australian people, with the creation of massive unemployment and dramatic social problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, we in the Left of the Australian Labor Party wish to emphasise our concern that the current economic strategy is mistaken. We believe that this strategy is based on an excessive reliance on conservative economic theory and is in conflict with the values and principles of democratic socialism. In saying this, I reject the claim that the Left seeks to resolve the economic crisis through reliance on traditional and outmoded formulas. We wish to voice the concerns of a large number of trade unions, ethnic groups, community organisations and members of the Labor Party in relation to the decisions. We have faith in the view that the economic crisis can be resolved without abandoning the principles of equality and social justice. Of course, we agree with the Government that there is a fundamental problem in Australia's balance of payments and in our overseas indebtedness. Indeed, various members of the Left had emphasised the seriousness of this issue many months before the now celebrated `banana republic' statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We have been concerned with the failure to achieve the J-curve effect since last year. We have been talking about the need for new trade and industry initiatives based on the platform of the Party since 1984.

While we agree that there is a basic problem with our current account, we are concerned that the Government has chosen to abandon its previous strategy of maximising growth. This strategy had the very positive outcome of producing 670,000 jobs in three years. It was based on an expansionary approach to the economy, which created an optimism in the community and positive support for the Labor Government. Within the constraints of that policy we were able to adopt some positive redistributive measures, including action to assist the poor and working families. However, we have serious concerns about the new macroeconomic strategy which has been adopted. In particular, we believe that the strategy of reducing growth as a means of reducing imports is full of dangers. This strategy is based on the assumption that reducing growth will reduce demand in the economy and that this will mean that fewer imported products will be purchased.

However, there are important questions which need to be raised here: Firstly, can the reduction in growth be controlled so that we have the 2 1/2 per cent figure as predicted in the Budget Papers, or are we entitled to be concerned that the growth rate may be lower, possibly resulting in a recession? Secondly, will the measures adopted in the Budget achieve the turnaround in the current account and the stabilisation of the dollar, as the Treasurer seems to believe? Thirdly, even assuming that the reduction in government spending of the levels achieved in this Budget can be justified on macroeconomic grounds--

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no reduction in government spending; there was an increase in taxes.

—The honourable member should talk to the groups whose spending has been reduced, if that is what he thinks. I repeat: Even assuming that the reduction in government spending of the level achieved in this Budget can be justified on macroeconomic grounds, were the cuts which have been made consistent with the principle of restraint with equity, as outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? I shall attempt to deal with these difficult questions because they have been raised with me by many members and supporters of the Labor Party and many other groups and individuals of goodwill who wish to see not only the re-election of the Labor Government but also the positive restoration of our economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Consider now the last question. The trade union movement, in the form of the Australian Council of Trade Unions executive, had this to say:

The ACTU does not believe that the Budget deals with restraint on the basis of equity. Wage and salary earners in particular have had to bear a heavy burden in accommodating the economic pressures. The additional cost to wage and salary earners imposed by the Budget include the additional tax on petrol, the deferral of the tax cuts, the increase in the Medicare levy and a number of other surcharges representing a significant reduction in the purchasing power of workers.

Indeed, the estimate of the Australian Consumers Association of the impact on the average family is a reduction in spending power of the order of $15 a week. Let us then not hear any more of the nonsense from the Opposition about this Budget being insufficiently tough on workers and their families. However, there is an even more disturbing aspect. The Budget was particularly harsh on a number of the poor in our community. The Australian Council of Social Service said of the Budget:

In the circumstances, the huge cut in welfare assistance is entirely unnecessary and unjustifiable. It will cause considerable hardship and injustice while doing little or nothing to solve our national economic difficulties.

ACOSS identified five areas which have hit people living in poverty. These are: Firstly, cuts of about one per cent in all indexed pensions and benefits through deferring indexation; secondly, cuts of 8 per cent in other benefits and allowances through failing to adjust them for inflation; thirdly, the deferral for another seven months of the poverty traps measures which were a fundamental part of our tax package announced last September, and the most progressive aspect of that package; fourthly, the abolition of the community employment program, a program that most benefited the unemployed who were in the most severe poverty; and, fifthly, large increases in pharmaceutical charges which will particularly hit the working poor. The ACTU expressed a special concern about these measures. It said:
The Budget has shown in many cases considerable insensitivity in these and other areas.

In addition to these decisions which, in my view, are contrary to the spirit of the social justice strategy of the party as adopted at the national conference, there are a number of decisions about which many groups in the ethnic communities have protested to me. These decisions have been interpreted by them as an attack on multi-culturalism. The extraordinary decision to merge the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service not only flies in the face of the decisions of the National Conference and the Caucus but also has clearly undermined much of the good work which this Government has done in the ethnic communities. This was compounded by the decisions in relation to the cuts in the English as a second language program and the multi-cultural education program.

The Government must now act to change these decisions, or at least to mitigate their consequences. In particular, it must act to protect the interests of multicultural broadcasting and pay more attention to migrants' educational needs. Of course, it might be argued that, since the Government was in a difficult position, what else could it have done. Let me say that, even assuming that the cuts were necessary, I do not believe that they have been applied with fairness. It was still possible to achieve greater fairness by imposing some burdens on the rich. (Quorum formed) I was talking about the fact that the Budget could have imposed some further burdens on the rich. Indeed, they have hardly been affected by the cuts. Instead of deferring poverty traps assistance to the poor, why not defer until next July tax cuts to the wealthy, such as those earning above $40,000 a year?

Alternatively, the same deficit outcome could have been achieved if the Government had raised more money by imposing a one per cent surcharge on imports, as requested by the national conference. This would have allowed much more flexibility as it would have raised at least $300m, which could have been used to continue expenditures in key programs affecting the poor and ordinary workers. Incidentally, it would have helped also to deal with the current account deficit by reducing imports.

There are a number of additional measures in the savings area and in the introduction of redistributive measures which could have assisted us in achieving a fairer outcome. We could thus have avoided decisions such as saving $66m by selling uranium to France. It is well to keep in mind that according to the Business Review Weekly, the wealthiest people in Australia have increased their wealth by in excess of 40 per cent in the past year. There are over 200 multi-millionaires in Australia. Contrary to the claims of the Opposition, the rich have never had it so good. Unfortunately, they have not been investing their wealth in productive enterprises in Australia, which is one of the fundamental causes of our present crisis.

I wish now to return to the second question I have raised: Will the tough fiscal strategy of the Government achieve a stabilisation of the dollar and a resolution of our current account problems? So far, the signs have not been very optimistic. In the days following the Budget, the dollar did not increase significantly in value. On the contrary, it became clear that the Government would have to continue to pursue a high interest rate strategy in order to keep the dollar above US60c. Yet the whole point of the low Budget deficit was that it would allow us to reduce interest rates. Clearly, both in their public comments and in their actions, the foreign money dealers who have secured a vicious grip on the Australian economy were not impressed. There were calls for further cuts in expenditure and a freezing of wages, strategies which would destroy the accord. The abuse of power by some foreign dealers knows no bounds. They will not be satisfied until they have destroyed the Labor Government. Of course, they have been supported strongly by the extremist comments of the so-called New Right and their disgraceful apologists in the Liberal Party.

It is heartening to see that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in today's Melbourne Age has admitted that the Government has acted to set a minimum value to the Australian dollar through the use of the Reserve Bank. This is a course of action which many of us have been advocating, including the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). However, it may be necessary to introduce controls further to stabilise the currency, especially if foreign exchange dealers continue in their irresponsible fashion. As my colleague the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has said, there are a number of possible arrangements which can be adopted to stabilise the value of the dollar. The Government needs to explore these alternatives, especially the possibility of some controls on purely speculative capital flows.

Let me turn now to the first question: What happens if we do not achieve the 2 1/2 per cent growth in the economy and are faced with greater contraction in the economy, with increased unemployment? The Budget Papers are pessimistic about the possibility of our being able to achieve any sizable reduction in the huge balance of payments deficit. Furthermore, the Budget supposes that there will be no increase in domestic investment. The question that then arises is whether we are justified in abandoning the successful growth strategy for such a relatively modest outcome. Have we been hoodwinked by the conservative economic dogmas of the Treasury?

Rather than relying on traditional conservative solutions to the current account problem, we could have adopted an innovative series of measures which, on the one hand, would have allowed us to continue with the successful growth strategy and, on the other, attack the problem directly with more positive outcomes. Specifically, there are a number of things we could have done. For example, firstly, rather than continue to rely on the possibility that the devaluation will result in increased investment in manufacturing, a matter about which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has expressed considerable scepticism, we could have embarked on a large program of direct intervention to rebuild our industrial base. Instead of continuing to lecture sections of the private sector for their failure to invest, we could have put into place industry development measures such as direct government investment in new export industries and potentially viable import replacement industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does the money come from?
—We could also have given tax concessions-
—The Prime Minister wants to fight an election on tax but the honourable member for Calwell wants more taxation. Fantastic!

—I ask the honourable member not to interrupt. The Opposition is intellectually bankrupt and does not wish to have a serious debate. The only serious debate on the economy is engaged in by honourable members on this side of the House. If the honourable member is quiet he might learn something.

SPEECH.PARA: We could have given tax concessions for direct investment in new productive enterprises. This could have been paid for by a number of tax measures to discourage purely speculative activities that have been taking place throughout our economy over the past few years, especially in the form of takeovers. Secondly, contracting the economy by a $3,000m cut will reduce imports by only approximately $700m. This is a highly inefficient way of dealing with the problem of import penetration. Instead, we could have adopted direct controls on imports, either through the introduction of quota systems or by the imposition of a surcharge, especially on goods which we can produce relatively competitively in Australia. That was the approach adopted at the national conference. This would have put much greater pressure on both domestic and foreign corporations to invest in Australian production. A strong improvement in our trading and current account positions would have been achieved much more quickly. Thirdly, if we had adopted these measures, together with proposals to introduce some stabilisation of the currency, we would be in a position to meet our commitments to the poor and the unemployed. A higher level of government spending on welfare would have been possible. We would also have been able to avoid the problems of unjustified cuts in education and ethnic affairs.

I have set out some of the measures which could have been adopted to resolve our problems. The Government has chosen a different course. If, however, its strategy proves to be unsuccessful, we will be advocating strongly a change of direction, with the implementation of measures such as those I have outlined. In the meantime, the Government must adopt a more flexible attitude towards economic policy discussion. It is necessary for there to be a public discussion of proposals from all sides so that we may be able to achieve the goal we all want; namely, the reindustrialisation of Australia and a strong, healthy economy for all our people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, unfortunately a discussion between the Deputy Speaker-not yourself-and a member prevented me finishing a speech on regional television last Tuesday. I was midway through reading a Press release by the Australian Labor Party member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) criticising his own Government's policies on regional commercial television. I now complete my quotation of extracts from his release by reminding the House that the honourable member said that in view of Australia's balance of payments position `it would be irresponsible to encourage the importation of an additional $400m or more of overseas capital equipment'. He added the following two extracts:

SPEECH.PARA: The vast majority of regional broadcasters provide a first rate service to country viewers, and I am confident that most stations would provide a quality second signal until 1995 if given the opportunity . . . In the meantime, viewers in country and regional areas will gain additional choice and Australia's Balance of Payments will be at least $400m better off than it would otherwise be.

Labor's own member for Bendigo is absolutely correct. I explained on Tuesday how the policy will work and how devastating it will be for local employment, local advertising and local programming. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) tonight gave an excellent speech with which I completely concur. The judgment of the honourable member for Bendigo is shared not merely by the Opposition but also by media and economic experts.

The draft indicative plan produced by the Government is riddled with false assumptions and conclusions. It has shown all the hallmarks of a document which was designed to justify previously decided positions. For example, the draft indicative plan ignores the realities regarding potential increased revenue from advertising. In October 1985 Mr Bruce Cormack, who is the Federal Director of the Advertising Federation of Australia which represents the advertising agencies, told a Department of Communications conference in Sydney that advertising revenues would not rise by as much as the Department was predicting. Mr Cormack repeated those views in the publication Advertising News on 22 August 1986. His conclusion is clear, that the assumptions of the revenue growth in the draft indicative plan are simply wrong.

On Tuesday I illustrated to the House the problems of this policy by reference to the State of Victoria. I pointed out that the small market, Mildura, can trigger off an aggregation of Bendigo and Ballarat which is disadvantageous to the two larger ones, advantageous to the smaller, but overall guarantees that the smaller market will start taking network programs from Sydney and in due course the other two will be forced to do the same and eliminate local programming altogether because it would be too costly to produce. That means that under the Government's own policy a multi-channel service is not an option. There will be an automatic triggering of an aggregation in most markets.

To show that this is simply not a ploy by the Opposition I will quote some more, first from Mr Harold Mitchell in the publication Advertising News. Mr Harold Mitchell is a media consultant, a principal of a Melbourne media buying consultancy, Mitchell and Partners. He says the following devastating things:

The existing 24 markets will be reduced to six which will create tension in the regions rather than produce a highly developed commercial television system that suits both the operators and the viewers.

There is little doubt that the government through its various agencies has set the scene for only the big operators to survive. This does not mean necessarily the current owners but quite probably new companies.
It seems certain that a process of sellout and merging by current operators is about to take place.
In one swoop the government has thrown regional television stations to the wolves and allowed the metro operators into the regions almost overnight.
The way it will work is simple. The current stations will be forced by the trigger mechanism into aggregation in almost every market of the six new regions.

The trigger mechanism has been described elsewhere, but put simply, if only one station in each of the regions indicates that it wishes to telecast in another market then all other stations in that region have to do likewise.
In summary the government believed that advertising would grow in regional markets between 4 per cent and 9.2 per cent in real terms on an annual basis for the next eight years.
This is on top of inflation and suggests actual growth in some areas, assuming 9 per cent inflation could be up to 18 per cent per annum.
This is idiotic, meddlesome, centralised dogma of the worst kind.
I would be proud to have summed up the plan in such strong terms, but this is from a media expert with no vested interest whatsoever in the outcome of these policies. Mr Mitchell goes on:

The next five years are simple to forecast. The regional markets will be in a frenzy, and, led by the smaller stations in each market, will aggregate. This could well be started by the likes of Mildura (which has already commenced aggregation), Mackay and others.
All regional operators will be forced into heavy capital expenditure in a weakening advertising market.
They will be hard pressed, especially the new operators who have paid large sums of money for licences.

The cost of money is now very heavy in these dire economic circumstances forced on each of the regional operators, a white knight, or should I say three white knights, will appear on the hillside. They will be the major networks who will suggest an easy way out to each of the regional operators: `Why don't you hand all your television time over to us? We will sell it for you, give you a little bit of money back and you can go back and live on the farm.'
Overnight the new regional operators will be based in those wonderful regional towns of Willoughby, Artarmon and Nunawading.

There is another point I wish to make to the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham): It is only a matter of time under the new policies of his Government before not only regional culture within Australia but also Australian culture will disappear because the next step is broadcasting from Los Angeles. The technology is now there to do that, so the honour- able member should not be too smug about this. This is a serious issue. As the honourable member for Murray said, this will be a major issue in marginal seats. The honourable member for McMillan should have a look at his seat as it is a serious matter in his area as well.
Mr Cormack has a few things to say in the same publication from which I can quote only briefly now. In speaking about the cake not being big enough--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about competition?

—I will tell the honourable member a thing or two about competition. Until we have a country with a population size approaching that of the United States he cannot talk about comparisons between the United States and Australia of competition in areas such as television if he is serious about maintaining local programming and community interests. After listening to the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) one can see what a divided outfit this Government is. What a vastly different philosophy is being voiced now by the honourable member for Bendigo and others whom I have quoted. He has to face up to the words he has correctly uttered in that Press release. In the Advertising News Mr Cormack had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The matter we must now consider is what will happen to regional rate cards when there are three independent stations in a market?
We already have these facts, or probabilities:
There will be no population explosion to increase market size;
Total audience size, or viewing capacity, can change only slightly;
Total media budgets will not increase.
Conclusion: Audience fragmentation, leading to unacceptable rate cards, could drive advertisers out of regional television.
He says:
No. The cake is not big enough in our opinion. We would be delighted to be proved wrong-but no one has produced evidence to contradict this view.
Not one of the optimistic revenue predictions has been justified in market terms.

So here we have a media expert saying that the regional operators will go broke, and that is confirmed by a man representing advertising agencies. He even thinks that the advertising agencies may not think it worth while to be involved. I want to give a further quote tonight to show that this is not a political ploy by the Opposition, from another expert, Mr Hugh Mackay from the Centre for Communications Studies, which is based in rural New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —An eminent researcher.

—He is an eminent researcher, as the honourable member for Fadden says. Mr Mackay makes a very important comment on the socio-demographic aspects of the draft indicative plan. It has been described in many unflattering terms, but I will quote him because he is most eloquent on the subject. On 8 September this year he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Draft Indicative Plan also acknowledges that the idea of `community of interest' implies social and economic links between the communities which constitute an Approved Market . . .

Having examined the analyses, I have to say that I am positively astonished by their fundamental irrelevance to the process of establishing community of interest within Approved Markets. Indeed, I would go further: far from being ``the building blocks for such identification'', the socio-demographic analyses of Approved Markets actually prevent any possibility of determining homogeneity within AMs. They do not reveal community of interest: they conceal the ``building blocks'' within an aggregation of statistics which simply by-pass the whole question of homogeneity.

Let me explain precisely what I mean by the charge of irrelevance. In order to demonstrate a community of interest within an Approved Market, it would be necessary to give socio-demographic detail of each identifiable sub-group within that Market and then show that those sub-groups have so much in common that they constitute, in some sense, a community. I would be confident in suggesting that the people of Bathurst would have no sense of ``community of interest'' with the people of Newcastle or Griffith.
But, of course, the Government has placed them together in an aggregated viewing area. He said:

I doubt whether the devastation suffered by many Bathurst people in the recent floods was of any but passing concern to the people of Griffith or Newcastle. Nor can I imagine that recent soul-searching in the Griffith community over the Donald Mackay case or the recent murder of a child impinges on Bathurst, Orange, Maitland, Dubbo or Newcastle with anything like the intensity or sense of relevance which it has for the people in the Griffith region.

Such examples could be multiplied for every AM listed in the Draft Indicative Plan. It is simply not good enough to suggest that because shopping patterns maybe quite similar (corner stores for groceries, department stores for large items) or that the population visits major towns for medical, legal, or other professional help, this constitutes a ``community of interest'' . . . I simply make the point that the Draft Indicative Plan included virtually no data which impinges on the question of community of interest. It is true that very brief comments are made on such issues as shopping patterns, recreation and sport, and so on, yet, even here, the emphasis is on generalisations rather than on identifying patterns within local communities which would allow us to assess whether those communities share sufficient experiences, facilities, values and patterns of life to feel as though they comfortably fit into a larger community.
Mr Mackay, an expert on communication studies and socio-demographic factors, concluded:
The Draft Indicative Plan simply failed to address, in any of its statistical analysis, the question of homogeneity within Approved Markets.
He also stated:

At first glance, many of the Approved Markets would look as though they were extremely heterogeneous and that their aggregation into an Approved Market would be a matter of technical or other convenience rather than having any basis in social cohesion or socio-economic compatibility.

That being so, the Department of Communications may as well abandon the whole question of ``community of interest'' and admit that it is proceeding with ``equalisation'' of regional commercial television on technical, commercial, economic or political grounds.

As things stand, the question of homogeneity cannot be examined: the mass of statistical data in Part 3 of the Draft Indicative Plan neither confirms nor denies the assertion that AMs are based on a community of interest. The data are simply irrelevant to the assertion.

I conclude my remarks by confirming what the honourable member for Murray has already said. The Government has failed. It made no effort to find out what local people want. The consequence of its policy is immediate programming from Sydney with eventual programming from Los Angeles and an end of localism in the regions immediately and ultimately, unless we are very careful, in Australia itself.

We oppose the policies announced by the Government. We oppose the aggregation announced by it. We support the immediate issue of supplementary licences so that existing licence holders can provide diversity of programming-a genuine alternative program and a genuine choice, because the existing licence holder will not be in competition with itself and will not be chasing the major mass market. There will be complementary programming between the existing licence holder, the supplementary licence holder, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, which will give viewers a genuine choice.

We wish the NBN application for a writ of mandamus well. We hope that the supplementary licence succeeds. If the Government tries to frustrate that legal action by bringing in legislation to abandon supplementary licences, we will oppose it. If it is wise, the Government will back down for the good of Australia, culturally and in several other ways. The next step for us is to take the Government head on in any legislation which it now proposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —For many days now we have been debating Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I suppose that the Government expects some analysis and criticism of its policies on this occasion. We expect a degree of nitpicking, distortion and hyperbole, but above that, there was an expectation on this side of the House that, in view of the gravity of our economic circumstances, the Opposition would put forward some concrete suggestions, or perhaps a prescription for the future and a long term plan and vision. But what we have had from the Opposition-I suppose that we could only have expected it-is the short-sighted approach that it had in government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) suggested that if we returned the free lunch, the free car and the interest-free loan, we would solve all our problems. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) hitched his wagon to incentive-a policy that I would perhaps endorse. Indeed, this Government has done much to restore competitiveness in our economy and to provide fairness and incentive in our taxation system. But what was his prescription? He was going to cut public expenditure, yet today we have spent five hours debating two pieces of legislation. One after another, Opposition members have trooped in here complaining, groaning and moaning about these pieces of legislation. Who is going to be cut under those opposite, how and where will it be done and where will the savings be made? According to the member for Bennelong, a few statutory bodies will be done away with. There will also be the opportunity to opt out of Medicare. But it seems that he does not want to explain to the Australian people-those who choose to opt out-what that will mean in terms of their premiums for private health benefits. He does not want to explain to low-income families what that will mean with respect to a possible increase in the levy to pay for the increased utilisation by those in the system.

The honourable member for Bennelong suggested that there is a whole wish list of proposals for tax reform and decreasing taxation. These measures would cost $5.9 billion, and they include the introduction of a flat rate of tax, income splitting, the abolition of the fringe benefits tax, negative gearing, the abolition of capital gains tax, et cetera. But can we honestly say that we can believe the honourable member for Bennelong in these matters? I refer to a quote which has already been read in the House today, but which I think is very relevant:

Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash-as most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax, and thus effectively subsidise, those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds.

Is that a quote from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or perhaps the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? No, it is from the honourable member for Bennelong in 1980. He is very careful in his wording when he says time and again `We will remove Labor's fringe benefits tax', because he intends to replace it with his own. Why does he not tell the people of Australia that that is what he intends to do? If he intends to remove the fringe benefits tax and many of the other measures of this Government, does that mean that he will increase the marginal rate back to 60 cents after it has been reduced to 49 cents in the dollar? The people of Australia and the Government are entitled to ask him what he intends to do.

In industrial relations, the Opposition has vague policies without any substance at all. Does the Opposition intend, if it ever gets on the treasury bench again, to smash centralised wage-fixing, as it tried to do in 1981 and 1982, with a massive blow-out of wages? Does it not realise that the relativities that have been created by our devaluation provide us with a substantial advantage over most of our trading partners in terms of wage costs?

The Government, when it was elected, realised that economic management would be an important aspect of its government, and that perhaps it would live and die on economic management and its ability to succeed in that area. We had seen the neglect and lassitude of the Menzies Government. We had learnt from the mistakes of the Whitlam Government. We had observed the ineptitude of the Fraser years-the failure to grasp opportunity after opportunity. We believed that inappropriate policy and folly over a number of years had led to many structural problems within our economy. Ad nauseam, the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) talked about restructuring our economy, about the need for us to invest in brain-based industries and the need to take decisions. (Quorum formed)

The Budget needs to be viewed within the framework in which the Government came to office. At that time, we found ourselves faced with two principal problems. The first and the most immediate problem was that the economy was in recession. We had had negative growth, burgeoning inflation and unemployment, a projected deficit of $9.6 billion and industrial chaos. The growth strategy that the Government sought was effective. We created 630,000 new jobs. Inflation was cut. We had significant growth over a period. The accord allowed us, as no other industrial nation has been able to do over recent times, to climb out of a wage pause that had been placed on the workers of this country by the previous Administration. At the same time, we were able to cut deficits significantly.

The second problem that we faced-we realised it at the time-was much greater and the prescription for it was much more long term. The problem related to the basic imbalance in our economy, the fact that our primary industries-farming, mining and energy exports-were dying and their prospects were less than promising. Indeed, the manufacturing industry in this country was in a parlous state. It was uncompetitive and overprotected. There was an essential need for Australia to become competitive and for it to review its structural problems. The Government set about putting in place the fundamentals to do that.

The first and the most important decision taken was to float the Australian dollar. We decided that Australia must become part of a world economy and that it must become internationally competitive. It was a brave decision and a decision that the Opposition, in government, could have taken at any time but chose not to do. It is that decision, perhaps more than any other, that has given us the best chance to face up to the problems that existed in our economy. In the area of wages policy, the accord brought about a period of responsible economic and industrial outcomes. There has been a 7 per cent decline in unit labour costs. Disputation is at its lowest level for two decades. At the same time, in a period of significant growth, the accord proved to be a very flexible instrument of policy.

Thirdly, we set about reforming taxation. We were aware that oppressive marginal rates were a disincentive. We were aware that double taxation on dividends was a disincentive. We were aware that there was a great need to improve the fairness of our taxation system, that money would be directed more to productive areas by the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, a tax on capital gains, and the abolition of negative gearing. It was no longer possible for those tax havens to underpin those areas of our industry. The Government also embarked on industry plans and developed plans for the car industry, the heavy engineering industry and the steel industry. Presently, it is looking at the clothing and textiles industry. In addition, there was a significant freeing up of the financial markets.

In the 1950s and 1960s we took the easy path. We said `She'll be right' and hoped that the sheep's back would provide the answer to our problems. We did not take opportunities to develop manufacturing. The National Party threw around tariffs and bounties like confetti at a wedding. From 1953 to 1983, we moved from the eighth to the twenty-third largest exporting nation in the world. In the 1970s and 1980s, inflation and wages grew out of step with the rest of the world. We looked for the quick solutions. We did not come to grips with the fundamentals. Sooner or later we had to come to the crossroads. Perhaps the floating of the dollar and its subsequent depreciation has wiped the slate clean for Australia. Perhaps it provides us with our best opportunity.

In an article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, Ross Gittins provided some information on an index of international labour costs per hour for Australia. The information, which was provided by the ANZ Bank, shows that, if one considers Australia as 100 units, comparatively, the cost of labour per hour in the United States of America is 133 units; in the United Kingdom, 141 units; in Germany, 149 units; in Japan, 154 units; in France, 200 units; and in Switzerland, 248 units.

Australia is very competitive internationally. We must grasp this opportunity. It will not be easy. The terms of trade will not turn around suddenly. There will not be any quick solutions. The reindustrialisation of this country will take time. What is important is that this Government has put the fundamentals in place to deal with those structural problems.

Our opponents are looking for their best prospects of getting into government. They believe that those will come about by a decline in our economy. I do not think that they are really aware of how to attack the structural difficulties that we face. This Government has attacked those difficulties. We have restored our competitive edge and we are determined to preserve it. We are determined to take the opportunity that it allows us to take.

There are immediate opportunities in the services industry. Tourism is one that comes quickly to mind. In manufacturing, those changes will take time. The Budget has been framed to allow Australia to take advantage of the fundamentals that we have put in place. It has been accepted overwhelmingly by the Australian people. The Australian of 27 August states that 57 per cent of Australians say that the Budget is good and only 25 per cent say that it is bad. Of coalition supporters, more thought it was good than bad. Even Moody's Investor Services Inc, when it rapped Australia on the knuckles over the international situation and our external debt position, endorsed the domestic Budget strategy. I confidently add my endorsement to its endorsement and I reject the claims of the Opposition. The people of Australia have overwhelmingly accepted this Budget. A former member of the coalition Government, John Hyde, has accepted that the economic management of this Government has been better than his. Indeed, I confidently add my endorsement and reject the claims of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to spend the brief time available to me in discussing one particular portfolio, the Department of Communications. I too would like to direct my comments towards the draft indicative plan for future television development in this country. We have heard a couple of speeches tonight outlining some of the very real difficulties that will face Australia if this plan comes to fruition. There is no doubt that the communications area is one of the most dynamic areas of our society today. While I admit that there are changing aspects of the technical developments in that area almost daily, it would seem that this Government can change its policies almost daily too. I would like to cite as an example of that the government publication of June 1985, the forward development report for the future of television. On page 26, of volume I the Government in fact, just over 12 months ago, spelt out its policy for the future development of radio and television in this country. The Government said, and rightly so at that stage, that it had five major broadcasting policy objectives. It wanted to maximise the diversity of choice, maintain viability of the broadcasting system, encourage Australian production and employment, encourage localism, and discourage the concentration of media ownership and control of stations. So what happened? In about 12 months in came the draft indicative plan that threw all those admirable propositions out the window. By doing that, of course, the Government put into jeopardy the very future of commercial television in the non-metropolitan areas of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I bring this to the attention of the House especially during this Budget debate because the cost involved to the taxpayer is not going to be inconsiderable. The cost effect on our balance of payments is going to be quite horrific. It is very interesting to read this report and to look at some of the figures that have been put up by the members of the Department who undertook that report. We have heard amply tonight what that plan means in terms of aggregating these areas into virtually three networks. In this report, which was released on 17 July this year, it was said that this particular aggregation process would cost the networks some $389m.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Some $389m. What has not been brought to light at this stage is the fact that that was said on 17 July when the yen stood at 162 to the Australian dollar. The facts of the situation are now, of course, that the equipment that is going to be used in the aggregation process will be brought in from Japan. If we look at today's exchange rate we see that it is 94 yen to the dollar. If we do a quick calculation, that quoted cost of aggregation to the regional television networks is no longer $389m but in fact $650m. At a time when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is terribly concerned about Australia's balance of payments it would seem to me to be absolutely crazy to be proceeding with a plan like this.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) really has to answer some questions. He has to ask himself why, suddenly, there is this rush to get into aggregation. Why is there this rush when we already have the capacity to provide people in regional Australia with a diversity and a choice of television programs purely through the supplementary licence system? That system is cheap and quick and it would be only a matter of months before we could provide the people of regional Australia with choice. We have to ask why suddenly we have this rush. Why suddenly have those propositions for multi-channel services in regional Australia been thrown out the window, especially when it was only a couple of months ago that the Minister for Communications quite rightly put forward that proposition? Why was the Minister for Communications rolled in Cabinet by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? What is the Prime Minister's real reason for trying to rush this into the country areas of Australia? We already know why that is happening. It is happening purely so that we can have a dominance of the major metropolitan stations across Australia. We must ask ourselves: What is the deal the Prime Minister has done with the major networks? We must also ask ourselves: On what basis were these particular regional areas put in together so that aggregation could go ahead? There is no doubt that it will go ahead.

I turn to the Minister's report on those areas. The report was interesting because one of the things that came out was the statement that has been brought up time and time again that one million people are needed to support three commercial television stations in any one area. That was used recently in Perth as the basis for a very real argument, yet suddenly we have these aggregated areas in Australia. It really is most remarkable. I turn to my own State of Queensland. The proposal for north Queensland includes stations in Townsville, Cairns, Mackay and Rockhampton, with a total population of 505,000 people. What is not mentioned is that if we take the tip of the viewing area of FNQ, which is the station in Cairns, and work it down to the southernmost regions of RTQ, the station in Rockhampton, that covers a distance of 1,400 kilometres, which is greater than the distance from Sydney to Adelaide. There is absolutely no community of interest in that. As we have already had other cases cited tonight I will not go into them, but I fail to see what effect the news from Atherton will have on the people of Rockhampton and further south. We go to southern Queensland and look at that aggregated area covering Maryborough, Toowoomba and Warwick, with a total population of 417,000 people, bearing in mind that we need one million people to support three commercial television stations. Let us turn to northern New South Wales, where Tamworth, Taree, Lismore and Coffs Harbour have a total population of 646,000. Let us then go to central New South Wales and Newcastle, Orange, Dubbo and Griffith, with a total population of 911,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would they want them there?

—The Government wants them to be the subservient tools of the major networks, and that is what worries me. It really throws out that whole concept of localism. I will get back to that later. I want to put these figures on the record because on all the available information there is no viable reason whatsoever for aggregation. Let us go to southern New South Wales-Wollongong, Canberra, Wagga Wagga and Albury, with a total population of 887,000. In Victoria, the area covering Mildura, Ballarat, Bendigo, Shepparton and Traralgon, has a total population of 823,000. Not one of those proposed aggregated markets contains a million people and the only one that gets close to it is that based at Newcastle, which has 911,000 people. So in terms of viability, it just cannot work.

SPEECH.PARA: What effect will it have on regional Australia? What effect is aggregation going to have on those many hundreds of people who are presently employed in regional television? What effect will it have on the 111 journalists who are employed in regional television newsrooms? This is an important point. The projections show that it is not possible for the regional stations to make a profit under these aggregated proposals. It will not be possible for them to maintain a large staff. We have already admitted that localism is going out the window. So when this is introduced 111 journalists will be without a job. One wonders what the Australian Journalists Association, one of the strongest unions in Australia, is saying about that proposition. We have not heard too much yet, but we can rest assured that as soon as this comes in there will be 111 regional television journalists looking for a job. There is no doubt that there has not been any consultation with the regional areas in devising this proposal.

We also hear that we are going to have changes in the future ownership of television in Australia. Does that mean, too, that we will make it legal to have this huge concentration of ownership by the present three major networks cast across the whole of Australia? We know that there will be a decrease in staff. We know that the equipment that must be brought in for aggregation has to be imported from Japan. We want to know what is wrong with the present legislation. We want to know why we cannot have a supplementary licence system to give those people in rural Australia very real choice.

Let us look at the facts of providing three network stations in all of the markets around Australia. Government members should do the small exercise of looking at the program guides for channels 7, 9 and 10 for last Christmas. The only non-repeat programs that went to air in the month over Christmas were the news and the cricket. Every other program that was put to air by the three networks was a repeat. Yet the Government says that it will give country people a choice. At least under the supplementary licence system the stations would certainly have the capacity to bring in the best of the available programs of the three networks. That is an absolute fact. So the whole story of being able to provide greater choice, frankly, is not true. I feel very sorry for the Minister for Communications because in this situation he has been rolled.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you know?

—We must ask ourselves why we are destroying an industry which provides a very real service to regional Australia, why we are destroying the capacity of local communities in Australia to have their own local news services--
—How do you know?
—Why will 111 journalists be thrown out of work?
—You would not understand.
—The honourable member for Aston will please cease interjecting.

—He is quite an interesting fellow, Mr Deputy Speaker. I believe he has many endearing qualities. It is a pity that intelligence is not one of them. We must get to the stage of being even more far-sighted in terms of future development in the electronic media. The rapid development that is happening now in fibre optics and international transmissions could mean that these tremendous investments-in today's dollar figures, they are worth probably about $650m-are all for nought because of the tremendous technical developments that are taking place at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge Government back benchers to put as much pressure as they can on the Prime Minister. I urge the Minister for Communications to take up his fight once again with the Prime Minister to have all this craziness thrown out the door. Let us get back to a bit of rationality and let us make sure that we give the people of regional Australia real choice in television programs, but not at a cost that will send those regional stations under.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a few remarks to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull). At one stage he asked: What is wrong with the current position? I will tell him what is wrong with the current position.
—The Labor Government.

—People who live in the electorate of Cowper have access to only one commercial television station. The Labor Government wants them to have more choice by giving them three commercial television stations as soon as possible. Honourable members opposite were in government for seven years and regional Australia got nothing. The existing commercial networks had a monopoly. Honourable members opposite were not in favour of giving greater choice to the people in regional Australia through competition.
—And we are satisfied.

—The honourable member for Mallee says that he has been satisfied with the current system. I would be very interested, if a poll were taken in his electorate, to find out whether any of his constituents did not want two additional commercial channels.

SPEECH.PARA: A great Australian, Gough Whitlam, claimed in 1972 that there were times in the history of every country when a single decision of the electors could influence the country's future for many years. He was correct in predicting that the Australian people's decision on 2 December 1972 would close forever the era of dull, tired and uninspired leadership which was provided by the Liberal and National parties. I believe that, as was the case in 1972, when the next election is held-whenever that may be-it will be crucial in determining the future of this country for many years to come. The Labor Government faces a difficult task in lifting Australia out of a balance of payments crisis which has been caused by a decline in the prices which we receive for our export commodities.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no better government to do it.

—As the honourable member for Chisholm suggests, no government is better equipped to handle that problem. As each day passes, the Opposition offers more and more extremist policies which are alien to Australians and generate nothing but division and confrontation. We should not forget that the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer during the Fraser years. What did the previous Government offer the people of Australia? It offered lower economic growth, higher unemployment, more bankruptcies, higher inflation and record levels of tax avoidance and evasion. In my view, world economic growth is a very good measure of the health of any economy, particularly Australia's. It is the rate of growth and total national income after one has allowed for inflation. In many ways, it is the rate of growth in the national cake which must then be divided amongst the community. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have a table incorporated in Hansard. It was checked by the shadow Minister who was in the chamber previously.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
