TALK.START.PARA: —The table demonstrates that in the last three years in which the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer Australia had an average real economic growth rate of only 1.4 per cent. In the Hawke Government's first three years in office-with the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) as Treasurer-it has produced an average of 4.5 per cent for real economic growth. That figure should be compared with the measly figure of 1.4 per cent in the last three years in which the present Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer. In fact, in his last year as Treasurer of this country we had a decline, a fall-back, of 11.1 per cent-a disgraceful result.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of this record, I think it is quite interesting that the Opposition is seeking to distance itself as far as possible from its dismal record when it was in government. It is seeking to show that the leopard has changed its spots, that it is not the same Liberal and National parties which failed to deliver and which destroyed the Australian economy. It would like us to forget that the current Leader of the Opposition was the Treasurer who offered us the fistful of dollars in 1977, then took them away in the following Budget. He promised tax indexation and failed to deliver that promise also. He said he would apply a temporary income tax surcharge which would last for only 12 months; yet, when the 12 months were up, unfortunately the then Treasurer, Honest John, had to retract his promise to remove the temporary income tax surcharge. He delivered the biggest recession that this country has had since the Great Depression.

In my view, the fringe benefits tax provides a great example of the stark alternative offered by this Government to the conservatives opposite. We have seen in the last five years a rapid expansion in the number of executives and employees on very senior salaries who receive fringe benefits tax free. While lower and middle income earners have all of their income shown on their group certificates at the end of the year, senior executives and top income earners do not have all of their income shown on their group certificates. They do not pay tax on the company car which they are allowed to use for private use. They do not pay tax on the club membership which the employer pays for. They do not pay tax on the holidays for their families which are provided by the employer. They do not pay tax on the credit cards which the company pays for, and they do not pay tax on the health insurance which is also paid for by their bosses. This Government, like the New Zealand Government, has come to the conclusion that the easiest and most efficient way to treat everyone fairly and to tax all of the income of employees is to apply a fringe benefits tax on the employer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe that is fair?

—I believe it is very fair and very efficient. I will come back to that point in a moment. The fringe benefits tax will raise $310m in a full financial year. That $310m will go towards the income tax cuts which the Government is providing from 1 December this year. In addition, by eliminating tax deductibility for entertainment expenses, we will claw in another $300m. I do not believe that such expenses should be a tax deduction for companies.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to read an article in the Australian Financial Review after the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) addressed the National Press Club shortly after the Budget was brought down. The headline of the article is `Back to the old on incomes and lunches get a break'. The article reads:

The Federal Opposition's Treasury spokesman, Mr Jim Carlton, yesterday extended the new spartan tax commitments of his leader, Mr John Howard, by suggesting that business lunches would be tax deductible.
Mr Carlton, delivering a post-Budget speech to the National Press Club, said that if business lunches were legitimate working expenses, they would be tax deductible.
Whether they were legitimate could be determined by `administrative mechanisms', he said but declined to give details.

TALK.START.PARA: —The log book of entertainment.

—As the honourable member for Chifley suggests, the log book of entertainment. Perhaps people should fill out a log book when they are taken out to lunch. The honourable member for Mackellar went on to say that he believed that the fringe benefits tax should not be implied to the employer; it should hit employees. The honourable member for Mackellar is proposing the establishment of a crazy bureaucracy which would seek to keep track of every business lunch to seek to determine whether it was a legitimate business lunch through some vague, administrative mechanism. We can imagine how many thousands of public servants would be needed to keep track of everyone's business lunches. I am sure the public servants would not object if they got a seat at the table. I consider that to be nothing but a total administrative nightmare. The honourable member for Mackellar is not the only person who wants to make employees pay tax on their fringe benefits. Mr Bob Ansett, head of the Budget company, has been very prominent in newspaper campaigns in suggesting that his employees, not Budget, should pay the extra tax. I was interested in an article in the Australian of 12 August headlined `Ansett confident of driving through perks tax loophole'. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most vocal opponents of the fringe benefits tax believes he has found a loophole to avoid payment.
Car rental chief Mr Bob Ansett, who has been heading the Axe The Tax campaign said yesterday that this company, Budget, was `putting its affairs in order so liability has been removed'.
He refused to give details of what methods he would be using, but said that for the tax to be levied `you've got to be able to prove liability'.

I believe that Mr Ansett also wants his employees to pay the tax. I can imagine the additional staff who would have to be employed in the Australian Taxation Office if this Government ordered every employee to determine whether he or she had received tax free fringe benefits. It is obviously much more efficient to do audits on employers to examine whether tax free fringe benefits have been left off group certificates. While I am on the subject of tax and Mr Ansett, I would be very interested to know who has paid for the `Axe The Tax' advertisements which must have cost a fortune and have been run in many newspapers across the country. If Mr Ansett's company-Budget Rent a Car System Pty Ltd-paid for the advertisements I would be very interested to know whether Budget will seek to claim the cost as a tax deduction. If it does, Mr Ansett, by running these advertisements in newspapers and gaining a lot of cheap publicity, has made every Australian taxpayer pay for 49 per cent of them because that is the appropriate rate of tax on companies. Recently the Australian Financial Review had an excellent editorial on the fringe benefits tax. It was headed `Hypocrisy and whingeing about the FBT' and stated:
The campaign against the fringe benefit tax is typical of much that is wrong with this country.

The fringe benefit tax is a method of reducing tax evasion, as part of a broad tax reform aimed at producing more equity and fewer rorts, and improving incentive for effort by getting the top marginal income tax rate down below 50 per cent.

The editorial went on to state that while Australian businesses have been bellyaching about the fringe benefits tax New Zealand is now exporting more to Australia than Australia is exporting to New Zealand. The Australian Financial Review editorial commented, quite correctly:
Fringe benefit taxes are now well established in New Zealand. While Australian business people whinge, New Zealanders are getting on with business and taking their markets.

That is a very appropriate comment which some prominent businessmen, perhaps even the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) could investigate. I consider it an excellent editorial. As I have said, the fringe benefits tax will provide $300m which will help finance the $4.5 billion tax cuts which the Government will provide by July 1987. It is the most radical restructuring of income tax rates since World War II. I know that all honourable members on this side of the House endorse them completely.

Before I conclude tonight, I draw the attention of the House to the level of Commonwealth general revenue assistance to local councils in my electorate. As all honourable members would be aware three councils are included in the electorate of Dobell-Gosford, Lake Macquarie and Wyong. I was interested to learn that Wyong Shire received an increase of 13 per cent in its general revenue assistance but the other councils-Gosford and Lake Macquarie-received only 12.2 per cent and 10.7 per cent respectively. Until last night a very close friend of mine-Councillor Tony Sheridan-was the President of Wyong Shire. He personally is largely responsible, through his hard work and dedication, for Wyong Shire receiving a larger than average increase in funding for local government. For the interests of the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), after some particularly nasty local government wheeling and dealing-the less said about that the better-Councillor Sheridan unfortunately failed to receive a majority of the votes on Wyong Shire for the first time in three years. As has happened several times before he failed in a draw from the hat. I am sure that Councillor Sheridan will return to the shire presidency in 12 months time and that his next term in office will be even longer and more productive for the local residents of Wyong Shire.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the Leader of the National Party of Australia, rising on a matter of privilege, referred to a letter sent to the President of the Parliamentary Press Gallery concerning the behaviour of journalists at the main entrance to Parliament House. The issue raised by the right honourable gentleman is not a matter of either privilege or contempt as such: Rather it is a matter of parliamentary administration.

INTERJECT.PARA: I wish to provide the House with some background on this matter. I understand that the President of the Press Gallery was advised by the Security Controller some months ago of problems in relation to the behaviour of media personnel in the area of the front steps and that a request from the President to the offending members of the gallery to observe long standing Press Gallery rules-developed in co-operation with gallery representatives-was ignored. These rules state that television cameramen should avoid using the centre area of the landing and the steps outside the front entrance for the purpose of interviewing members or others. I believe that the vast majority of members of the media who operate within Parliament House are responsible and observe the rules that have been set down over years by the Presiding Officers in conjunction with the Press Gallery.

On 14 August the President and I wrote to the President of the Press Gallery complaining about the general behaviour of journalists and cameramen in the vicinity of the main entrance. For example, on one occasion members of the Press Gallery were observed playing with a football on the front steps and when asked by an attendant to desist, became abusive. Coffee cups and newspapers have also been left on the front steps by members of the Gallery.

On 11 September 1986 the Acting Security Controller wrote to the President of the Press Gallery expressing concern that rubbish had again been left in clear view on the front steps of Parliament House on 8 September, the day of a visit by the Vice-Premier of China, Mr Wan Li. The letter sought assistance in ensuring that, in future, members of the Press refrain from littering the front steps.

On 17 September Mr President and I wrote to the President of the Gallery again expressing concern at the behaviour of journalists at the main entrance. Our letter did say that we found the behaviour totally unacceptable and a poor reflection on the Parliament. We went on to say that if such behaviour recurred we would have no alternative but to ban all journalists and camera crews from waiting or conducting interviews on the steps. The right honourable member expressed concern at this part of the letter in particular and asked in what circumstances a prohibition would be enforced.

The letters I have mentioned are but the most recent expressions of concern Mr President and I have had about these matters for some time. We have received complaints from honourable members and the public about littering and also about access being impeded by media representatives. It is no exaggeration to say that there have been numerous grounds for complaint.

I would hope that all members would share the concern that Mr President and I have to maintain standards in these matters. The House may be well assured that we have no desire whatsoever to impede or frustrate the workings of the media. We have a responsibility, however, to ensure that the activities of the media within the building and its precincts are not such as would impede members or others, including visitors to parliament, or reflect poorly on the institution. Should media behaviour breach these entirely reasonable requirements, we would be bound to intervene. However it is our sincere hope that this would not be necessary. I table copies of the three letters to which I have referred, together with a copy of the Press Gallery rules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek your indulgence, Madam Speaker, to comment briefly on the statement you have just made. I thank you for your comments. I say initially that I do not think any member of this House or indeed, I guess, of the other place would endorse the sorts of activities to which your comments were addressed and about which I gather there have been complaints. However, from my personal experience I have found those who have gathered both outside the front steps and in other places around this chamber always to have been quite without reproach. As one who has come and gone and been interviewed by them, not always in circumstances where I have appreciated it, I believe that they are a very important part of the functioning of this chamber and, while we on this side of the House would seek to support you in ensuring that they do not either litter or abuse their privilege, we would be most concerned if the opportunity that there is for them to interview members as they come and go were to be denied them.

SPEECH.PARA: In that respect in your second paragraph, Madam Speaker, you assert that it is rather a matter of parliamentary administration. I note that interpretation. Perhaps-I do not wish at this stage necessarily to differ with you-it is a matter of interpretation and it would concern us only if parliamentarians were to find that they were not able to meet any media in the area referred to, as it is to a degree in the public place, although I accept that it is in the precincts. I note your judgment, Madam Speaker. If there were to be any further action taken that is perhaps a matter which we hope that you would consider in the light of the absolute necessity in a democracy for people to be able to meet and interview the media and, in my view, for the media to be able to meet and interview members, including the Prime Minister, on any occasion they might seek to do so as they come to and leave this place.

I note that you certainly have commented that media behaviour should meet reasonable requirements. I hope that those who are in the gallery take note of your admonition. For our part, while we endorse your remarks in that respect, we certainly believe that it is essential that opportunities for meeting and being interviewed by the Press Gallery be preserved to the maximum. However, Madam, as a matter of standards we were disappointed that when the House resumed at 8 o'clock tonight neither your nor any of your representatives were in the chair. We expect the same standard of concern for the conduct of this affair from you and your deputies as there is from those in the gallery. I know that circumstances can intervene, but my colleague who was on duty in this place found that there was nobody in the chair at 8 o'clock and it was only fortunate that a Deputy Speaker happened to be in the House and the House was able to resume at all.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) for his comments and his support in ensuring that the standards of this House are met. May I point out to the Leader of the National Party that one of the rules agreed to by the President of the parliamentary Press Gallery on behalf of the Press Gallery and in conjunction with the Presiding Officers is that television cameramen should avoid using the centre area of the landing and the steps outside the front entrance to the building for the purpose of interviewing members of the Parliament or other persons. It has been the habit in years past for this to be observed. I think the Leader of the National Party himself has expressed concern in the past that visitors and members can be impeded in attempting to see one another or visiting their own members within the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: In regard to my being late tonight, I am sure that the Leader of the National Party has not always been on time himself. I extend my apologies to the House. I had an important engagement outside the House and unfortunately my deputy was held up in the traffic. I think the House will understand these things without too much being made of them.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This 1986 Budget is a disaster. It is a tragedy that, at a time when our nation was demanding leadership and a reduction in the cost and burden of government and was crying out for an opportunity and encouragement to use our human and natural resources to pull Australia out of a severe economic downturn, none of these demands were met. The political commentators generally got the Budget all wrong. How the discussions changed a few days later when the economic analysts saw what we in the Opposition already knew. It was just another Labor Budget. The deficit was to be lower, but at the expense of national programs and by increases in taxation and massive penalties to our productive sector.

SPEECH.PARA: It is often said that a week in politics is a long time. The three weeks that this Government gave itself to sell the Budget must have seemed like an eternity. Everything has gone wrong. Indecision, policy reversals and broken promises have not just destroyed the Government's credibility in the electorate but have also created massive divisions within the Parliamentary Labor Party and its rank and file. Its members are now totally disillusioned, frustrated and betrayed.

The credibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been destroyed over the past 12 months. This Budget simply nails down the lid on any future for the Australian Labor Party in office. This Prime Minister, his world's best Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his Cabinet have provided a Budget which is big spending with handouts for anyone with a loud voice, but which is a total failure in meeting the primary task of government. Labor governments have always assumed that they know best and should dictate to society what they believe is necessary and not respond to the cries of the people who are fed up with high interest rates, high taxes and high debts. It is a tragedy to see that this nation has not been able to maintain funds for its research effort or its aid programs. It is a tragedy to see that our education effort has been reduced, that thousands of applicants cannot obtain tertiary education admissions and that our defence infrastructure has been run down. It is a tragedy that nothing has been done to encourage private employers to take on more employees at a time when those supported by government, in other words, by the taxpayer, have for the first time become a larger sector in our economy that those in private employment.

At the same time, none of the Government's sacred policy cows, based on its socialist philosophical commitment, have suffered. The Government continues, in the words of one commentator `on its ideological pleasure cruise'. Hundreds of millions of dollars are still being squandered on groups and organisations in a frivolous way. Taxpayers' money goes down the plughole to story-tellers and mural artists in residence for trade unions so they can plaster our urban environment with Norm Gallagher posters and graffiti.

I have listened to my colleagues on the other side of the House with interest as they endeavour to justify their Government's action in the midst of public outrage, concern and pessimism. How excited each one of them becomes when he finds some new and increased area of expenditure to hang his hat on. They should re-examine their priorities. Not one Government member has attempted to justify and explain the effect of the increased taxes and the decline in this nation's commitment to its real responsibility in the areas of education, health and production. I turn now to these areas and particularly to the Budget's impact on my rural electorate of Mallee, one of Australia's great agricultural and productive regions.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great electorate.

—It is a tremendous electorate, and one that is going through some severe difficulties; but we will get out of them. In these rural electorates, despite the devaluation of our dollar and despite the loss of our high credit rating, we now find ourselves in a non-competitive position with all our world competitors. The Government, and particularly the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), have concentrated their attacks on other trading nations and the protective barriers imposed against our exports. This is an important part of our problem and one that Australian governments should try to influence. But we all know that it will have minimal impact. The real area of Government action is the domestic scene-to reduce the cost burdens on all its citizens-
—We have done that.
—To cut out waste-
—We have done that.
—To reduce public expenditure-
—We have done that.

—And to remove all forms of restrictive work practices-the Government has not done that-and bureaucratic red tape. In this area the Government has failed. Let us look at some of these aspects. The cost of fuel has leapt. In just a few months, through indexation and greed, excise has gone from 6c a litre to 24c a litre.
—Not diesel.

—I remind the House that all this is from a Prime Minister who promised a 3c reduction. Not diesel, says the honourable member. The latest sleight of hand increase in the price of diesel of 5.8c per litre is just another example in a long series of policy actions that have rapidly increased farm costs to a sector struggling to maintain its viability. Let us look at the comparative position in this respect with the United States of America. In the United States, costs have gone up 22 per cent while their returns have gone up 60 per cent. In Australia the opposite is the case. Australia's primary industry costs have gone up 55 per cent while our returns have gone down 20 per cent. This recent change, which the honourable member for McMillan said has added nothing to diesel fuel costs, in fact has added another $76m to the $715m in increased costs in the fuel area in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: It is incongruous that, in a nation that is so dependent on rural export income, we are now the highest fuel taxed nation in the world, although we are self-sufficient in oil products. For the broad acre cereal producing industries in the Mallee and the Wimmera, this imposes a further threat to their viability. While this is going on, of course, the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Treasurer have crowed about how an additional two and a half billion dollars profit was made on our money through exchange rate transactions, at the same time keeping interest rates up to support the sick dollar. It is equally farcical for the Prime Minister to call on Australians to buy Australian on the one hand, but then tax Australian products out of the market on the other hand. Not only is the Government taking products out of the market, as the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) just said, but also it is driving money out of Australia, off-shore into more favourable investment opportunities. There was simply no justice or reason to impose increased sales taxes on wine or a sales tax for the first time on flavoured milk and fruit juices. It is a scandal. Why has there been this conscious and consistent attempt to strangle these industries?

The paradox is that, as programs such as vine-pull schemes are expanded, taxes and further high taxes are being levied on our horticultural industries to get the cash to pay for them. These industries need incentives to export and to improve the quality of their products, the financial capacity to diversify, and, of course, the removal of restrictive trading practices, both at home and abroad; not further cost burdens. We read yesterday of the attack in the Senate by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) on the National Farmers Federation, while that Federation and the farming community it represents are doing their best to survive.

What about our regional services? Perhaps there is no more important area of government responsibility than health. Yet we see Medicare levies increasing, the removal of the Commonwealth bed subsidy from our bush nursing hospitals, which is going to drive them into bankruptcy, and the proposed increases in private health insurance. These acts of discrimination and injustice must be overturned, and when the coalition parties get back into government, we will do it.

This Government, in its grovelling before the big three in communications, is squeezing to death our regional television and radio services. The regional Australian Broadcasting Corporation services are now under threat and the importance of localism, news and programming is being discarded to satisfy these big networks. The unchecked power of the electronic media could well become the greatest tyranny in our history. Our viewing may even be controlled and transmitted from sources outside this country in the near future.

Sadly, this Government, despite the rhetoric and the declaration of war by the Prime Minister, has dodged the real challenge to do something about our economic difficulties. He has not faced up to the clear fact that our welfare state has outgrown our capacity to pay, that there is a deplorable lack of investment incentives, that our wage fixing system is irrelevant, that tax is crippling and that there is now a general lack of competitiveness. In this Budget the Government has not cut anything; it has just kept putting taxes up. To those who want to work and who still have some belief in the work ethic, the Government has said that it does not care. The fringe benefits tax, the assets test and the capital gains tax long ago sank this Hawke Government. I remind the House that it will also sink the Australian Democrats as it plays around with this Government's Budget in small areas. The electorate will not forget the action it took in regard to the Bill of Rights, the fringe benefits tax, the assets test and the capital gains tax-taxes it could have stopped, but taxes which it has allowed to be imposed on the Australian community.

This Budget, therefore, ensures that even those hard core Australian Labor Party voters will desert the ship, as the Government has not even had the courage to adhere, as many of its own members agree, to its own principles and policies. We on this side of the House condemn the Government for the failure of the Budget to tackle Australia's fundamental economic problems. We condemn the Budget for the record and rising level of overseas debt that now is $6,000 for every man, woman and child in this country and which is rising at $26,000, a minute. We condemn the Government for its excessively high levels of government spending and taxation, for an inflation rate four times the average of our major trading partners and interest rates that once again approach 20 per cent. In fact, short term interest rates in Australia at this time are 17.4 per cent, while amongst our major competitors the rate for Japan is 4.7 per cent and for the United States of America it is 5.6 per cent.

We condemn the Government for this Budget and for its wage policy that does not take account of the capacity of individual enterprises to pay and the pernicious effect of the anti-business, anti-investment taxes such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's anti-Australian.

—It is anti-Australian. It is seen to be particularly anti-Australian when we recognise that our world's best Treasurer has ensured that, for the first time, Australia has lost its AAA rating of international credit following the failure of this Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Ms H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was fascinating to hear the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) carry on in his usual fashion in saying that, if we do not pay tax and we do not pay pensioners the pensions they need, we will all get on a lot better. That is a most extraordinary thing to say; yet that is what we have been listening to for the last few minutes. What a pity it is that we do not have an Opposition that has a policy. We do not have an Opposition that has any kind of planning for the future of Australia. We simply have an Opposition that wants to whinge. Honourable members of the National Party of Australia are not alone in that-they are joined by their friends in the Liberal Party of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This fourth Budget of the Labor Government continues a major thrust of our policy; that is, to provide responsible economic management while at the same time expanding into areas of need-government services and benefits. The Government, as part of its strategy of deficit reduction and providing for identified areas of need, has not taken the easy options available of cutting government expenditure by simply ignoring long-felt community and personal needs, continuing present programs at a reduced level and continuing new funding to groups able to produce a positive political advantage. We are all too familiar with that strategy, as applied by the previous Government to the detriment of the Australian people.

This Budget, as with previous Budgets of this Government, has embedded in it provisions which are the results of long-term planning and the reviews that have examined the efficiency and effectiveness of existing policies and strategies, identified areas of need not previously addressed and considered the long term effect of policies. Each year our Budget has put into place a more effective government operation. We have considered not just one year, but the needs of years ahead, while addressing the contemporary problems and necessities. Even in this year of great restraint and zero growth in government expenditure, new programs have been funded through the internal adjustment of expenditure. To name just a few, we have provided for 3,000 extra higher education places and 3,000 occasional child care places; we have put a ceiling on the pharmaceutical costs of the chronically ill, increased the allocation for soil conservation, continued the rationalisation and upgrading of some youth allowances, provided new services under the home and community care program; and, in the defence budget, funds are allocated to complete the project definition study of the new submarine-a project of great importance to Australian industry.

Underpinning the Government's ability to reduce the deficit and provide for the needs of a range of groups is the operation of the accord. In spite of the apparent eagerness of some journalists, economic commentators and politically motivated individuals to see the end of the accord, the facts speak for themselves. Wage and salary earners, responsible Australians, have through their unions accepted a real 4 to 5 per cent wage cut at a time when profits have risen substantially. In no other country has such an outcome been possible. It is workers' restraint and responsibility that have made possible the rates of economic growth which this year external economic factors make less possible. It is their capacity for accepting tough times upon which the well-being of this country rests. Those who abuse the workers of Australia should remember that.

It is a tragedy that we have an Opposition that is run by the incompetent and sometimes faceless men whose answer to the economic difficulties of the 1980s is a return to the appalling conditions suffered by workers in the early part of this century. (Quorum formed) It is rather ironic that the name of the society which runs the Opposition is that of a man who fought hard for the rights of workers in the mines in the early part of this century.

For the wage and salary earners whom we represent, it is important that the services the Government provides meet their needs, the needs of their children and the needs of the older members of their families. Included in this Budget is a provision which is particularly helpful to those who suffer from chronic illnesses. Many of these people are not pensioners and, therefore, have found themselves, especially if they are diabetic, paying many hundreds of dollars each year over and above the Government's contribution to their medicines. These people will pay a maximum cost of up to $250 annually from November, and many will pay less. Diabetics who are taking insulin now will have their syringes provided without cost. Although the cost of the initial 25 prescriptions may be higher, the annual cost could be many hundreds of dollars less.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Andrew Hay-Sunday Telegraph:Poster-Terrorist Organisations-East Hills Naval Estate-Telecom Australia-Fringe Benefits Tax-Road Safety-Qantas Airways Ltd.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take strong issue with the President of the Victorian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr Andrew Hay, who spoke yesterday to a luncheon hosted by the Melbourne Rotary Club. I quote the report of his speech in today's edition of the Australian, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hay, in the most public warning to the Liberals by the New Right, said Australia had to introduce a tax system with a maximum rate of 30 per cent.
Mr Hay is quoted as saying:
I and others have made it clear to Mr Howard that if he does not bite the bullet the conservative ground will be populated by other than the Liberal Party.

What arrogance! That statement is not made as a threat to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). It is a purposeful and conscious attempt to intimidate every member of the Liberal Party of Australia, both parliamentary and organisational. Do Mr Hay and the Victorian Chamber of Commerce think that they are in a position to blackmail the Liberal Party? Clearly, Mr Hay is putting forward proposals that would suit the sectarian interests of his members, and it is his right to lobby such views. However, the Liberal Party cannot and will not be blackmailed into passively accepting the narrow self-interested views of any organisation. The Liberal Party Federal platform states:
Members of Parliament are responsible to their electors alone and not subject to direction by people or organisations inside or outside Parliament.

Thankfully, that provision makes one of the greatest distinctions between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. Independence from outside organisations has always been a central pillar of the Liberal Party. I quote Sir William Spooner in the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 December 1945, who said:
A political party cannot retain public confidence if there is doubt in the public mind as to its complete freedom from any influence or control.

If Mr Hay wishes to influence Liberal Party policy, he should debate his points in the various forums of the Party and test their acceptability by a free and democratic vote of Party members. However, while the Liberal Party platform remains worded as it is, there is no way in which the Victorian Chamber of Commerce or any other organisation can dictate to the Liberal Party by way of threats or intimidation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter that relates to a newspaper in Australia, the so-called family newspaper, the Sunday Telegraph, and more particularly last Sunday's issue of 14 September. I do so in the context that I think newspapers have a responsibility to provide accurate information to the public. Last Sunday, while travelling through New South Wales after I had spent three days in that State with the country task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), I noticed a poster displayed outside many of the milk bars. I have the poster here and it reads: `Kids to be hit by FBT'. I stopped the car and decided to buy a copy of the Sunday Telegraph. For three days I and my colleagues had been listening to much misinformation produced by the National Party of Australia about FBT, and I proceeded to read through the newspaper to find the story. I believe that it is very wrong to have such a poster outside milk bars giving such a message to the public when there is not one story in the newspaper that mentions anything relating to the poster. It is wrong that a newspaper should place a poster such as this in a place in that paper where everybody can read it, a poster in a family newspaper which says `Kids to be hit by FBT', and then not follow it up with a story. Having bought the newspaper, I decided to plough my may through it to see what it had to say. It has an editorial in relation to the fringe benefits tax. It says that there are too many holes in the FBT bucket.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take a couple of points from the editorial to give an illustration of the misinformation that is being provided. The newspaper in its editorial makes the claim that government departments will be paying the FBT-in other words, for public servants and politicians from both sides of the House-that governments do not have money of their own and that this is something new-something new for governments to be taxing themselves. I am afraid that the newspaper apparently does not realise that every person who works for a department, whether it be the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Defence or any other department at the Federal level, is certainly paying pay as you earn tax and has been doing so since the PAYE system was introduced.

This newspaper is amazed that governments are now paying tax on their own employees. It does not realise that there are people in the community who receive their accommodation or other benefits over and above their salary and wage and have been getting away with it. That is the issue. This newspaper has tried to develop a story which clearly indicates that the Government is doing something new by collecting tax and paying it to the Treasury. Everybody would be aware, I would expect, except for the editor of this newspaper, the writer of the article, that this is not so. The editor believes that this is something new, that government departments taking tax from their employees is something new. I honestly believe that a power such as this is so misleading that it is my intention to draw it to the attention of the Press Council.

Those of us who toured Australia with the task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had clear indication of the deliberate misrepresentation that has been put around about the FBT. It has been reported to our committee over and over again that the tax will impact upon people in certain circumstances and that those persons-country-wide-have enough problems with the downturn in commodity prices without having to deal with the total misinformation that is provided. The only statement that I have found in the last month where this has been mentioned at all was one by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), who, I understand, was making a claim that had something to do with people who drive their children to school or drive them to catch a bus being taxed for their efforts. It is a disgrace that this sort of misinformation has been peddled. It is a disgrace for a newspaper such as the Sunday Telegraph to take the position of presenting a poster which is absolutely false and misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many Australians are becoming alarmed at this Government's support of overseas terrorist organisations. There has been the recent exposure that the Australia Council blatantly used taxpayers' money-$5,000 of it-with the full support of this Government to fund the Palestine Liberation Organisation operation in Australia known as the Palestine Information Office. This office in Melbourne is headed by the self-styled PLO representative in Australia, Mr Ali Kazak. Equally disturbing is the desire of the Government to fund and lend support to African terrorist organisations. It has already given its blessing to the establishment of an information office for the African National Congress and the South West African People's Organisation. The Government invited them here. It has even set up a fund called the African Liberation Trust Fund headed by the Federal Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to appeal for money for that trust fund.

SPEECH.PARA: The ANC's Sydney offices are located in the Trades Hall, Goulburn Street. One wonders whether the ANC is paying rent on those premises. The New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party has given $1,000 to both SWAPO and the ANC in clear breach of the Federal Government's own laws on foreign aid and incursions. The South Australian Branch has given them $250 each also. As well, two ANC men have received training from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in film production techniques. They are being either financed or assisted by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Federal Government, the ABC Staff Union and ABC management.

The Department of Foreign Affairs has also been instructed to examine ways to fund ANC and SWAPO. These are communist groups backed from Moscow and have as their policy the violent overthrow of the South African Government and the installation of a one-party Marxist state. This was beautifully summed up by the words of Michael Davis, a Labor delegate from the Maroubra State Electorate Council, who said:
We should not pretend that the ANC is about liberation when we know that communist revolution has never liberated anyone.

The ANC has a history going back to 1912. The Communist Party in South Africa at that time began eying at an early stage the rise of the ANC. By 1936, with an overlap of membership between the Communist Party and the ANC, an intimate relationship had been cemented between these two groups. For example, J. B. Marks, a Communist Party member who became Secretary-General of the ANC and who was a student at the Lenin School in Moscow, died in Russia in 1972. The Kremlin gave him an official funeral. The Secretary-General of the Communist Party, Moses Kotane, became the next Secretary-General of the ANC. Later, in 1943 Abraham Fischer, South Africa's most senior communist, drafted a new constitution for the ANC.

With the clampdown on the Communist Party that occurred in the ensuing years they were forced to take a lower profile. In the 1960s they decided to promote the ANC as the spearhead of the revolutionary liberation movement. Soon after Nelson Mandela emerged as its leader. The Communist Party and the ANC began a joint campaign of sabotage and terrorism in South Africa until they were raided in 1963. Mandela was arrested and gaoled for his part in a revealed plot to overthrow the Government by armed revolution. Terrorist acts then fell away sharply until the late 1970s. However, with millions of dollars being poured into the ANC from the United Nations, and with base facilities being provided in nearby countries such as Mozambique, acts of ANC terrorism rose again.

In the 1980s there emerged a switch of policy from sabotaging state installations to attacking civilians. The murder of innocent men, women, children and babies by the ANC is presided over by the executive council of that body. Of the 30 members of the executive, no fewer than 23 are members or active supporters of the South African Communist Party. Their attacks are aimed largely at blacks who work within the system with the aim of intimidating the population into submission. Moderate blacks are being brutally murdered in their hundreds, by radical blacks. Black businesses are being destroyed in their thousands. Black policemen are particular targets. Several hundred schools and a number of health clinics have also been destroyed-all serving the black community. Individuals are killed by necklacing, a process whereby a tyre is jammed over the body and arms and set alight. ANC spokesman Alosi Moloi justified this in October 1985 by saying:
You have to eliminate one to save hundreds of others.
His colleague, Tim Ngubane, also said:
We want to make the death of a collaborator so grotesque that people will never think of it.
Even in April this year Winnie Mandela said:
. . . with our boxes of matches and our necklaces we shall liberate this country.

Though we all want to see an end to apartheid, no reasonable Australian would support these deliberate and despicable policies of brutality. I call on this Government not only to stop assisting such terrorism but also to expel the ANC and SWAPO organisations from Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say what a delight it is to follow the sensitive and compassionate contribution by the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), whose obsession with people with black skin is well known to all honourable members. Unlike the honourable member, I raise a matter of concern to people in my electorate. I do not embark upon some ideological hobby-horse for the benefit of the News Weekly.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter that I seek to raise concerns the conditions of my constituents in the East Hills naval estate in the electorate of Hughes. I begin by complimenting the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on the outstanding contribution he has already made to the well-being of service families. As my fellow Australian Labor Party members will know, including the honourable members for Brand (Ms Fatin) and for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), the Minister for Defence has made some outstanding reforms that have drastically improved the standard of living of service families. The initiative that the Minister took to create the Hamilton report, and the action that he has further taken to implement those recommendations, will literally transform service life in this country.

When I became the member for Hughes, I confessed to not knowing a lot about the conditions that service families experienced, but I have come to regard them as having been the subject of years of neglect by previous governments. It is a tragedy that those who purport to believe in an efficient and well-organised defence force for this country have failed so dramatically in past years to do anything for the conditions of service personnel. The matter that I seek to raise concerns an aberration and a forgotten outpost of service families in Australia, the East Hills naval estate to which I have already referred. It can truly be called the forgotten residential outpost of the Royal Australian Navy. During a recent visit to that estate, I met with the spouses of Navy personnel and found an extremely distressing low level of morale and many social problems which, regrettably, the Navy has yet to confront. I draw the attention of the House to some of those problems. First, there is a serious lack of transport, with only three bus services during the whole day. There is some possibility of a morning school bus, but the mothers informed me that they cannot take prams on that bus. That is a major cause for concern.

There is a dilapidated footbridge across the Georges River, which is their only convenient access to the East Hills railway station. That bridge is so dilapidated as to be positively dangerous to the service families and particularly to children. There are no lights on that bridge, which, as I have indicated, forms a vital link to the only available railway station. There is such a lack of shopping facilities that the local residents are unable to go to any corner shop or get to any shop without a long period of travel. There is a misleading road sign on Heathcote Road, which results in unnecessary traffic going to that estate and causing a hazard to local families. There is a great deal of uncertainty in the local community as to who is responsible for their plight. The residents do not know who owns the land. I would draw the attention of the Minister for Defence to the need to give some back-up to those local residents. There is a need for extensive tree-planting, a post box, a public phone and a move by the Minister and the Navy to build a real sense of community identity for this forgotten residential outpost.

Importantly, I draw the attention of the House to the Voyager Park in the estate, which is a memorial to the men who tragically lost their lives on the Voyager. That park is in a very run-down and dilapidated condition and does not reflect well upon the Navy in its important 75th anniversary year. I draw the attention of the Minister to these important concerns of my constituents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today, the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) made a big song and dance about the level of cross-subsidy that Telecom Australia gives to rural people in the form of telephone services. I was very interested to listen to the Minister, because I happen to be a member of the sub-committee of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, along with the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), who chairs that sub-committee. During our deliberations, we have looked at some length at the level of cross-subsidy between metropolitan and rural subscribers to Telecom. We have had some difficulty in obtaining precise figures. That is why I was interested to hear the Minister quoting exact figures today. He talked about $531 per year per service for the constituents of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), and talked about $1,083 per service in relation to the electorate of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). I think that is what one calls four significant figures in mathematical language.

SPEECH.PARA: That sort of precision is very interesting, because it appears from the transcripts of the Expenditure Committee hearing held on 29 May-of course, they are public documents-that we were looking at the cross-subsidy which, at that stage, Telecom was trying to claim was $492m. It is interesting to note from the Press release dated 24 August, to which the Minister referred today, that the cross-subsidy for 1984-85 has dropped to $459m. I am slightly curious to know why it is dropping. Perhaps it indicates that people in the country are using the telephone more than they used to and more proportionately than their city counterparts.

The Expenditure Committee has been looking at this matter in some detail. The transcript of that hearing shows that Mr Pitt, the Financial Studies and Development Manager of Telecom, when queried about the level of cross-subsidy, had some interesting things to say. In part, he said:
Our best estimate of the cross-subsidy metropolitan to country in 1984-85 was of the order of $400m to $500m.
That is very different from the figure quoted by the Minister for Communications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is telling the truth?

—I do not know who is telling the truth, but I am trying to point out that one of the senior members of Telecom has admitted that the figure is of the order of $400m to $500m. With someone in Telecom as vague as that, it is very interesting to hear the Minister trying to provide precise figures. It is interesting to note that the chairman of the sub-committee, who happens to be present tonight, also quoted from Mr Ergas, who is an expert on telecommunications and who came out from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to look at Telecom. He had this to say on how to work out the cross-subsidy:

SPEECH.PARA: It is nonetheless extraordinarily difficult, if not impossible, to rigorously determine the extent of the cross-subsidisation inherent in a given structure of telecommunication prices.

I raise this point not because I question whether there is a cross-subsidy-obviously there is-but because the Minister gave some precise figures in the chamber today. He has made some claims that these precise figures show that there is a level of cross-subsidy in certain country electorates. However, when we look at what the Expenditure Committee found, we see that these figures are very vague. They are not precise. A figure of the order of $400m to $500m is very different from the precise figure of $459m quoted by the Minister-a figure which the previous year seemed to be a lot higher, at $492m. I suspect that the pressure which the Expenditure Committee has put on Telecom forced it to reduce the cross-subsidy figure that it had been quoting, but it is up to the Minister to be quite frank with members of this chamber and admit that it is a ball-park figure, that it is not precise and that a figure of the order of $400m to $500m is very different from $459m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in response to some of the comments made by my colleague on the Standing Committee on Expenditure, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who mentioned my name as the sub-committee chairman for the inquiry relating to Telecom Australia. It was interesting to listen to some of the comments of the honourable member for Wannon tonight, because the essence of his contribution was not to deny that there was a cross-subsidy, but to say that the cross-subsidy was of the order of $400m to $500m. I think the figure that was mentioned today by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in an answer in Question Time was $459m, which is very close to halfway between $400m and $500m.

SPEECH.PARA: The important element in the whole debate about cross-subsidy-significantly and honestly, the honourable member for Wannon does not deny that there is a cross-subsidy-is that no member of this House would have the audacity to deny that a cross-subsidy exists within the national communications system operated by Telecom Australia.

I shall remind the House of a couple of interesting points about the extent of the cross- subsidy. Perhaps it is worth reminding ourselves of those points in the context of the debate on privatisation. The area within one square mile of Sydney central business district accounts for 20 per cent of Telecom's total revenue Australia-wide. If one extrapolates such information to Melbourne and the other capital cities of Australia, I think it would be fair to say that some 50 to 60 per cent-perhaps even more-of Telecom's total revenue comes from that area. In other words, we can understand why some elements within our society are very keen to tap into the main trunk routes between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne. Essentially, that is where the profits are.

Who would want to build and operate a private communications system in the electorate of Wannon? Quite clearly, whoever did so would go broke. Who would want to operate a private telecommunications system in Dubbo? Quite clearly, whoever did so would also go broke. That is the important point about the whole cross-subsidy argument. Telecom provides a very fair system whereby people, wherever they live in Australia, get the benefit of the fact that a large percentage of our population is concentrated in very few urban centres. If we were able to draw a line between the cities of Brisbane and Adelaide, even including the State of Tasmania, that would account for 90 per cent of Australia's total population. It is significant that, within that relatively small area in a geographical sense, we have such a huge concentration of population. It is important to realise that, with such geographical information, Telecom, as the national communications system operator in Australia, has a responsibility to provide a communications system, a telephone system, to people, wherever they live.

I admit-it is on the public record of the hearings of the Expenditure Committee-that the whole question of the methodology of the cross-subsidy is being addressed, as it should properly be addressed during such an important inquiry. If the honourable member persists with his claim that the cross-subsidy is of the order of $400m to $500m, I will accept an intermediate point of about $450m. Even if the honour- able member errs on the side of $400m, I do not think that what the Minister for Communications said today will be fundamentally different in terms of the total figures that are available to each of those areas nominated by the Minister today. If the honourable member for Wannon errs on the side of generosity, towards $500m, there will be a quite significant difference. I think that it is in the interests of everyone, especially those members who represent rural and provincial electorates of Australia, to argue very strongly for the principle of the cross-subsidy so that we are not threatened by some of the ideological nonsense that is talked about with privatisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September, I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Hawke,

The Hawke Socialist Government's Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation is not only grossly unjust-it is bad Law. It is vague, uncertain, contradictory and ambiguous. It is an absolute shambles. It is a legal jungle and an Accountant's nightmare. Some of the best business brains in Australia still cannot understand it months after it has been passed through the Parliament. It is unintelligible.

Prime Minister, in recent weeks you, the Treasurer, and others have made a number of public statements seeking to clarify this incredible Legislation. There have been comments on possible amendments; correcting certain glaring anomalies; suggestions of administrative changes and gratuitous `on the spot' advice whenever the mood takes you. A classic example was the ad hoc-and ill-prepared-`advice' in the House yesterday by your Treasurer on the use of Log Books in Motor Vehicles.
If the Treasurer of Australia demonstrably does not fully understand his own Legislation how can your Government demand that the citizens of Australia be compelled to comply with such a bad Law?

I am advised that of the 100 Questions put to the Australian Taxation Office on your hotch-potch Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation at least 30 per cent of the Questions have not been properly answered at all. I am further advised that several leading Counsel and Tax Experts have described a significant proportion of the Answers as `absolutely useless'.

Prime Minister, the right to disobey Objectionable Laws-and by so doing to challenge the same in the Courts-is constitutionally well recognised. The great Dicey held that `there are political limits on what parliament may impose on the people. If parliament chooses to pass a thoroughly unacceptable law, it can command obedience only by meeting resistance with massive forces'. Blackstone properly asserted `the right to rebel' while at the same time acknowledging the principle of the `sovereignty of parliament'. Thirteen years ago the distinguished C. P. Mills of the University of Sydney wrote in The Australian Law Journal that `Most of us today are conditioned to the idea of the ultimate supremacy of the parliamentary will, and so it seems axiomatic to us that the law (whatever it decrees) must be obeyed, but it was not always so in the English experience. The Great Charter of 1215 and the Bill of Rights of 1689 were products of revolt against what were then regarded as oppressive laws'. Mills also noted that the American colonists asserted their right to rebel, not only as a `natural' right, but also as `a right due to them as subjects of George III'. The learned author concluded his treatise `Wherever it is claimed that parliament has an absolute and limited right to legislate, such a claim by its very nature will give rise to another claim, that of the right to resist oppressive or unjust laws'. (47 A.L.J. 278-80.)

With respect to your comments in the House yesterday, I remind you of your own public statements on the Law during the Vietnam Debate, and many of your comments on the Law and its application during your term as President of the ACTU. I am certain you will also recall the arguments put to the High Court of Australia in Thompson's Case, which you will find reported in 118 C.L.R. 488 and Giltinan's Case 45 A.L.J.R. 372. Whilst those challenging the National Service Laws in these cases were unsuccessful it is clear that the Court was not unaware of the deep divisions in public opinion, and further that many public utterances of then Federal Ministers denouncing the resistors as `rejecting the rule of law' were seen to be more than slightly hypocritical.

Prime Minister, I was admitted to the Bar on 19 February 1962 and appointed Queens Counsel in January 1984. In 24 years in the Law and nearly 20 years in Parliaments-both State and Federal-I have never before advocated that citizens should not comply with the Law, and by so doing provoke a challenge to the said Law in the Courts. I maintain it is the fundamental right of any Australian to create a situation where an unjust, objectionable, uncertain and ambiguous Law can be tested, where it should be tested-in the Courts. Your Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation fits every one of the four adjectives I have just enunciated. I admit to you and the Attorney-General that I uttered the aforementioned views in an address I gave to a combined Liberal Party Branches Dinner in Melbourne on Thursday last, 11 September. I believe that my comments were fully justified-and I stand by them. If you think otherwise you may well consider it your duty to take advice as to whether you should charge me with inciting a breach of Commonwealth Law. I assure you that I will strenuously defend any proceedings which may be instituted against me in any court.
Yours faithfully,
HON. MICHAEL HODGMAN QC MP
Federal Member for Denison

I await a reply from this gutless wonder of a Prime Minister as to whether he will uphold the law, whether he will prosecute Bob Ansett, who will not pay the tax and whether he will prosecute me for an alleged breach of the law by inciting a breach of Commonwealth laws. This Prime Minister and this Treasurer (Mr Keating) know that this law is unjust and that no prosecution will succeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently, while in the southern part of the Throsby electorate, I visited the Bomaderry ambulance station. The visit resulted from my Press release to the local media, which drew attention to the success of the Australia-wide campaign to reduce deaths on our roads. As honourable members will be aware, statistics released earlier this year by the Federal Office of Road Safety show that, while the number of cars has increased in the last decade, the number of fatalities has actually dropped. Statistics also reveal that Australia's road safety campaign compares more than favourably with similar campaigns in Europe. Following my Press release on road safety I was contacted by Mr Selwyn Watt, an ambulance officer at Huskisson in the Shoalhaven area. We discussed efforts to date to reduce the road toll, and Mr Watt, speaking from his experience as an ambulance officer, suggested possible ways in which fatalities could be further reduced. At my suggestion, Mr Watt then wrote to me, putting his ideas on paper. I arranged to meet with him and fellow ambulance officers to discuss the matter personally.

SPEECH.PARA: All the ambulance officers, speaking from many years experience in attending road accidents, agreed that efforts to date to reduce the road toll had been highly effective. In particular, they applauded the introduction of seat belts, random breath testing, and the use of helmets by motor-bike riders and cyclists, especially children. They also applauded road safety campaigns conducted in recent years by the Federal Government. They then drew my attention to one particular cause of death and serious and permanent injury. From time to time, they said, they arrived at the scene of a road accident to find that a victim, being unconscious, had died not because of injuries sustained in the accident but because of asphyxiation. In many cases there were passers-by at the scene of the accident who, had they known, had only to tilt back the unconscious person's head to clear the airway, thus ensuring that the victim would continue to breathe properly. The ambulance officers also made the point that, even when the victim survived, partial asphyxiation had been known to cause irreparable brain damage.

Drawing on his own experience, Mr Watt said that on one occasion he arrived at the scene of an accident to find several motorists already present. They were standing beside a young motor-cyclist who was dead. He had been knocked out when he fell from his motor-bike and, his head having dropped forward, he had died of asphyxiation. Subsequent examination established that his only other injury was a broken leg. The other ambulance officers were all able to give similar examples. They said that many lives could be saved if only passing motorists, who are almost always the first persons present at the scene of a motor accident, had some skills in basic first-aid. This, they suggested, could be ensured if new motor vehicle drivers licences were issued to only those persons who have attended a course in basic first-aid and obtained an appropriate certificate. The course would need to cover airway management and haemorrhage control, but need not entail cardiac-pulmonary arrest. The officers said the course would not need to be very lengthy, nor need it be very complicated. They further suggested that, in order to keep it as simple and practical as possible, they are strongly of the opinion that ambulance officers themselves should conduct such courses. Quite apart from saving lives in motor accidents, the recommended first aid course would result in many more people in our community having basic first-aid and life-saving skills, which would prove invaluable in the work place, at home and wherever people gather for recreation. Another suggestion put forward by the ambulance officers was that every motor vehicle should contain a first-aid kit, and that no vehicle should be passed for registration which did not contain such a kit. The kit, they further suggested, should be inspected and passed on an annual basis as part of the normal registration of motor vehicles.

No doubt there will be those in the community who will oppose these recommendations. Some will say that they would represent an unnecessary infringement of the motorist's personal freedom. Others will argue that they will constitute yet another expense imposed upon the motoring public. Both these arguments, honourable members will recall, were used against the introduction of the compulsory use of seat belts, the compulsory wearing of safety helmets and random breath testing. Yet all three measures have done much to save lives and considerably reduce serious injury on our roads. They have also saved millions of dollars for Australian taxpayers in the form of reduced hospital care, and for the general public in the form of lower insurance premiums and, of course, for insurance companies themselves.

I therefore endorse the recommendations put to me by the ambulance officers with whom I recently spoke and commend them to the House. Surely there are measures on which we can all agree, irrespective of the side of the House on which we may sit. I would hope that, following a reasonable period of public debate, which would necessarily involve State as well as Federal parliaments and departments, the recommendations I have received might be implemented without undue delay. I will certainly be discussing them with the Federal Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport Safety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn recently to an answer by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) to a question on notice dated 17 September about air service arrangements. It concerns Qantas Airways Ltd. I would like to bring it to the attention of the House, because devaluation has had some benefits and Qantas and tourism may be seen to be benefiting by that. But waiting in the wings, so to speak, some negotiations need to take place with the United States of America on new air treaties. They are being renegotiated for the first time in many years. I am advised that there is some dispute between the Minister for Aviation and the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) as to who will actually undertake these vital negotiations.
—Who won?
—I do not think that it has been resolved yet. On the track record of the two Ministers, one would hope that the Minister for Aviation would be the one to have the stewardship of those negotiations.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of those negotiations is illustrated by the contribution that Qantas makes to the Australian economy. The interesting point about existing arrangements is that Qantas has only four entry points into the United States, whereas under the existing agreements the United States has many more entry points into Australia. It is quite clear-the Minister says this in the answer to that question, and I agree with him-that the existing arrangements are not fair and do not provide an equal opportunity. He says that we will be negotiating on the capacity of those routes and, more importantly, the route entitlements. We, for example, would like to be able to fly directly into Chicago. So the importance of those renegotiated treaties cannot be overestimated. It is quite clear from the statistics that foreign airlines historically are not good at bringing foreign tourists to Australia. Qantas now outcarries foreign airlines by three to one in bringing tourists into Australia. For example, last year Qantas brought 100,000 more Americans to Australia than all the United States airlines combined.

The problems for Qantas lie in the very real possibility of capacity dumping by the United States airlines on the United States of America-Australia routes. The concern exists that the United States-Australia routes account for more than 30 per cent of Qantas's entire traffic, yet the routes account for only 2 per cent of the traffic for the United States airlines, primarily Continental Airlines and United Air Lines. Qantas must be allowed to compete on an equal footing. For this reason, in our recent aviation policy we have said that we will permit interlining by Qantas on domestic airline routes. Qantas must be permitted to utilise currently wasted capacity which exists because Qantas cannot fly domestic passengers on the domestic component of international routes. Qantas is currently Australia's only major export industry without access to any part of a domestic industry. Qantas is also a major export earner for Australia and it operates in an almost totally deregulated market against 31 major competitors. We should examine the international aviation economy and the valuable part played by Qantas in helping Australia overcome its present disastrous trade imbalance-and we all recognise that from both sides of the House.

On a global scale, the aviation industry produces more economic activity than anything else. The total annual international airline revenue is $180 billion. Added to this is an annual tourism revenue of a further $100 billion. The international airline market is worth around $5 billion to Australia. While Qantas has a 43 per cent market share, the total market is still just 1.5 per cent of the total world market. Qantas believes that it is feasible to double this to 3 per cent of the total market by the end of the decade. So these negotiations are absolutely vital for this country to secure rights for Qantas to make sure that it can meet that projection, because if we do not do that we are cutting our own throats and we are giving to other operators the opportunity to earn income for their countries that we badly need here at this time. The increased growth would mean that a further $1 billion would be added to Qantas's existing $1.3 billion overseas earnings.

Qantas's total contribution to the Australian economy is already about $4 billion. In terms of export earnings, Qantas ranks only behind coal, iron ore, wheat and wool. That should give honourable members some idea of the significance of its activities. It has had some difficulties with devaluation, labour costs, the size of the company, geography and foreign government subsidies to airlines, all of which have affected it. Cargo is another area that needs to be looked at, and that would involve, of course, the Department of Trade.

I go back to my very first point. There is real concern that the renegotiation of these treaties, which are absolutely vital to our foreign earning capacity, may get bogged down in the bureaucratic argument between the Minister for Aviation and the Minister for Trade, and we just cannot afford to let that happen.
